10,000,000 Volt Thunderbolt.name: 10,000,000 Volt Thunderbolt
10,000,000 Volt Thunderbolt.effects: 10,000,000 Volt Thunderbolt is an Electric type Z-Move exclusive to Ash-Pikachu. It is used with Thunderbolt. 10,000,000 Volt Thunderbolt deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
10,000,000 Volt Thunderbolt.gameDescription: The user, Pikachu wearing a cap, powers up a jolt of electricity using its Z-Power and unleashes it. Critical hits land more easily.

Absorb.name: Absorb
Absorb.effects: Absorb deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained. If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokemon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
Absorb.gameDescription: A nutrient-draining attack. The user’s HP is restored by half the damage taken by the target.

Accelerock.name: Accelerock
Accelerock.effects: Accelerock deals damage and has high priority. Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
Accelerock.gameDescription: The user smashes into the target at high speed. This move always goes first.

Acid.name: Acid
Acid.effects: Acid deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Acid.changes: In Generations 1-3, Acid has a 10% chance of lowering Defense. This is likely because Acid is a Physical move in those games.
Acid.gameDescription: The opposing Pokémon are attacked with a spray of harsh acid. This may also lower their Sp. Def stat.

Acid Armor.name: Acid Armor
Acid Armor.effects: Acid Armor raises the user's Defense by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Acid Armor.changes: In Generations 1-5, Acid Armor has 40 PP.
Acid Armor.gameDescription: The user alters its cellular structure to liquefy itself, sharply raising its Defense stat.

Acid Downpour.name: Acid Downpour
Acid Downpour.effects: Acid Downpour is the Poison type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Acid Downpour.gameDescription: The user creates a poisonous swamp using its Z-Power and sinks the target into it at full force. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Acid Spray.name: Acid Spray
Acid Spray.effects: Acid Spray inflicts damage and lowers the target's Special Defense by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Acid Spray.gameDescription: The user spits fluid that works to melt the target. This harshly lowers the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Acrobatics.name: Acrobatics
Acrobatics.effects: Acrobatics deals damage, however, if the user is not holding an item, its power doubles to 110. If the user is holding a Flying Gem, it is consumed before the Pokemon attacks, so it receives both boosts and increases Acrobatics' power to 165. Once the Gem is consumed Acrobatics' power for the rest of the battle will be 110.
Acrobatics.gameDescription: The user nimbly strikes the target. If the user is not holding an item, this attack inflicts massive damage.
Acrobatics.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Acupressure.name: Acupressure
Acupressure.effects: Acupressure raises a random stat - Attack, Defense, Speed, Special Attack, Special Defense, Accuracy or Evasion - by two stages. It will always choose a stat that is not already maximized. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each. Acupressure is unlike other status moves in that it can be targeted at itself or an adjacent teammate. It cannot be used on an ally if they are behind a Substitute, but the user can apply Acupressure to itself if behind a Substitute.
Acupressure.gameDescription: The user applies pressure to stress points, sharply boosting one of its or its allies’ stats.
Acupressure.target: Targets either the user or an adjacent Pokemon on the user’s team.

Aerial Ace.name: Aerial Ace
Aerial Ace.effects: Aerial Ace deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Aerial Ace.gameDescription: The user confounds the target with speed, then slashes. This attack never misses.
Aerial Ace.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Aeroblast.name: Aeroblast
Aeroblast.effects: Aeroblast deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Aeroblast.gameDescription: A vortex of air is shot at the target to inflict damage. Critical hits land more easily.
Aeroblast.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

After You.name: After You
After You.effects: After You forces the target to attack first in the next turn. It can be targeted at opponents or team-mates.
After You.gameDescription: The user helps the target and makes it use its move right after the user.

Agility.name: Agility
Agility.effects: Agility raises the user's Speed by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Agility.gameDescription: The user relaxes and lightens its body to move faster. This sharply raises the Speed stat.

Air Cutter.name: Air Cutter
Air Cutter.effects: Air Cutter deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Air Cutter.changes: In Generations 3-5, Air Cutter has base power 55.
Air Cutter.gameDescription: The user launches razor-like wind to slash the opposing Pokémon. Critical hits land more easily.

Air Slash.name: Air Slash
Air Slash.effects: Air Slash deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Air Slash.gameDescription: The user attacks with a blade of air that slices even the sky. This may also make the target flinch.
Air Slash.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

All-Out Pummeling.name: All-Out Pummeling
All-Out Pummeling.effects: All-Out Pummeling is the Fighting type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
All-Out Pummeling.gameDescription: The user rams an energy orb created by its Z-Power into the target with full force. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Ally Switch.name: Ally Switch
Ally Switch.effects: In a triple battle, if the user is on either the left or right of the team (not in the middle), Ally Switch switches with the Pokemon on the other end of the team.
Ally Switch.gameDescription: The user teleports using a strange power and switches places with one of its allies.

Amnesia.name: Amnesia
Amnesia.effects: Amnesia raises the user's Special Defense by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Amnesia.gameDescription: The user temporarily empties its mind to forget its concerns. This sharply raises the user’s Sp. Def stat.

Anchor Shot.name: Anchor Shot
Anchor Shot.effects: The user entangles the target with its anchor chain while attacking. The target becomes unable to flee.
Anchor Shot.gameDescription: The user entangles the target with its anchor chain while attacking. The target becomes unable to flee.

Ancient Power.name: Ancient Power
Ancient Power.effects: Ancient Power deals damage and has a 10% chance of raising all the user's stats at once - Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed - by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Ancient Power.changes: In Generations 2-5, this move's name was formatted as AncientPower.
Ancient Power.gameDescription: The user attacks with a prehistoric power. This may also raise all the user’s stats at once.

Aqua Jet.name: Aqua Jet
Aqua Jet.effects: Aqua Jet deals damage and has a priority of +1. Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
Aqua Jet.gameDescription: The user lunges at the target at a speed that makes it almost invisible. This move always goes first.

Aqua Ring.name: Aqua Ring
Aqua Ring.effects: The user of Aqua Ring surrounds itself with a veil of water, which restores 1⁄16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn. If the user is holding a Big Root, Aqua Ring restores 30% more HP each turn - approximately 1⁄12 of its maximum.
Aqua Ring.gameDescription: The user envelops itself in a veil made of water. It regains some HP every turn.

Aqua Tail.name: Aqua Tail
Aqua Tail.effects: Aqua Tail deals damage with no additional effect.
Aqua Tail.gameDescription: The user attacks by swinging its tail as if it were a vicious wave in a raging storm.

Arm Thrust.name: Arm Thrust
Arm Thrust.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 30
3 3⁄8 45
4 1⁄8 60
5 1⁄8 75

 Arm Thrust hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Arm Thrust is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Arm Thrust to always hit the maximum number of times.
Arm Thrust.changes: In Generations 3-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generation 3, Arm Thrust ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute.
Arm Thrust.gameDescription: The user lets loose a flurry of open-palmed arm thrusts that hit two to five times in a row.

Aromatherapy.name: Aromatherapy
Aromatherapy.effects: Cures all status problems in your party.
Aromatherapy.gameDescription: The user releases a soothing scent that heals all status conditions affecting the user’s party.
Aromatherapy.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Aromatic Mist.name: Aromatic Mist
Aromatic Mist.effects: Aromatic Mist raises the Special Defense of the user and its teammates by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Aromatic Mist.gameDescription: The user raises the Sp. Def stat of an ally Pokémon by using a mysterious aroma.

Assist.name: Assist
Assist.effects: In a Double Battle, user randomly attacks with a partner's move.
Assist.gameDescription: The user hurriedly and randomly uses a move among those known by ally Pokémon.

Assurance.name: Assurance
Assurance.effects: Assurance deals damage, and if the target has already taken damage in this turn its power doubles to 120.
Assurance.changes: In Generations 4-5, Assurance has base power 50.
Assurance.gameDescription: If the target has already taken some damage in the same turn, this attack’s power is doubled.

Astonish.name: Astonish
Astonish.effects: Astonish deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Astonish.gameDescription: The user attacks the target while shouting in a startling fashion. This may also make the target flinch.

Attack Order.name: Attack Order
Attack Order.effects: Attack Order deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Attack Order.gameDescription: The user calls out its underlings to pummel the target. Critical hits land more easily.

Attract.name: Attract
Attract.effects: Attract causes Pokémon of the opposite gender to become infatuated. Infatuated Pokémon have a 50% chance of being immobilized by love each turn and unable to attack. Attract will fail on Pokémon of the same gender, genderless Pokémon and those with the ability Oblivious. Mew and Cryogonal can learn Attract via TM despite being genderless, however, the move will have no effect.
Attract.gameDescription: If it is the opposite gender of the user, the target becomes infatuated and less likely to attack.

Aura Sphere.name: Aura Sphere
Aura Sphere.effects: Aura Sphere deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Aura Sphere.changes: In Generations 4-5, Aura Sphere has base power 90.
Aura Sphere.gameDescription: The user lets loose a blast of aura power from deep within its body at the target. This attack never misses.
Aura Sphere.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Aurora Beam.name: Aurora Beam
Aurora Beam.effects: Aurora Beam deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Attack by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Aurora Beam.gameDescription: The target is hit with a rainbow-colored beam. This may also lower the target’s Attack stat.

Aurora Veil.name: Aurora Veil
Aurora Veil.effects: Aurora Veil halves damage from Physical and Special attacks for five turns.
Aurora Veil.gameDescription: This move reduces damage from physical and special moves for five turns. This can be used only in a hailstorm.
Aurora Veil.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Autotomize.name: Autotomize
Autotomize.effects:
Autotomize raises the user's Speed by two stages and halves its weight. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each. Decreasing weight affects these moves: 
Grass Knot (lower damage when receiving)
Heat Crash (lower damage when attacking, higher damage when receiving)
Heavy Slam (lower damage when attacking, higher damage when receiving)
Low Kick (lower damage when receiving)
 The effect of the weight change cannot be Baton-Passed (but the Speed change is passed as normal).
Autotomize.gameDescription: The user sheds part of its body to make itself lighter and sharply raise its Speed stat.

Avalanche.name: Avalanche
Avalanche.effects: Power doubles if user took damage first.
Avalanche.gameDescription: The power of this attack move is doubled if the user has been hurt by the target in the same turn.

Baby-Doll Eyes.name: Baby-Doll Eyes
Baby-Doll Eyes.effects: Baby-Doll Eyes lowers the target's Attack by one stage, and moves with priority +1.
Baby-Doll Eyes.gameDescription: The user stares at the target with its baby-doll eyes, which lowers its Attack stat. This move always goes first.

Baneful Bunker.name: Baneful Bunker
Baneful Bunker.effects: In addition to protecting the user from attacks, this move also poisons any attacker that makes direct contact.
Baneful Bunker.gameDescription: In addition to protecting the user from attacks, this move also poisons any attacker that makes direct contact.

Barrage.name: Barrage
Barrage.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 30
3 3⁄8 45
4 1⁄8 60
5 1⁄8 75

 Barrage hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Barrage is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Barrage to always hit the maximum number of times.
Barrage.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Barrage ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
Barrage.gameDescription: Round objects are hurled at the target to strike two to five times in a row.

Barrier.name: Barrier
Barrier.effects: Barrier raises the user's Defense by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Barrier.gameDescription: The user throws up a sturdy wall that sharply raises its Defense stat.

Baton Pass.name: Baton Pass
Baton Pass.effects:
Baton Pass causes the user to switch out for another Pokémon, passing any stat changes to the Pokémon that switches in. These effects are passed: 
Increases and decreases in Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed. For example the effects from Nasty Plot, Swords Dance and Screech (if targeted at the user of Baton Pass).
The sure hit effect from Lock-On and Mind Reader. In other words, after using either move followed by Baton Pass, the next move from the incoming Pokémon will always hit.
The confusion status ailment.
A Substitute, which keeps its remaining HP.
Trapping effects from Mean Look, Block and Spider Web, on both the user and opponent.
Critical hit ratio increase from the move Focus Energy or a Lansat Berry.
The HP-restoring effects of Aqua Ring and Ingrain.
The HP-depleting effect of Curse (when used by a Ghost-type on the user).
The effects of the moves Embargo, Gastro Acid, Magnet Rise, Perish Song and Power Trick.
Baton Pass.gameDescription: The user switches places with a party Pokémon in waiting and passes along any stat changes.

Beak Blast.name: Beak Blast
Beak Blast.effects: The user first heats up its beak, and then it attacks the target. Making direct contact with the Pokémon while it’s heating up its beak results in a burn.
Beak Blast.gameDescription: The user first heats up its beak, and then it attacks the target. Making direct contact with the Pokémon while it’s heating up its beak results in a burn.

Beat Up.name: Beat Up
Beat Up.effects:
Beat Up deals damage from each Pokémon on your team that does not have a status ailment (nor is fainted). Each strike has a different base power, calculated as: UsersBaseAttack ÷ 10 + 5
 However, the actual attack is carried out by the original user of Beat Up, so it will always use that Pokémon's current attack stat to calculate damage. It will also receive any boosts from the originating user, such as STAB and any applicable items. However, any items held by the rest of the team do not affect the damage dealt. Each strike of Beat Up is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
Beat Up.changes: In Generations 2-4, Beat Up deals 10 base power typeless damage from each able Pokémon (using each Pokémon's Attack stat).
Beat Up.gameDescription: The user gets all party Pokémon to attack the target. The more party Pokémon, the greater the number of attacks.

Belch.name: Belch
Belch.effects: Belch deals damage, but only works if the user has previously consumed a Berry during the battle. Manually feeding a Berry from the bag does not count.
Belch.gameDescription: The user lets out a damaging belch at the target. The user must eat a held Berry to use this move.

Belly Drum.name: Belly Drum
Belly Drum.effects: User loses 50% of its max HP, but Attack raises to maximum.
Belly Drum.gameDescription: The user maximizes its Attack stat in exchange for HP equal to half its max HP.

Bestow.name: Bestow
Bestow.effects: Bestow gives the user's held item to the target. It will not work if the target is already holding an item or is behind a Substitute. Mail cannot be transferred. Items bestowed upon wild Pokémon are permanently lost if the Pokémon is KO'd, but items lost in Trainer battles are returned. All held items in wi-fi/linked battles (including Battle Tower/Subway/Maison) are returned to their respective owners at the end of a battle. Pokemon with the ability Sticky Hold cannot have their held item removed. The Griseous Orb cannot be removed from Giratina; Type Plates cannot be removed from Arceus; Drives cannot be removed from Genesect; and Mega Stones cannot be removed from their respective Pokémon.
Bestow.gameDescription: The user passes its held item to the target when the target isn’t holding an item.

Bide.name: Bide
Bide.effects: The user of Bide stores energy for 2 turns. At the end of the second turn the Pokémon unleashes energy, dealing twice the HP damage it received. Bide deals fixed, typeless damage, so will hit Ghost-type Pokémon. It also ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats and can hit Pokémon in the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop. In double and triple battles, Bide hits the last Pokémon to attack the user (including teammates).
Bide.changes: In Generations 1-3, Bide is not an increased priority move. It also stores energy for 2-3 turns. In Generations 2-3, Bide does not hit Ghost-type Pokémon.
Bide.gameDescription: The user endures attacks for two turns, then strikes back to cause double the damage taken.

Bind.name: Bind
Bind.effects: Bind inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the opponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
Bind.changes: In Generations 1-4, Bind has 75% accuracy. Its after-effects last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5. In Generation 1, Bind simply inflicts its base power damage for 2-5 turns. While in effect, the target is unable to attack.
Bind.gameDescription: Things such as long bodies or tentacles are used to bind and squeeze the target for four to five turns.

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.effects: Bite deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Bite.changes: In Generation 1 Bite is a Normal type move and is categorized as Physical. In Generation 2, Bite's type was changed to the newly-introduced Dark type. Due to the type-based categorization of moves, it became a Special move until Generation 4 when it was returned to the Physical category.
Bite.gameDescription: The target is bitten with viciously sharp fangs. This may also make the target flinch.

Black Hole Eclipse.name: Black Hole Eclipse
Black Hole Eclipse.effects: Black Hole Eclipse is the Dark type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Black Hole Eclipse.gameDescription: The user gathers dark energy using its Z-Power and sucks the target into it. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Blast Burn.name: Blast Burn
Blast Burn.gameDescription: The target is razed by a fiery explosion. The user can’t move on the next turn.

Blaze Kick.name: Blaze Kick
Blaze Kick.effects: Blaze Kick deals damage and has a 10% chance of burning the target. It also has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16). Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned. Pokémon with the abilities Battle Armor or Shell Armor are protected against critical hits.
Blaze Kick.gameDescription: The user launches a kick that lands a critical hit more easily. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Blizzard.name: Blizzard
Blizzard.effects: Blizzard deals damage and has a 10% chance of freezing the target. It will hit both opponents in a double battle or adjacent opponents in a triple battle. Ice type Pokémon, those with the ability Magma Armor or those behind a Substitute cannot be frozen. During a hailstorm, Blizzard has 100% accuracy.
Blizzard.changes: In Generations 1-5, Blizzard has base power 120. In Diamond/Pearl only, Blizzard has a 25% chance of hitting through Protect or Detect during hail. In Generation 1, Blizzard has 90% accuracy. In the original Japanese Red/Green, it has a 30% chance to freeze the opponent.
Blizzard.gameDescription: A howling blizzard is summoned to strike opposing Pokémon. This may also leave the opposing Pokémon frozen.

Block.name: Block
Block.gameDescription: The user blocks the target’s way with arms spread wide to prevent escape.

Bloom Doom.name: Bloom Doom
Bloom Doom.effects: Bloom Doom is the Grass type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Bloom Doom.gameDescription: The user collects energy from plants using its Z-Power and attacks the target with full force. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Blue Flare.name: Blue Flare
Blue Flare.effects: Blue Flare deals damage and has a 20% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Blue Flare.gameDescription: The user attacks by engulfing the target in an intense, yet beautiful, blue flame. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Body Slam.name: Body Slam
Body Slam.effects: Body Slam deals damage and has a 30% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Body Slam.gameDescription: The user drops onto the target with its full body weight. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Bolt Strike.name: Bolt Strike
Bolt Strike.effects: Bolt Strike deals damage and has a 20% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Bolt Strike.gameDescription: The user surrounds itself with a great amount of electricity and charges its target. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Bone Club.name: Bone Club
Bone Club.effects: Bone Club deals damage and has a 10% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Bone Club.gameDescription: The user clubs the target with a bone. This may also make the target flinch.

Bone Rush.name: Bone Rush
Bone Rush.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 50
3 3⁄8 75
4 1⁄8 100
5 1⁄8 125

 Bone Rush hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Bone Rush is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Bone Rush to always hit the maximum number of times.
Bone Rush.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 2-3, Bone Rush ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generations 2-4, Bone Rush has 80% accuracy.
Bone Rush.gameDescription: The user strikes the target with a hard bone two to five times in a row.

Bonemerang.name: Bonemerang
Bonemerang.effects:
Bonemerang deals damage and will strike twice (with 50 base power each time).
Each strike of Bonemerang is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
Bonemerang.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Bonemerang ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
Bonemerang.gameDescription: The user throws the bone it holds. The bone loops around to hit the target twice—coming and going.

Boomburst.name: Boomburst
Boomburst.effects: Boomburst deals massive damage and targets all adjacent Pokémon in battle, including allies.
Boomburst.gameDescription: The user attacks everything around it with the destructive power of a terrible, explosive sound.

Bounce.name: Bounce
Bounce.effects: The user of Bounce will spring up on the first turn, disappearing from view and becoming invulnerable to most attacks. On the second turn, Bounce deals damage and has a 30% chance of paralyzing the target. While in the air, the Pokemon can only be hit by the moves Gust, Twister, Thunder, Sky Uppercut and Smack Down, with Gust and Twister dealing twice normal damage. Moves from No Guard Pokemon, or any move following an identify move can also hit for regular power. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed. If the user is holding a Power Herb, Bounce executes in one turn.
Bounce.gameDescription: The user bounces up high, then drops on the target on the second turn. This may also leave the target with paralysis.
Bounce.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Brave Bird.name: Brave Bird
Brave Bird.effects: Brave Bird deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄3 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 90 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 30 HP.
Brave Bird.gameDescription: The user tucks in its wings and charges from a low altitude. This also damages the user quite a lot.
Brave Bird.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Breakneck Blitz.name: Breakneck Blitz
Breakneck Blitz.effects: Breakneck Blitz is the Normal type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Breakneck Blitz.gameDescription: The user builds up its momentum using its Z-Power and crashes into the target at full speed. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Brick Break.name: Brick Break
Brick Break.effects: Brick Break deals damage, but removes the effects of Reflect and Light Screen before attacking.
Brick Break.changes: In Generations 1-4, Brick Break removes the Reflect and Light Screen barriers even if the attack itself does not affect the opponent (being a Ghost-type for example).
Brick Break.gameDescription: The user attacks with a swift chop. It can also break barriers, such as Light Screen and Reflect.

Brine.name: Brine
Brine.effects: Power doubles if opponent's HP is less than 50%.
Brine.gameDescription: If the target’s HP is half or less, this attack will hit with double the power.

Brutal Swing.name: Brutal Swing
Brutal Swing.effects: The user swings its body around violently to inflict damage on everything in its vicinity.
Brutal Swing.gameDescription: The user swings its body around violently to inflict damage on everything in its vicinity.

Bubble.name: Bubble
Bubble.effects: Bubble deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Speed by one stage.
Bubble.changes: In Generations 1-5, Bubble has base power 20.
Bubble.gameDescription: A spray of countless bubbles is jetted at the opposing Pokémon. This may also lower their Speed stat.

Bubble Beam.name: Bubble Beam
Bubble Beam.effects: Bubble Beam deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Speed by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Bubble Beam.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as BubbleBeam.
Bubble Beam.gameDescription: A spray of bubbles is forcefully ejected at the target. This may also lower its Speed stat.

Bug Bite.name: Bug Bite
Bug Bite.effects: Bug Bite deals damage, and if the target is holding a Berry, the user eats it and gains its effect. For example, if the target is holding a Sitrus Berry the user will recover 1⁄4 of the its HP. Bug Bite cannot steal a berry from a Substitute.
Bug Bite.gameDescription: The user bites the target. If the target is holding a Berry, the user eats it and gains its effect.

Bug Buzz.name: Bug Buzz
Bug Buzz.effects: Bug Buzz deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Bug Buzz.gameDescription: The user generates a damaging sound wave by vibration. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Bulk Up.name: Bulk Up
Bulk Up.effects: Bulk Up raises the user's Attack and Defense by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Bulk Up.gameDescription: The user tenses its muscles to bulk up its body, raising both its Attack and Defense stats.

Bulldoze.name: Bulldoze
Bulldoze.effects: Bulldoze deals damage and lowers the target's Speed by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Bulldoze.gameDescription: The user strikes everything around it by stomping down on the ground. This lowers the Speed stat of those hit.

Bullet Punch.name: Bullet Punch
Bullet Punch.effects: Bullet Punch deals damage and has a priority of +1. Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
Bullet Punch.gameDescription: The user strikes the target with tough punches as fast as bullets. This move always goes first.

Bullet Seed.name: Bullet Seed
Bullet Seed.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 50
3 3⁄8 75
4 1⁄8 100
5 1⁄8 125

 Bullet Seed hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Bullet Seed is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Bullet Seed to always hit the maximum number of times.
Bullet Seed.changes: In Generations 3-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generation 3, Bullet Seed ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generations 3-4, Bullet Seed has a base power of 10.
Bullet Seed.gameDescription: The user forcefully shoots seeds at the target two to five times in a row.

Burn Up.name: Burn Up
Burn Up.effects: To inflict massive damage, the user burns itself out. After using this move, the user will no longer be Fire type.
Burn Up.gameDescription: To inflict massive damage, the user burns itself out. After using this move, the user will no longer be Fire type.

Calm Mind.name: Calm Mind
Calm Mind.effects: Calm Mind raises the user's Special Attack and Special Defense by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Calm Mind.gameDescription: The user quietly focuses its mind and calms its spirit to raise its Sp. Atk and Sp. Def stats.

Camouflage.name: Camouflage
Camouflage.effects:
Camouflage causes the user to change its type based on the current terrain: 
Normal type in buildings, paved/plain terrain or wi-fi/linked battles.
Grass type in standard grassy areas or when Grassy Terrain is in effect.
Ground type in desert, beaches or rocky terrain.
Rock type in caves.
Water type when surfing on water.
Ice type in snow or in icy caves.
Fairy type when Misty Terrain is in effect.
Electric type when Electric Terrain is in effect.
Camouflage.gameDescription: The user’s type is changed depending on its environment, such as at water’s edge, in grass, or in a cave.

Captivate.name: Captivate
Captivate.effects: Captivate lowers the Special Attack of the target by two stages, if they are of the opposite gender to the user. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Captivate will fail if both Pokemon are the same gender, either Pokemon is genderless, or the target has the ability Oblivious.
Captivate.gameDescription: If any opposing Pokémon is the opposite gender of the user, it is charmed, which harshly lowers its Sp. Atk stat.

Catastropika.name: Catastropika
Catastropika.effects: Catastropika is a Z-Move exclusive to Pikachu. It can only be used with Volt Tackle.
Catastropika.gameDescription: The user, Pikachu, surrounds itself with the maximum amount of electricity using its Z-Power and pounces on its target with full force.

Celebrate.name: Celebrate
Celebrate.effects: The Pokémon congratulates you on your special day. No battle effect.
Celebrate.gameDescription: The Pokémon congratulates you on your special day!

Charge.name: Charge
Charge.effects: Charge raises the user's Special Defense by one stage, and if this Pokémon's next move is a damage-dealing Electric-type attack, it will deal double damage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Charge.changes: In Generations 1-3, Charge does not raise Special Defense.
Charge.gameDescription: The user boosts the power of the Electric move it uses on the next turn. This also raises the user’s Sp. Def stat.

Charge Beam.name: Charge Beam
Charge Beam.effects: Charge Beam deals damage and has a 70% chance of raising the user's Special Attack by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Charge Beam.gameDescription: The user attacks with an electric charge. The user may use any remaining electricity to raise its Sp. Atk stat.

Charm.name: Charm
Charm.effects: Charm lowers the target's Attack by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Charm.changes: In Generations 2-5, Charm is a Normal type move.
Charm.gameDescription: The user gazes at the target rather charmingly, making it less wary. This harshly lowers its Attack stat.

Chatter.name: Chatter
Chatter.effects: Chatter deals damage and causes the target to become confused. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Chatter.changes: In Generations 4-5, Chatter has base power 60. In Generations 4-5, the player's voice can be recorded and this recording is played back when the move is used. The louder the recording, the more likely Chatter is to cause confusion. The chance of confusion can be 1%, 11% or 31% for a low, medium or high volume respectively. Chatot was previously banned from online play due to the possibility of inappropriate phrases being recorded with Chatter (although the recording is always somewhat distorted).
Chatter.gameDescription: The user attacks the target with sound waves of deafening chatter. This confuses the target.
Chatter.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Chip Away.name: Chip Away
Chip Away.effects: Chip Away deals damage, but ignores changes to the target's stats (i.e. Defense and Evasion in this case). Note this does not include the effects of screens like Reflect as they are different to regular stat boosts.
Chip Away.gameDescription: Looking for an opening, the user strikes consistently. The target’s stat changes don’t affect this attack’s damage.

Circle Throw.name: Circle Throw
Circle Throw.effects: In battles, the opponent switches. In the wild, the Pokémon runs.
Circle Throw.gameDescription: The target is thrown, and a different Pokémon is dragged out. In the wild, this ends a battle against a single Pokémon.

Clamp.name: Clamp
Clamp.effects: Clamp inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the opponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
Clamp.changes: In Generations 1-4, Clamp has 75% accuracy. Its after-effects last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5. In Generation 1, Clamp simply inflicts its base power damage for 2-5 turns. While in effect, the target is unable to attack.
Clamp.gameDescription: The target is clamped and squeezed by the user’s very thick and sturdy shell for four to five turns.

Clanging Scales.name: Clanging Scales
Clanging Scales.effects: Clanging Scales deals damage but lowers the user's Defense by one stage after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Clanging Scales.gameDescription: The user rubs the scales on its entire body and makes a huge noise to attack the opposing Pokémon. The user’s Defense stat goes down after the attack.

Clear Smog.name: Clear Smog
Clear Smog.effects: Removes all of the target's stat changes.
Clear Smog.gameDescription: The user attacks by throwing a clump of special mud. All stat changes are returned to normal.

Close Combat.name: Close Combat
Close Combat.effects: Close Combat deals damage but lowers the user's Defense and Special Defense by one stage each after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Close Combat.gameDescription: The user fights the target up close without guarding itself. This also lowers the user’s Defense and Sp. Def stats.

Coil.name: Coil
Coil.effects: Coil raises the user's Attack, Defense and Accuracy by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Coil.gameDescription: The user coils up and concentrates. This raises its Attack and Defense stats as well as its accuracy.

Comet Punch.name: Comet Punch
Comet Punch.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 36
3 3⁄8 54
4 1⁄8 72
5 1⁄8 90

 Comet Punch hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Comet Punch is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Comet Punch to always hit the maximum number of times.
Comet Punch.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Comet Punch ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
Comet Punch.gameDescription: The target is hit with a flurry of punches that strike two to five times in a row.

Confide.name: Confide
Confide.effects: Confide lowers the target's Special Attack by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Confide.gameDescription: The user tells the target a secret, and the target loses its ability to concentrate. This lowers the target’s Sp. Atk stat.

Confuse Ray.name: Confuse Ray
Confuse Ray.effects: Confuse Ray causes the target to become confused. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Confuse Ray.gameDescription: The target is exposed to a sinister ray that triggers confusion.

Confusion.name: Confusion
Confusion.effects: Confusion deals damage and has a 10% chance of confusing the target. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Confusion.gameDescription: The target is hit by a weak telekinetic force. This may also confuse the target.

Constrict.name: Constrict
Constrict.effects: Constrict deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Speed by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Constrict.gameDescription: The target is attacked with long, creeping tentacles, vines, or the like. This may also lower the target’s Speed stat.

Continental Crush.name: Continental Crush
Continental Crush.effects: Continental Crush is the Rock type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Continental Crush.gameDescription: The user summons a huge rock mountain using its Z-Power and drops it onto the target with full force. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Conversion.name: Conversion
Conversion.effects: Conversion changes the user's type to the same type as the first move in the Pokémon's move list. For example, if the Pokémon has the moves Psybeam, Discharge, Recover and Conversion in that order, Conversion will change the user's type to Psychic.
Conversion.changes: In Generation 1, Conversion changes the user's type to the target Pokémon's type. In Generations 2-4, Conversion changes the user's type to the type of any one of its moves randomly. It also cannot be used on Curse as it is the ??? type.
Conversion.gameDescription: The user changes its type to become the same type as the move at the top of the list of moves it knows.

Conversion 2.name: Conversion 2
Conversion 2.effects: Conversion 2 changes the user's type to one that is resistant (or immune) to the last move used by the target, randomly. For example, if the target last used a Fighting type move, Conversion 2 would change the user's type to one of Poison, Flying, Psychic, Bug, Ghost or Fairy at random.
Conversion 2.changes: In Generations 2-4, Conversion 2 only takes into account damaging moves that hit the user (from any Pokémon).
Conversion 2.gameDescription: The user changes its type to make itself resistant to the type of the attack the opponent used last.

Copycat.name: Copycat
Copycat.gameDescription: The user mimics the move used immediately before it. The move fails if no other move has been used yet.

Core Enforcer.name: Core Enforcer
Core Enforcer.effects: Scorches a 'Z' pattern on the ground.
Core Enforcer.gameDescription: If the Pokémon the user has inflicted damage on have already used their moves, this move eliminates the effect of the target’s Ability.

Corkscrew Crash.name: Corkscrew Crash
Corkscrew Crash.effects: Corkscrew Crash is the Steel type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Corkscrew Crash.gameDescription: The user spins very fast and rams into the target with the full force of its Z-Power. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Cosmic Power.name: Cosmic Power
Cosmic Power.effects: Cosmic Power raises the user's Defense and Special Defense by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Cosmic Power.gameDescription: The user absorbs a mystical power from space to raise its Defense and Sp. Def stats.

Cotton Guard.name: Cotton Guard
Cotton Guard.effects: Cotton Guard raises the user's Defense by three stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each. Assuming no other stat changes, the first use of Cotton Guard would raise Defense to 2.5× normal value, and the second to 4× (the maximum level).
Cotton Guard.gameDescription: The user protects itself by wrapping its body in soft cotton, which drastically raises the user’s Defense stat.

Cotton Spore.name: Cotton Spore
Cotton Spore.effects: Cotton Spore lowers the target's Speed by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Cotton Spore.changes: In Generations 1-4, Cotton Spore has 85% accuracy.
Cotton Spore.gameDescription: The user releases cotton-like spores that cling to the opposing Pokémon, which harshly lowers their Speed stat.

Counter.name: Counter
Counter.effects: When hit by a Physical Attack, user strikes back with 2x power.
Counter.gameDescription: A retaliation move that counters any physical attack, inflicting double the damage taken.

Covet.name: Covet
Covet.effects: Covet deals damage and steals the target's held item, if the user is not already holding an item. Items stolen from wild Pokémon are kept after the battle ends, but items stolen from a Trainer's Pokémon are not. Items stolen from the player's Pokémon, either by wild Pokémon or Trainer Pokémon, are returned at the end of the battle. All held items in wi-fi/linked battles (including Battle Tower/Subway/Maison) are returned to their respective owners at the end of a battle. If the item would activate on attack (e.g. Focus Band), it does so before being stolen. If the item is consumable on attack (e.g. Focus Sash) then the item is consumed as normal and cannot be stolen. Pokemon with the ability Sticky Hold cannot have their held item removed. The Griseous Orb cannot be removed from Giratina; Type Plates cannot be removed from Arceus; Drives cannot be removed from Genesect; and Mega Stones cannot be removed from their respective Pokémon.
Covet.changes: In Generations 3-5, Covet has 40 PP. In Generations 3-4, Covet has a base power of 40. In Generations 3-4, Covet steals a Trainer Pokémon's item permanently, but a wild Pokémon or a Trainer's Pokémon using Covet will not steal the player's item at all.
Covet.gameDescription: The user endearingly approaches the target, then steals the target’s held item.

Crabhammer.name: Crabhammer
Crabhammer.effects: Crabhammer deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Crabhammer.changes: In Generations 1-5, Crabhammer has base power 90. In Generations 1-4, Crabhammer has 85% accuracy.
Crabhammer.gameDescription: The target is hammered with a large pincer. Critical hits land more easily.

Crafty Shield.name: Crafty Shield
Crafty Shield.effects: Crafty Shield protects the user's team from any Status category move used by any opponent. It does not protect against attacking moves. Its accuracy drops to 50% if used consecutively after itself or any other protecting move.
Crafty Shield.gameDescription: The user protects itself and its allies from status moves with a mysterious power. This does not stop moves that do damage.

Cross Chop.name: Cross Chop
Cross Chop.effects: Cross Chop deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Cross Chop.gameDescription: The user delivers a double chop with its forearms crossed. Critical hits land more easily.

Cross Poison.name: Cross Poison
Cross Poison.effects: Cross Poison deals damage and has a 10% chance of poisoning the target. It also has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16). Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Cross Poison.gameDescription: A slashing attack with a poisonous blade that may also poison the target. Critical hits land more easily.

Crunch.name: Crunch
Crunch.effects: Crunch deals damage and has a 20% chance of lowering the target's Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Crunch.changes: In Generations 1-3, Crunch instead may lower Special Defense one stage. This is likely because Crunch is a Special move before those games.
Crunch.gameDescription: The user crunches up the target with sharp fangs. This may also lower the target’s Defense stat.

Crush Claw.name: Crush Claw
Crush Claw.effects: Crush Claw deals damage and has a 50% chance of lowering the target's Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Crush Claw.gameDescription: The user slashes the target with hard and sharp claws. This may also lower the target’s Defense stat.

Crush Grip.name: Crush Grip
Crush Grip.effects:
Crush Grip inflicts more damage when the opponent's HP is higher. At full HP its base power is 120 and it decreases in proportion - i.e. the power is: 120 × CurrentHP ÷ MaxHP
 Crush Grip is a Physical-category counterpart move to Wring Out. It is also similar to Water Spout and Eruption, based on the opponent rather than the user.
Crush Grip.gameDescription: The target is crushed with great force. The more HP the target has left, the greater this move’s power.

Curse.name: Curse
Curse.effects: Curse is a unique move that works differently for Ghost-type Pokémon than other Pokémon. Ghost-type Pokémon use 50% of their maximum HP to place a curse on the target. The cursed Pokémon loses 25% of their maximum HP every turn. If the user has less than 50% HP remaining, they will faint but the curse still takes effect. For all other Pokémon, Curse raises the user's Attack and Defense by one stage each and lowers Speed by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each, or lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Curse.changes: In Generations 1-4, Curse has its own type of ???
Curse.gameDescription: A move that works differently for the Ghost type than for all other types.

Cut.name: Cut
Cut.effects: Cut deals damage with no additional effect in battle.

Dark Pulse.name: Dark Pulse
Dark Pulse.effects: Dark Pulse deals damage and has a 20% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Dark Pulse.gameDescription: The user releases a horrible aura imbued with dark thoughts. This may also make the target flinch.
Dark Pulse.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Dark Void.name: Dark Void
Dark Void.effects: Dark Void puts the target(s) to sleep. It can only be used by Darkrai. It targets all adjacent opponents i.e. the opposing Pokémon in a single battle, both opponents in a double battle, three opponents if in the center of a triple battle, or two opponents if situated at the side in a triple battle. Each target is counted as a separate attack so it may succeed for all, any or none of the targets. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns. Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
Dark Void.changes: In Generations 4-6, Dark Void has 80% accuracy. It is usable by other Pokémon if selected via Metronome, Assist, or Sketched by Smeargle.
Dark Void.gameDescription: Opposing Pokémon are dragged into a world of total darkness that makes them sleep.

Darkest Lariat.name: Darkest Lariat
Darkest Lariat.effects: Darkest Lariat deals damage, but ignores changes to the target's stats (i.e. Defense and Evasion in this case).
Darkest Lariat.gameDescription: The user swings both arms and hits the target. The target’s stat changes don’t affect this attack’s damage.

Dazzling Gleam.name: Dazzling Gleam
Dazzling Gleam.effects: Dazzling Gleam deals damage and hits all adjacent opponents in double/triple battles.
Dazzling Gleam.gameDescription: The user damages opposing Pokémon by emitting a powerful flash.

Defend Order.name: Defend Order
Defend Order.effects: Defend Order raises the user's Defense and Special Defense by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Defend Order.gameDescription: The user calls out its underlings to shield its body, raising its Defense and Sp. Def stats.

Defense Curl.name: Defense Curl
Defense Curl.effects: Defense Curl raises the user's Defense by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each. After Defense Curl has been used at least once and while the user stays in battle, the power of Rollout and Ice Ball is double their regular base power.
Defense Curl.gameDescription: The user curls up to conceal weak spots and raise its Defense stat.

Defog.name: Defog
Defog.effects: Defog lowers the target's Evasion by one stage and removes entry hazards and barriers on both sides of the field. The moves affected are: Light Screen, Reflect, Mist, Safeguard, Spikes, Stealth Rock, Sticky Web and Toxic Spikes. Defog also clears foggy weather in battle (which causes Accuracy loss when present), however this weather condition is only present in Sinnoh (Diamond/Pearl/Platinum) and cannot be created in battle otherwise.
Defog.changes: In Generations 4-5, Defog only clears entry hazards on the target's side of the field. In Generation 4, Defog could lower the Evasion of a target behind a substitute.

Destiny Bond.name: Destiny Bond
Destiny Bond.effects: If the user faints, the opponent also faints.
Destiny Bond.gameDescription: After using this move, if the user faints, the Pokémon that landed the knockout hit also faints. Its chance of failing rises if it is used in succession.

Detect.name: Detect
Detect.effects: Detect prevents any attacks targeted at the user from striking on that turn. It is identical to Protect. Its accuracy drops to 50% if used consecutively after itself, Protect, Endure, Quick Guard or Wide Guard.
Detect.changes: In Generations 1-4, the accuracy of Detect drops by 50% each time when used consecutively after itself, Protect or Endure.
Detect.gameDescription: Enables the user to evade all attacks. Its chance of failing rises if it is used in succession.

Devastating Drake.name: Devastating Drake
Devastating Drake.effects: Devastating Drake is the Dragon type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Devastating Drake.gameDescription: The user materializes its aura using its Z-Power and attacks the target with full force. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Diamond Storm.name: Diamond Storm
Diamond Storm.effects: Diamond Storm deals damage and has a 50% chance of raising the user's Defense by one stage. It hits all adjacent opponents in double/triple battles. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Diamond Storm.gameDescription: The user whips up a storm of diamonds to damage opposing Pokémon. This may also sharply raise the user’s Defense stat.

Dig.name: Dig
Dig.effects: The user of Dig will burrow its way underground on the first turn, disappearing from view and becoming invulnerable to most attacks. On the second turn, Dig deals damage. While underground, the Pokemon can only be hit by the moves Earthquake, Magnitude or Fissure, with Earthquake and Magnitude dealing twice normal damage. Moves from No Guard Pokemon, or any move following an identify move can also hit for regular power. The user also avoids end-of-turn damage from Sandstorm and Hail when underground. If the user is holding a Power Herb, Dig executes in one turn.
Dig.changes: In Generations 1-3, Dig has a base power of 60.
Dig.gameDescription: The user burrows, then attacks on the next turn.

Disable.name: Disable
Disable.effects: Disable causes the previous move the target used to be disabled for 1-8 turns, which prevents the move's use.
Disable.changes: In Generations 1-3 it has 55% accuracy. In Generation 4 this is improved to 80%, and improved again to 100% from Generation 5 onward.
Disable.gameDescription: For four turns, this move prevents the target from using the move it last used.

Disarming Voice.name: Disarming Voice
Disarming Voice.effects: Disarming Voice deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Disarming Voice.gameDescription: Letting out a charming cry, the user does emotional damage to opposing Pokémon. This attack never misses.

Discharge.name: Discharge
Discharge.effects: Discharge deals damage and has a 30% chance of paralyzing the target(s). Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Discharge.gameDescription: The user strikes everything around it by letting loose a flare of electricity. This may also cause paralysis.

Dive.name: Dive
Dive.effects: The user of Dive will hide underwater on the first turn, disappearing from view and becoming invulnerable to most attacks. On the second turn, Dive deals damage. While underwater, the Pokemon can only be hit by the moves Surf, Whirlpool or Low Kick, with Surf and Whirlpool dealing twice normal damage. Moves from No Guard Pokemon, or any move following an identify move can also hit for regular power. The user also avoids end-of-turn damage from Sandstorm and Hail when underwater. If the user is holding a Power Herb, Dive executes in one turn.
Dive.changes: In Generations 1-3, Dive has a base power of 60.

Dizzy Punch.name: Dizzy Punch
Dizzy Punch.effects: Dizzy Punch deals damage and has a 20% chance of confusing the target. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Dizzy Punch.changes: In Generation 1, Dizzy Punch does not cause confusion.
Dizzy Punch.gameDescription: The target is hit with rhythmically launched punches. This may also leave the target confused.

Doom Desire.name: Doom Desire
Doom Desire.effects: Two turns after the move is selected, Doom Desire will deal damage. If the opponent switched Pokémon in the meantime, the damage dealt will depend on the Special Defense of the Pokémon the move hits, not the Pokémon it was originally targeted at.
Doom Desire.changes: In Generations 1-4, Doom Desire has a base power of 120 and 85% accuracy. The damage Doom Desire deals in these games is typeless. Furthermore, it uses the Special Defense stat (Defense in Generation 3 due to its categorization) of the originally targeted Pokémon, even if it switched out in the meantime.
Doom Desire.gameDescription: Two turns after this move is used, a concentrated bundle of light blasts the target.

Double Hit.name: Double Hit
Double Hit.effects:
Double Hit deals damage and will strike twice (with 35 base power each time). Each strike of Double Hit is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
Double Hit.changes: In Generation 4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint.
Double Hit.gameDescription: The user slams the target with a long tail, vines, or a tentacle. The target is hit twice in a row.

Double Kick.name: Double Kick
Double Kick.effects:
Double Kick deals damage and will strike twice (with 30 base power each time).
Each strike of Double Kick is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
Double Kick.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Double Kick ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
Double Kick.gameDescription: The target is quickly kicked twice in succession using both feet.

Double Slap.name: Double Slap
Double Slap.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 30
3 3⁄8 45
4 1⁄8 60
5 1⁄8 75

 Double Slap hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Double Slap is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Double Slap to always hit the maximum number of times.
Double Slap.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Double Slap ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest. In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as DoubleSlap.
Double Slap.gameDescription: The target is slapped repeatedly, back and forth, two to five times in a row.

Double Team.name: Double Team
Double Team.effects: Double Team raises the user's Evasiveness by one stage, thus making the user more difficult to hit. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Double Team.gameDescription: By moving rapidly, the user makes illusory copies of itself to raise its evasiveness.

Double-Edge.name: Double-Edge
Double-Edge.effects: Double-Edge deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄3 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 90 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 30 HP.
Double-Edge.changes: In Generations 1-2, the recoil is 1⁄4 of the damage inflicted. In Generation 1, Double-Edge has a base power of 100.
Double-Edge.gameDescription: A reckless, life-risking tackle. This also damages the user quite a lot.

Draco Meteor.name: Draco Meteor
Draco Meteor.effects: Draco Meteor deals damage but lowers the user's Special Attack by two stages after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Draco Meteor.changes: In Generations 4-5, Draco Meteor has base power 140.
Draco Meteor.gameDescription: Comets are summoned down from the sky onto the target. The attack’s recoil harshly lowers the user’s Sp. Atk stat.

Dragon Ascent.name: Dragon Ascent
Dragon Ascent.effects: Dragon Ascent deals damage but lowers the user's Defense and Special Defense by one stage each after attacking. It is the signature move of Rayquaza, and once learned allows Rayquaza to Mega-Evolve.
Dragon Ascent.gameDescription: After soaring upward, the user attacks its target by dropping out of the sky at high speeds. But it lowers its own Defense and Sp. Def stats in the process.

Dragon Breath.name: Dragon Breath
Dragon Breath.effects: Dragon Breath deals damage and has a 30% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Dragon Breath.changes: In Generations 2-5, this move's name was formatted as DragonBreath.
Dragon Breath.gameDescription: The user exhales a mighty gust that inflicts damage. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Dragon Claw.name: Dragon Claw
Dragon Claw.effects: Dragon Claw deals damage with no additional effect.
Dragon Claw.gameDescription: The user slashes the target with huge sharp claws.

Dragon Dance.name: Dragon Dance
Dragon Dance.effects: Dragon Dance raises the user's Attack and Speed by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Dragon Dance.gameDescription: The user vigorously performs a mystic, powerful dance that raises its Attack and Speed stats.

Dragon Hammer.name: Dragon Hammer
Dragon Hammer.effects: The user uses its body like a hammer to attack the target and inflict damage.
Dragon Hammer.gameDescription: The user uses its body like a hammer to attack the target and inflict damage.

Dragon Pulse.name: Dragon Pulse
Dragon Pulse.effects: Dragon Pulse deals damage with no additional effect.
Dragon Pulse.changes: In Generations 4-5, Dragon Pulse has base power 90.
Dragon Pulse.gameDescription: The target is attacked with a shock wave generated by the user’s gaping mouth.
Dragon Pulse.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Dragon Rage.name: Dragon Rage
Dragon Rage.effects: Dragon Rage always deals 40 HP damage to the target, regardless of typing. It has no additional effect.
Dragon Rage.gameDescription: This attack hits the target with a shock wave of pure rage. This attack always inflicts 40 HP damage.

Dragon Rush.name: Dragon Rush
Dragon Rush.effects: Dragon Rush deals damage and has a 20% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Dragon Rush.gameDescription: The user tackles the target while exhibiting overwhelming menace. This may also make the target flinch.

Dragon Tail.name: Dragon Tail
Dragon Tail.effects: In battles, the opponent switches. In the wild, the Pokémon runs.
Dragon Tail.gameDescription: The target is knocked away, and a different Pokémon is dragged out. In the wild, this ends a battle against a single Pokémon.

Drain Punch.name: Drain Punch
Drain Punch.effects: Drain Punch deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained. If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokemon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
Drain Punch.changes: In Generations 1-4, Drain Punch has a base power of 60 and only 5 PP.
Drain Punch.gameDescription: An energy-draining punch. The user’s HP is restored by half the damage taken by the target.

Draining Kiss.name: Draining Kiss
Draining Kiss.effects: Draining Kiss deals damage and the user will recover 75% of the HP drained.
Draining Kiss.gameDescription: The user steals the target’s HP with a kiss. The user’s HP is restored by over half of the damage taken by the target.

Dream Eater.name: Dream Eater
Dream Eater.effects: Dream Eater deals damage only on sleeping foes and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained. If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokemon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
Dream Eater.gameDescription: The user eats the dreams of a sleeping target. It absorbs half the damage caused to heal its own HP.

Drill Peck.name: Drill Peck
Drill Peck.effects: Drill Peck deals damage with no additional effect, besides being able to hit non-adjacent Pokémon in triple battles.
Drill Peck.gameDescription: A corkscrewing attack with a sharp beak acting as a drill.
Drill Peck.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Drill Run.name: Drill Run
Drill Run.effects: Drill Run deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Drill Run.gameDescription: The user crashes into its target while rotating its body like a drill. Critical hits land more easily.

Dual Chop.name: Dual Chop
Dual Chop.effects:
Dual Chop deals damage and will strike twice (with 40 base power each time).
Each strike of Dual Chop is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
Dual Chop.gameDescription: The user attacks its target by hitting it with brutal strikes. The target is hit twice in a row.

Dynamic Punch.name: Dynamic Punch
Dynamic Punch.effects: Dynamic Punch deals damage and confuses the target, if it hits. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Dynamic Punch.changes: In Generations 2-5, this move's name was formatted as DynamicPunch.
Dynamic Punch.gameDescription: The user punches the target with full, concentrated power. This confuses the target if it hits.

Earth Power.name: Earth Power
Earth Power.effects: Earth Power deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Earth Power.gameDescription: The user makes the ground under the target erupt with power. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Earthquake.name: Earthquake
Earthquake.effects: Earthquake deals damage, and will hit with double power if the opponent is underground due to the move Dig.
Earthquake.gameDescription: The user sets off an earthquake that strikes every Pokémon around it.

Echoed Voice.name: Echoed Voice
Echoed Voice.effects: Echoed Voice deals damage starting at base power 40, and increases by 40 each turn if used by any Pokémon on the field, up to a maximum base power of 200. It does not reset if it misses, as long as the move is attempted each turn. The power does not increase during a turn (if multiple Pokémon use it), only after each turn.
Echoed Voice.gameDescription: The user attacks the target with an echoing voice. If this move is used every turn, its power is increased.

Eerie Impulse.name: Eerie Impulse
Eerie Impulse.effects: Eerie Impulse lowers the target's Special Attack by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Eerie Impulse.gameDescription: The user’s body generates an eerie impulse. Exposing the target to it harshly lowers the target’s Sp. Atk stat.

Egg Bomb.name: Egg Bomb
Egg Bomb.effects: Egg Bomb deals damage with no additional effect.
Egg Bomb.gameDescription: A large egg is hurled at the target with maximum force to inflict damage.

Electric Terrain.name: Electric Terrain
Electric Terrain.effects: Electric Terrain creates a low-lying electric field for 5 turns, that prevents grounded Pokémon from falling asleep. The power of Electric type moves also increases by 50% while in effect. Grounded Pokémon are simply those that are not raised. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary. Electric Terrain is a terrain condition and can coexist at the same time as weather conditions, but not other terrain conditions. The move Nature Power turns into Thunderbolt under Electric Terrain.
Electric Terrain.gameDescription: The user electrifies the ground for five turns, powering up Electric-type moves. Pokémon on the ground no longer fall asleep.

Electrify.name: Electrify
Electrify.effects: Electrify causes the target's move to become Electric type, if it has yet to attack during that turn.
Electrify.gameDescription: If the target is electrified before it uses a move during that turn, the target’s move becomes Electric type.

Electro Ball.name: Electro Ball
Electro Ball.effects:
Ratio (r) Power


4 ≤ r 150
3 ≤ r < 4 120
2 ≤ r < 3 80
1 ≤ r < 2 60
r < 1 40

 Electro Ball inflicts more damage the faster the user is compared to the opponent. The table to the right shows the different base powers for each ratio, where r = UserSpeed ÷ TargetSpeed For example, if the user's Speed is at least 3 times more than the target but less than 4 times, Electro Ball hits with 120 base power.
Electro Ball.gameDescription: The user hurls an electric orb at the target. The faster the user is than the target, the greater the move’s power.

Electroweb.name: Electroweb
Electroweb.effects: Electroweb deals damage and lowers the target's Speed by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Electroweb.gameDescription: The user attacks and captures opposing Pokémon using an electric net. This lowers their Speed stat.

Embargo.name: Embargo
Embargo.effects: Embargo prevents the target using any items for five turns. This includes both held items and items used by the trainer such as medicines.
Embargo.changes: In Generations 1-4, Magic Coat does not deflect the effect of Embargo.
Embargo.gameDescription: This move prevents the target from using its held item for five turns. Its Trainer is also prevented from using items on it.

Ember.name: Ember
Ember.effects: Ember deals damage and has a 10% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Ember.gameDescription: The target is attacked with small flames. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Encore.name: Encore
Encore.effects: Encore forces the target to use the previously selected move for 3 turns. Encore does not work against Encore itself, Mimic, Mirror Move, Sketch, Struggle or Transform.
Encore.changes: In Generations 2-3 and Diamond/Pearl, it lasts for 2-6 turns. In Platinum/HeartGold/SoulSilver it lasts for 3-7 turns.
Encore.gameDescription: The user compels the target to keep using the move it encored for three turns.

Endeavor.name: Endeavor
Endeavor.effects: Endeavor reduces the opponent's HP to equal the user's. (It fails if the user's HP is higher than the target's.)
Endeavor.gameDescription: This attack move cuts down the target’s HP to equal the user’s HP.

Endure.name: Endure
Endure.effects: Endure allows the user to survive all attacks in that turn with at least 1 HP (including Pokémon that already have 1 HP remaining). Its accuracy drops to 50% if used consecutively after itself, Detect, Protect, Quick Guard or Wide Guard.
Endure.changes: In Generations 1-4, the accuracy of Endure drops by 50% each time when used consecutively after itself, Detect or Protect.
Endure.gameDescription: The user endures any attack with at least 1 HP. Its chance of failing rises if it is used in succession.

Energy Ball.name: Energy Ball
Energy Ball.effects: Energy Ball deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Energy Ball.changes: In Generations 4-5, Energy Ball has base power 80.
Energy Ball.gameDescription: The user draws power from nature and fires it at the target. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Entrainment.name: Entrainment
Entrainment.effects: Entrainment makes the target's ability the same as the user's. It does not work on Pokémon with the abilities Truant, Multitype or Zen Mode.
Entrainment.gameDescription: The user dances with an odd rhythm that compels the target to mimic it, making the target’s Ability the same as the user’s.

Eruption.name: Eruption
Eruption.effects:
Eruption inflicts more damage when the user's HP is higher. At full HP its base power is 150 and it decreases in proportion - i.e. the power is: 150 × CurrentHP ÷ MaxHP
 Eruption is a counterpart move to Water Spout. It is also similar to Crush Grip and Wring Out, based on the user rather than the opponent.
