Eruption.gameDescription: The user attacks opposing Pokémon with explosive fury. The lower the user’s HP, the lower the move’s power.

Explosion.name: Explosion
Explosion.effects: Explosion deals high damage, but causes the user to faint.
Explosion.changes: In Generations 1-4, the opponent's defense stat is temporarily halved when calculating the damage. This gives Explosion an effective power of 500. In Generation 1, Explosion has a base power of 170 (doubled to 340 with the defense-halving).
Explosion.gameDescription: The user attacks everything around it by causing a tremendous explosion. The user faints upon using this move.

Extrasensory.name: Extrasensory
Extrasensory.effects: Extrasensory deals damage and has a 10% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Extrasensory.gameDescription: The user attacks with an odd, unseeable power. This may also make the target flinch.

Extreme Evoboost.name: Extreme Evoboost
Extreme Evoboost.effects: Extreme Evoboost is a Z-Move exclusive to Eevee. It is used with Last Resort. Extreme Evoboost raises all the user's stats (Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense, Speed) by two stages each.
Extreme Evoboost.gameDescription: After obtaining Z-Power, the user, Eevee, gets energy from its evolved friends and boosts its stats sharply.

Extreme Speed.name: Extreme Speed
Extreme Speed.effects: Extreme Speed deals damage and attacks before the majority of other moves (priority of +2).
Extreme Speed.changes: In Generations 1-4, its priority is +1, which means that an opponent using other priority moves such as Quick Attack or Aqua Jet can attack before Extreme Speed if the opponent is faster. In Generations 2-5, this move's name was formatted as ExtremeSpeed.
Extreme Speed.gameDescription: The user charges the target at blinding speed. This move always goes first.

Facade.name: Facade
Facade.effects: Facade deals damage, and hits with double power (140) if the user is burned, poisoned or paralyzed. In the case of a burn, the usual attack-halving still occurs so Facade hits with an effective power of 70.
Facade.gameDescription: This attack move doubles its power if the user is poisoned, burned, or paralyzed.

Fairy Lock.name: Fairy Lock
Fairy Lock.effects: Fairy Lock prevents all Pokémon on the field from fleeing during the following turn.
Fairy Lock.gameDescription: By locking down the battlefield, the user keeps all Pokémon from fleeing during the next turn.

Fairy Wind.name: Fairy Wind
Fairy Wind.effects: Fairy Wind deals damage with no added effects.
Fairy Wind.gameDescription: The user stirs up a fairy wind and strikes the target with it.

Fake Out.name: Fake Out
Fake Out.effects: Fake Out attacks with a priority of +3 and causes the target to flinch if it hits. It is only successful on the first turn the Pokemon is in battle, but reset each time the Pokemon switches out and back in. Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Fake Out.changes: In Generations 1-4, Fake Out has priority +1.
Fake Out.gameDescription: This attack hits first and makes the target flinch. It only works the first turn the user is in battle.

Fake Tears.name: Fake Tears
Fake Tears.effects: Fake Tears lowers the target's Special Defense by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Fake Tears.gameDescription: The user feigns crying to fluster the target, harshly lowering its Sp. Def stat.

False Swipe.name: False Swipe
False Swipe.effects: Always leaves opponent with at least 1 HP.
False Swipe.gameDescription: A restrained attack that prevents the target from fainting. The target is left with at least 1 HP.

Feather Dance.name: Feather Dance
Feather Dance.effects: Feather Dance lowers the target's Attack by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Feather Dance.changes: In Generations 3-5, this move's name was formatted as FeatherDance.
Feather Dance.gameDescription: The user covers the target’s body with a mass of down that harshly lowers its Attack stat.

Feint.name: Feint
Feint.effects: Feint only hits if the target used Protect or Detect in the same turn. It also cancels Protect/Detect for the remainder of the turn, so subsequent moves in the same turn (in double/triple battles) can still hit.
Feint.changes: In Generations 1-4, Feint has a base power of 50.
Feint.gameDescription: This attack hits a target using a move such as Protect or Detect. This also lifts the effects of those moves.

Feint Attack.name: Feint Attack
Feint Attack.effects: Feint Attack deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Feint Attack.changes: In Generations 2-5, this move's name was spelled Faint Attack.
Feint Attack.gameDescription: The user approaches the target disarmingly, then throws a sucker punch. This attack never misses.

Fell Stinger.name: Fell Stinger
Fell Stinger.effects: Fell Stinger deals damage, and if the target is knocked out by this move, the user's Attack is raised by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Fell Stinger.changes: In Generation 6, Fell Stinger has base power 30.
Fell Stinger.gameDescription: When the user knocks out a target with this move, the user’s Attack stat rises drastically.

Fiery Dance.name: Fiery Dance
Fiery Dance.effects: Fiery Dance deals damage and has a 50% chance of raising the user's Special Attack by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Fiery Dance.gameDescription: Cloaked in flames, the user dances and flaps its wings. This may also raise the user’s Sp. Atk stat.

Final Gambit.name: Final Gambit
Final Gambit.effects: Inflicts damage equal to the user's remaining HP. User faints.
Final Gambit.gameDescription: The user risks everything to attack its target. The user faints but does damage equal to its HP.

Fire Blast.name: Fire Blast
Fire Blast.effects: Fire Blast deals damage and has a 10% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Fire Blast.changes: In Generations 1-5, Fire Blast has base power 120.
Fire Blast.gameDescription: The target is attacked with an intense blast of all-consuming fire. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Fire Fang.name: Fire Fang
Fire Fang.effects: Fire Fang deals damage, has a 10% chance of burning the target and has a 10% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned. Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Fire Fang.gameDescription: The user bites with flame-cloaked fangs. This may also make the target flinch or leave it with a burn.

Fire Lash.name: Fire Lash
Fire Lash.effects: The user strikes the target with a burning lash. This also lowers the target’s Defense stat.
Fire Lash.gameDescription: The user strikes the target with a burning lash. This also lowers the target’s Defense stat.

Fire Pledge.name: Fire Pledge
Fire Pledge.effects: Fire Pledge deals damage at base power 80. If a teammate uses Grass Pledge or Water Pledge in the same turn, the moves combine into one attack of base power 160 and added effects appear. The faster Pokemon moves first but waits for the other Pokemon to make their move. When the slower Pledge user moves, the combo attack hits the Pokemon the slower user was targeting. If Fire Pledge is used with Grass Pledge, the move animation shows Fire Pledge and a sea of fire envelops the foe's team is created that damages opponents 1⁄8 of their maximum HP each turn, for 4 turns. If Fire Pledge is used with Water Pledge, the move animation shows Water Pledge and a rainbow appears in the sky on your team's side that doubles the chance of moves' secondary effects occurring for 4 turns.
Fire Pledge.changes: In Generation 5, Fire Pledge has base power 50.
Fire Pledge.gameDescription: A column of fire hits the target. When used with its grass equivalent, its power increases and a vast sea of fire appears.

Fire Punch.name: Fire Punch
Fire Punch.effects: Fire Punch deals damage and has a 10% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Fire Punch.gameDescription: The target is punched with a fiery fist. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Fire Spin.name: Fire Spin
Fire Spin.effects: Fire Spin inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the opponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
Fire Spin.changes: In Generations 1-4, Fire Spin has a base power of 15 and 70% accuracy. Its after-effects last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5. In Generation 1, Fire Spin simply inflicts its base power damage for 2-5 turns. While in effect, the target is unable to attack.
Fire Spin.gameDescription: The target becomes trapped within a fierce vortex of fire that rages for four to five turns.

First Impression.name: First Impression
First Impression.effects: Although this move has great power, it only works the first turn the user is in battle.
First Impression.gameDescription: Although this move has great power, it only works the first turn the user is in battle.

Fissure.name: Fissure
Fissure.effects:
If it hits, Fissure is guaranteed to make the opponent faint. It is more likely to hit Pokémon that are of a lower level than the user. Its accuracy (as a percentage) is calculated as below, ignoring all other accuracy and evasion modifiers: UserLevel - TargetLevel + 30
 This means that Fissure will fail against a target Pokémon at least 30 levels above the user.
Fissure.changes: In Generation 1, Fissure has 30% accuracy and can hit Pokémon of any level, but does not affect Pokémon faster than the user.
Fissure.gameDescription: The user opens up a fissure in the ground and drops the target in. The target faints instantly if this attack hits.

Flail.name: Flail
Flail.effects:
Flail deals more damage the lower the user's HP. The following formula is used: N = 48 × CurrentHP ÷ MaxHP
 The value of N is then used to determine the base power, as per the table below. It converts to some quite specific percentages which are also shown. 

Ratio (N) HP (%) Power


0 ≤ N < 2 0 - 4.16 200
2 ≤ N < 4 4.17 - 10.41 150
5 ≤ N < 9 10.42 - 20.82 100
10 ≤ N < 16 20.83 - 35.41 80
17 ≤ N < 32 35.42 - 68.74 40
33 ≤ N ≤ 48 68.75 - 100 20
Flail.changes:
In Generations 2-4, Flail used a multiplier of 64 instead of 48. The table below shows the appropriate numbers. 

Ratio (N) HP (%) Power


0 ≤ N < 2 0 - 3.12 200
2 ≤ N < 6 3.13 - 9.35 150
6 ≤ N < 13 9.36 - 20.30 100
13 ≤ N < 22 20.31 - 34.37 80
22 ≤ N < 43 34.38 - 67.18 40
43 ≤ N ≤ 64 67.19 - 100 20
Flail.gameDescription: The user flails about aimlessly to attack. The less HP the user has, the greater the move’s power.

Flame Burst.name: Flame Burst
Flame Burst.effects:
Flame Burst deals damage and will also cause splash damage to any Pokémon adjacent to the target (including the user if Flame Burst is targeted at an ally). The splash damage caused to a Pokémon is 1⁄16 of its maximum HP. It is typeless and not counted as regular damage but treated similarly to weather damage, which means that: 
It does not trigger Flash Fire or Color Change.
It does not affect Pokémon with the Magic Guard ability.
It cannot be shielded by moves like Protect, Endure or other protection moves.
It bypasses Wonder Guard, Mold Breaker, Telepathy, Substitute and Destiny Bond.
Flame Burst.gameDescription: The user attacks the target with a bursting flame. The bursting flame damages Pokémon next to the target as well.

Flame Charge.name: Flame Charge
Flame Charge.effects: Flame Charge deals damage and raises the user's Speed by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Flame Charge.gameDescription: Cloaking itself in flame, the user attacks. Then, building up more power, the user raises its Speed stat.

Flame Wheel.name: Flame Wheel
Flame Wheel.effects: Flame Wheel deals damage and has a 10% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned. If the user is frozen, Flame Wheel can be used and will thaw out the Pokemon before attacking.
Flame Wheel.gameDescription: The user cloaks itself in fire and charges at the target. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Flamethrower.name: Flamethrower
Flamethrower.effects: Flamethrower deals damage and has a 10% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Flamethrower.changes: In Generations 1-5, Flamethrower has base power 95.
Flamethrower.gameDescription: The target is scorched with an intense blast of fire. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Flare Blitz.name: Flare Blitz
Flare Blitz.effects: Flare Blitz deals damage and has a 10% chance of burning the target, but the user receives 1⁄3 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 90 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 30 HP. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned. If the user is frozen, Flare Blitz can be used and will thaw out the Pokemon before attacking.
Flare Blitz.gameDescription: The user cloaks itself in fire and charges the target. This also damages the user quite a lot. This attack may leave the target with a burn.

Flash.name: Flash
Flash.effects: Flash lowers the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Flash.gameDescription: The user flashes a bright light that cuts the target’s accuracy.

Flash Cannon.name: Flash Cannon
Flash Cannon.effects: Flash Cannon deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Flash Cannon.gameDescription: The user gathers all its light energy and releases it all at once. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Flatter.name: Flatter
Flatter.effects: Confuses opponent, but raises its Special Attack by two stages.
Flatter.gameDescription: Flattery is used to confuse the target. However, this also raises the target’s Sp. Atk stat.

Fleur Cannon.name: Fleur Cannon
Fleur Cannon.effects: Fleur Cannon deals damage but lowers the user's Special Attack by two stages after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Fleur Cannon.gameDescription: The user unleashes a strong beam. The attack’s recoil harshly lowers the user’s Sp. Atk stat.

Fling.name: Fling
Fling.gameDescription: The user flings its held item at the target to attack. This move’s power and effects depend on the item.

Floral Healing.name: Floral Healing
Floral Healing.effects: The user restores the target’s HP by up to half of its max HP. It restores more HP when the terrain is grass.
Floral Healing.gameDescription: The user restores the target’s HP by up to half of its max HP. It restores more HP when the terrain is grass.

Flower Shield.name: Flower Shield
Flower Shield.effects: Flower Shield raises the Defense of all Grass-type Pokémon in battle (including opponents) by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Flower Shield.gameDescription: The user raises the Defense stat of all Grass-type Pokémon in battle with a mysterious power.

Fly.name: Fly
Fly.effects: The user of Fly will fly up high on the first turn, disappearing from view and becoming invulnerable to most attacks. On the second turn, Fly deals damage. While in the air, the Pokémon can only be hit by the moves Gust, Twister, Thunder, Sky Uppercut and Smack Down, with Gust and Twister dealing twice normal damage. Moves from No Guard Pokémon, or any move following an identify move can also hit for regular power. If the user is holding a Power Herb, Fly executes in one turn.
Fly.changes: In Generations 1-3, Fly has a base power of 70.
Fly.gameDescription: The user soars and then strikes its target on the next turn.
Fly.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Flying Press.name: Flying Press
Flying Press.effects: Flying Press deals damage. It is a Fighting type move, but deals a combination of Fighting and Flying type damage. This in effect gives the move its own type chart, as shown below. NorFirWatEleGraIceFigPoiGroFlyPsyBugRocGhoDraDarSteFai2½222½½½02½ Although Flying Press deals dual type damage, it is still a pure Fighting type move so only gains STAB from Fighting type Pokémon.
Flying Press.changes: In Generation 6, Flying Press has base power 80.
Flying Press.gameDescription: The user dives down onto the target from the sky. This move is Fighting and Flying type simultaneously.

Focus Blast.name: Focus Blast
Focus Blast.effects: Focus Blast deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Focus Blast.gameDescription: The user heightens its mental focus and unleashes its power. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Focus Energy.name: Focus Energy
Focus Energy.gameDescription: The user takes a deep breath and focuses so that critical hits land more easily.

Focus Punch.name: Focus Punch
Focus Punch.effects: The user of Focus Punch will tighten its focus before any other moves are made. If any regular move (with a higher priority than -3) directly hits the focused Pokemon, it loses its focus and flinches, not carrying out the attack. If no direct hits are made, Focus Punch attacks as normal. Moves of lower priority than Focus Punch - for example Avalanche or Dragon Tail - will not cause the user to lose focus. The user will tighten their focus, Focus Punch will attack, then the opponent will use their lower priority move (and in the case of Avalanche, hit with double power).
Focus Punch.gameDescription: The user focuses its mind before launching a punch. This move fails if the user is hit before it is used.

Follow Me.name: Follow Me
Follow Me.effects: In Double Battle, the user takes all the attacks.
Follow Me.gameDescription: The user draws attention to itself, making all targets take aim only at the user.

Force Palm.name: Force Palm
Force Palm.effects: Force Palm deals damage and has a 30% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Force Palm.gameDescription: The target is attacked with a shock wave. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Foresight.name: Foresight
Foresight.effects: Resets opponent's Evasiveness, Normal-type and Fighting-type attacks can now hit Ghosts, and Ghost-type attacks hit Normal.
Foresight.gameDescription: Enables a Ghost-type target to be hit by Normal- and Fighting-type attacks. This also enables an evasive target to be hit.

Forest's Curse.name: Forest's Curse
Forest's Curse.effects: Forest's Curse adds the Grass type to the target. If the target is dual-typed they essentially become a triple-typed Pokémon. It fails if one of the Pokémon's types is already Grass. If the target is under the effect of Trick-or-Treat the Ghost type is replaced by Grass.
Forest's Curse.gameDescription: The user puts a forest curse on the target. The target is now Grass type as well.

Foul Play.name: Foul Play
Foul Play.effects: Foul Play uses the opponent's Attack stat instead of the user's in damage calculation. In other words, the move acts as if the target is attacking themselves, and thus is more powerful when the opponent has higher Attack.
Foul Play.gameDescription: The user turns the target’s power against it. The higher the target’s Attack stat, the greater the move’s power.

Freeze Shock.name: Freeze Shock
Freeze Shock.effects: The user of Freeze Shock will charge on the first turn. On the second turn, it deals damage and has a 30% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed. If the user is holding a Power Herb, Freeze Shock executes in one turn.
Freeze Shock.gameDescription: On the second turn, the user hits the target with electrically charged ice. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Freeze-Dry.name: Freeze-Dry
Freeze-Dry.effects: Freeze-Dry deals damage and has a 10% change of freezing the target. In addition to Ice's usual type advantages, Freeze-Dry is also super-effective against the Water type. This in effect gives the move its own (slightly different) type chart, as shown below: NorFirWatEleGraIceFigPoiGroFlyPsyBugRocGhoDraDarSteFai½22½222½
Freeze-Dry.gameDescription: The user rapidly cools the target. This may also leave the target frozen. This move is super effective on Water types.

Frenzy Plant.name: Frenzy Plant
Frenzy Plant.gameDescription: The user slams the target with an enormous tree. The user can’t move on the next turn.

Frost Breath.name: Frost Breath
Frost Breath.effects: Frost Breath deals damage and always results in a critical hit, increasing its power to 90. However, Pokemon with the abilities Battle Armor or Shell Armor, or those under the effect of Lucky Chant are immune to critical hits so Frost Breath will hit them with base power 60.
Frost Breath.changes: In Generation 5, Frost Breath has base power 40. Critical hits also increase power by 2× rather than 1.5× so the effective power is 80 with the critical hit.
Frost Breath.gameDescription: The user blows its cold breath on the target. This attack always results in a critical hit.

Frustration.name: Frustration
Frustration.effects: The power of Frustration is higher when the Pokémon likes its trainer less. The base power varies between 1 (maximum happiness) and 102 (minimum happiness). It is the counterpart move to Return.
Frustration.gameDescription: This full-power attack grows more powerful the less the user likes its Trainer.

Fury Attack.name: Fury Attack
Fury Attack.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 30
3 3⁄8 45
4 1⁄8 60
5 1⁄8 75

 Fury Attack hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Fury Attack is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Fury Attack to always hit the maximum number of times.
Fury Attack.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Fury Attack ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
Fury Attack.gameDescription: The target is jabbed repeatedly with a horn or beak two to five times in a row.

Fury Cutter.name: Fury Cutter
Fury Cutter.effects: Fury Cutter deals damage starting at base power 40, and for each successful consecutive hit doubles in power, up to a maximum base power of 160. If the move misses for any reason, the base power resets to 40.
Fury Cutter.changes: Its initial base power is 10 in Generations 1-4 and 20 in Generation 5, but otherwise works in the same way, up to the same maximum of 160.
Fury Cutter.gameDescription: The target is slashed with scythes or claws. This attack becomes more powerful if it hits in succession.

Fury Swipes.name: Fury Swipes
Fury Swipes.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 36
3 3⁄8 54
4 1⁄8 72
5 1⁄8 90

 Fury Swipes hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Fury Swipes is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Fury Swipes to always hit the maximum number of times.
Fury Swipes.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Fury Swipes ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
Fury Swipes.gameDescription: The target is raked with sharp claws or scythes quickly two to five times in a row.

Fusion Bolt.name: Fusion Bolt
Fusion Bolt.effects: Fusion Bolt deals damage, and its power doubles to 200 if Fusion Flare has been used before it in the same turn. If this happens Fusion Bolt's animation will change to look more epic.
Fusion Bolt.gameDescription: The user throws down a giant lightning bolt. This move’s power is increased when influenced by an enormous flame.

Fusion Flare.name: Fusion Flare
Fusion Flare.effects: Fusion Flare deals damage, and its power doubles to 200 if Fusion Bolt has been used before it in the same turn. If this happens Fusion Flare's animation will change to look more epic. If the user is frozen, Fusion Flare can be used and will thaw out the Pokemon before attacking.
Fusion Flare.gameDescription: The user brings down a giant flame. This move’s power is increased when influenced by an enormous lightning bolt.

Future Sight.name: Future Sight
Future Sight.effects: Future Sight deals damage, but does not hit until two turns after the move is used. If the opponent switched Pokémon in the meantime, the new Pokémon gets hit, with their type and stats taken into account. Future Sight cannot be stopped by Protect, Detect, Endure or the Wonder Guard ability.
Future Sight.changes: In Generation 5, Future Sight has base power 100. In Generations 2-4, Future Sight works a little differently. Its base power is 80, its accuracy 90% and it has 15 PP. The damage it deals is typeless, which means it could hit Dark-type Pokémon. It also uses the Special Defense stat of the originally targeted Pokémon, even if said Pokémon switched out in the meantime.
Future Sight.gameDescription: Two turns after this move is used, a hunk of psychic energy attacks the target.

Gastro Acid.name: Gastro Acid
Gastro Acid.effects: Cancels out the effect of the opponent's Ability.
Gastro Acid.gameDescription: The user hurls up its stomach acids on the target. The fluid eliminates the effect of the target’s Ability.

Gear Grind.name: Gear Grind
Gear Grind.effects:
Gear Grind deals damage and will strike twice (with 50 base power each time).
Each strike of Gear Grind is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
Gear Grind.gameDescription: The user attacks by throwing steel gears at its target twice.

Gear Up.name: Gear Up
Gear Up.effects: The user engages its gears to raise the Attack and Sp. Atk stats of ally Pokémon with the Plus or Minus Ability.
Gear Up.gameDescription: The user engages its gears to raise the Attack and Sp. Atk stats of ally Pokémon with the Plus or Minus Ability.
Gear Up.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Genesis Supernova.name: Genesis Supernova
Genesis Supernova.effects: Genesis Supernova is a Psychic type Z-move exclusive to Mew. It is used with the move Psychic.
Genesis Supernova.gameDescription: After obtaining Z-Power, the user, Mew, attacks the target with full force. The terrain will be charged with psychic energy.

Geomancy.name: Geomancy
Geomancy.effects: Geomancy charges on the first turn. On the second turn it raises the user's Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed by two stages each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each. Geomancy is the signature move of Xerneas. In battle, rainbow-colored light erupts from the ground around the user.
Geomancy.gameDescription: The user absorbs energy and sharply raises its Sp. Atk, Sp. Def, and Speed stats on the next turn.

Giga Drain.name: Giga Drain
Giga Drain.effects: Giga Drain deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained. If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokemon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
Giga Drain.changes: In Generations 1-4, Giga Drain has a base power of 60. In Generations 1-3, Giga Drain has only 5 PP.
Giga Drain.gameDescription: A nutrient-draining attack. The user’s HP is restored by half the damage taken by the target.

Giga Impact.name: Giga Impact
Giga Impact.effects: Giga Impact deals damage, but the user must recharge on the next turn (bringing its effective power down to 75 per turn). If the user has the ability Truant, it will recharge in the same turn that it loafs around. Giga Impact is the Physical counterpart to Hyper Beam.
Giga Impact.gameDescription: The user charges at the target using every bit of its power. The user can’t move on the next turn.

Gigavolt Havoc.name: Gigavolt Havoc
Gigavolt Havoc.effects: Gigavolt Havoc is the Electric type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Gigavolt Havoc.gameDescription: The user hits the target with a powerful electric current collected by its Z-Power. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Glaciate.name: Glaciate
Glaciate.effects: Glaciate deals damage and lowers the target's Speed by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Glaciate.gameDescription: The user attacks by blowing freezing cold air at opposing Pokémon. This lowers their Speed stat.

Glare.name: Glare
Glare.effects: Glare paralyzes the target, if it hits. Paralyzed Pokémon have a 25% chance of not being able to attack, and their Speed is decreased by 75%. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Glare.changes: In Generation 5, Glare has 90% accuracy. In Generations 1-4, Glare has 75% accuracy.
Glare.gameDescription: The user intimidates the target with the pattern on its belly to cause paralysis.

Grass Knot.name: Grass Knot
Grass Knot.effects:
Weight (kg) Power


0.1 - 9.9 20
10.0 - 24.9 40
25.0 - 49.9 60
50.0 - 99.9 80
100.0 - 199.9 100
200.0+ 120

 Grass Knot inflicts greater damage on heavier opponents, as per the table to the right.
Grass Knot.gameDescription: The user snares the target with grass and trips it. The heavier the target, the greater the move’s power.

Grass Pledge.name: Grass Pledge
Grass Pledge.effects: Grass Pledge deals damage at base power 80. If a teammate uses Fire Pledge or Water Pledge in the same turn, the moves combine into one attack of base power 160 and added effects appear. The faster Pokemon moves first but waits for the other Pokemon to make their move. When the slower Pledge user moves, the combo attack hits the Pokemon the slower user was targeting. If Grass Pledge is used with Fire Pledge, the move animation shows Fire Pledge and a sea of fire envelops the foe's team is created that damages opponents 1⁄8 of their maximum HP each turn, for 4 turns. If Grass Pledge is used with Water Pledge, the move animation shows Grass Pledge and a swamp envelops the foe's team that halves the opponents' speed for 4 turns.
Grass Pledge.changes: In Generation 5, Grass Pledge has base power 50.
Grass Pledge.gameDescription: A column of grass hits the target. When used with its water equivalent, its power increases and a vast swamp appears.

Grass Whistle.name: Grass Whistle
Grass Whistle.effects: Grass Whistle puts the target to sleep, if it hits. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns. Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
Grass Whistle.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as GrassWhistle.
Grass Whistle.gameDescription: The user plays a pleasant melody that lulls the target into a deep sleep.

Grassy Terrain.name: Grassy Terrain
Grassy Terrain.effects: Grassy Terrain creates a low-lying grassy field for 5 turns, that restores the HP of grounded Pokémon each turn, by 1⁄16 of their maximum HP. The power of Grass type moves also increases by 50% while in effect, and the moves Earthquake, Magnitude, and Bulldoze halve in power. Grounded Pokémon are simply those that are not raised. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary. Grassy Terrain is a terrain condition and can coexist at the same time as weather conditions, but not other terrain conditions. The move Nature Power turns into Energy Ball under Grassy Terrain.
Grassy Terrain.gameDescription: The user turns the ground to grass for five turns. This restores the HP of Pokémon on the ground a little every turn and powers up Grass type-moves.

Gravity.name: Gravity
Gravity.effects: Prevents moves like Fly and Bounce and the Ability Levitate for 5 turns.
Gravity.gameDescription: Enables Flying-type Pokémon or Pokémon with the Levitate Ability to be hit by Ground-type moves. Flying moves can’t be used.

Growl.name: Growl
Growl.effects: Growl lowers the target's Attack by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Growl.gameDescription: The user growls in an endearing way, making opposing Pokémon less wary. This lowers their Attack stat.

Growth.name: Growth
Growth.effects: Growth raises the user's Attack and Special Attack by one stage each. During strong sunlight it raises each stat by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Growth.changes: In Generations 1-4, Growth only increases Special Attack. In Generation 1 it increases the Special stat, which encompassed Special Attack and Special Defense.
Growth.gameDescription: The user’s body grows all at once, raising the Attack and Sp. Atk stats.

Grudge.name: Grudge
Grudge.effects: If the users faints after using this move, the PP for the opponent's last move is depleted.
Grudge.gameDescription: If the user faints, the user’s grudge fully depletes the PP of the opponent’s move that knocked it out.

Guard Split.name: Guard Split
Guard Split.effects: Guard Split averages the user's Defense and Special Defense with those of the target. Stat boosts are not taken into account. For example, if the user's Defense was 100, the opponent's was 200, and the opponent had used Screech on the user, then both Pokemon would end up with 150 Defense. Due to the stat drop, the Guard Split user's effective Defense would now be 75 (instead of the 50 it was originally).
Guard Split.gameDescription: The user employs its psychic power to average its Defense and Sp. Def stats with those of the target.

Guard Swap.name: Guard Swap
Guard Swap.effects: User and opponent swap Defense and Special Defense.
Guard Swap.gameDescription: The user employs its psychic power to switch changes to its Defense and Sp. Def stats with the target.

Guardian of Alola.name: Guardian of Alola
Guardian of Alola.effects: Guardian of Alola is a Z-move exclusive to the guardian deities of Alola - Tapu Koko, Tapu Lele, Tapu Bulu and Tapu Fini. It is used with Nature's Madness. Guardian of Alola cuts the target's HP by 75% of its remaining HP.
Guardian of Alola.gameDescription: The user, the Land Spirit Pokémon, obtains Alola’s energy using its Z-Power and attacks the target with full force. This reduces the target’s HP greatly.

Guillotine.name: Guillotine
Guillotine.effects:
If it hits, Guillotine is guaranteed to make the opponent faint. It is more likely to hit Pokémon that are of a lower level than the user. Its accuracy (as a percentage) is calculated as below, ignoring all other accuracy and evasion modifiers: UserLevel - TargetLevel + 30
 This means that Guillotine will fail against a target Pokémon at least 30 levels above the user.
Guillotine.changes: In Generation 1, Guillotine has 30% accuracy, but does not affect opponents faster than the user.
Guillotine.gameDescription: A vicious, tearing attack with big pincers. The target faints instantly if this attack hits.

Gunk Shot.name: Gunk Shot
Gunk Shot.effects: Gunk Shot deals damage and has a 30% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Gunk Shot.changes: In Generations 4-5, Gunk Shot has 70% accuracy.
Gunk Shot.gameDescription: The user shoots filthy garbage at the target to attack. This may also poison the target.

Gust.name: Gust
Gust.effects: Gust deals damage with no additional effect. However, it can hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stages of Bounce, Fly and Sky Drop - and in the case of Bounce and Fly, inflicts double damage.
Gust.changes: In Generation 1, Gust is a Normal-type move.
Gust.gameDescription: A gust of wind is whipped up by wings and launched at the target to inflict damage.
Gust.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Gyro Ball.name: Gyro Ball
Gyro Ball.effects:
Gyro Ball inflicts varying damage: the slower the user compared to the opponent, the higher the damage, up to a maximum base power of 150. The base power is calculated as: 25 × TargetSpeed ÷ UserSpeed
 For example, if the opponent is twice as fast as the user, Gyro Ball will have base power 50.
Gyro Ball.gameDescription: The user tackles the target with a high-speed spin. The slower the user compared to the target, the greater the move’s power.

Hail.name: Hail
Hail.effects:
Hail creates a hailstorm that lasts for 5 turns and induces these additional effects: 
All Pokémon except Ice types and those with the Ice Body or Snow Cloak abilities lose 1⁄16 of their max HP at the end of each turn.
Pokémon with the Ice Body ability recover 1⁄16 of their max HP each turn.
Pokémon with the Snow Cloak ability increase their evasion by 20%.
From Generation 4, Blizzard has 100% accuracy.
In Diamond/Pearl only, Blizzard has a 25% chance to break through Protect and Detect.
The move Weather Ball changes to Ice type and doubles in power.
The power of SolarBeam decreases by 50%.
The moves Synthesis, Morning Sun and Moonlight recover 1⁄4 of the user's max HP (instead of the usual 1⁄2 HP).
Castform changes to its Hail form.
Hail.gameDescription: The user summons a hailstorm lasting five turns. It damages all Pokémon except the Ice type.

Hammer Arm.name: Hammer Arm
Hammer Arm.effects: Hammer Arm deals damage but lowers the user's Speed by one stage after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Hammer Arm.gameDescription: The user swings and hits with its strong, heavy fist. It lowers the user’s Speed, however.

Happy Hour.name: Happy Hour
Happy Hour.effects: Happy Hour has no battle effect. Instead, it doubles the prize money awarded to the player at the end of the battle. If the Amulet Coin or Luck Incense is held by any Pokémon in battle, and any Pokémon uses Happy Hour during the battle, the prize money is quadrupled. Happy Hour is an event-exclusive move known by Inkay from a Japanese event.
Happy Hour.gameDescription: Using Happy Hour doubles the amount of prize money received after battle.

Harden.name: Harden
Harden.effects: Harden raises the user's Defense by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Harden.gameDescription: The user stiffens all the muscles in its body to raise its Defense stat.

Haze.name: Haze
Haze.gameDescription: The user creates a haze that eliminates every stat change among all the Pokémon engaged in battle.

Head Charge.name: Head Charge
Head Charge.effects: Head Charge deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄4 of the damage it inflicts in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 100 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 25 HP.
Head Charge.gameDescription: The user charges its head into its target, using its powerful guard hair. This also damages the user a little.

Head Smash.name: Head Smash
Head Smash.effects: Head Smash deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄2 of the damage it inflicts in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 100 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 50 HP.
Head Smash.gameDescription: The user attacks the target with a hazardous, full-power headbutt. This also damages the user terribly.

Headbutt.name: Headbutt
Headbutt.effects: Headbutt deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Headbutt.gameDescription: The user sticks out its head and attacks by charging straight into the target. This may also make the target flinch.

Heal Bell.name: Heal Bell
Heal Bell.effects: Heals the user's party's status conditions.
Heal Bell.gameDescription: The user makes a soothing bell chime to heal the status conditions of all the party Pokémon.
Heal Bell.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Heal Block.name: Heal Block
Heal Block.effects: Prevents the opponent from restoring HP for 5 turns.
Heal Block.gameDescription: For five turns, the user prevents the opposing team from using any moves, Abilities, or held items that recover HP.
Heal Block.target: Targets all Pokemon on the opposing field.

Heal Order.name: Heal Order
Heal Order.effects: Heal Order recovers up to 50% of the user's maximum HP.
Heal Order.gameDescription: The user calls out its underlings to heal it. The user regains up to half of its max HP.

Heal Pulse.name: Heal Pulse
Heal Pulse.effects: Heal Pulse restores half of the target's maximum HP. It can be used on team-mates but not on itself.
Heal Pulse.gameDescription: The user emits a healing pulse that restores the target’s HP by up to half of its max HP.
Heal Pulse.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Healing Wish.name: Healing Wish
Healing Wish.effects: The user faints and the next Pokémon released is fully healed.
Healing Wish.gameDescription: The user faints. In return, the Pokémon taking its place will have its HP restored and status conditions cured.

Heart Stamp.name: Heart Stamp
Heart Stamp.effects: Heart Stamp deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Heart Stamp.gameDescription: The user unleashes a vicious blow after its cute act makes the target less wary. This may also make the target flinch.

Heart Swap.name: Heart Swap
Heart Swap.effects: Stat changes are swapped with the opponent.
Heart Swap.gameDescription: The user employs its psychic power to switch stat changes with the target.

Heat Crash.name: Heat Crash
Heat Crash.effects:
Ratio (r) Power


5 ≤ r 120
4 ≤ r < 5 100
3 ≤ r < 4 80
2 ≤ r < 3 60
r < 2 40

 Heat Crash inflicts more damage the heavier the user compared to the opponent. The table to the right shows the different base powers for each ratio, where r = UserWeight ÷ TargetWeight For example, if the user's weight is at least 4 times more than the target but less than 5 times, Heat Crash hits with 100 base power.
Heat Crash.gameDescription: The user slams its target with its flame-covered body. The more the user outweighs the target, the greater the move’s power.

Heat Wave.name: Heat Wave
Heat Wave.effects: Heat Wave deals damage and has a 10% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Heat Wave.changes: In Generations 3-5, Heat Wave has base power 100.
Heat Wave.gameDescription: The user attacks by exhaling hot breath on the opposing Pokémon. This may also leave those Pokémon with a burn.

Heavy Slam.name: Heavy Slam
Heavy Slam.effects:
Ratio (r) Power


5 ≤ r 120
4 ≤ r < 5 100
3 ≤ r < 4 80
2 ≤ r < 3 60
r < 2 40

 Heavy Slam inflicts more damage the heavier the user compared to the opponent. The table to the right shows the different base powers for each ratio, where r = UserWeight ÷ TargetWeight For example, if the user's weight is at least 4 times more than the target but less than 5 times, Heavy Slam hits with 100 base power.
Heavy Slam.gameDescription: The user slams into the target with its heavy body. The more the user outweighs the target, the greater the move’s power.

Helping Hand.name: Helping Hand
Helping Hand.effects: In Double Battles, boosts the power of the partner's move.
Helping Hand.gameDescription: The user assists an ally by boosting the power of that ally’s attack.
Helping Hand.target: Targets an adjacent Pokemon on the user’s team.

Hex.name: Hex
Hex.effects: Hex inflicts damage, but if the target has a major status ailment (i.e. is burned, poisoned, paralyzed, asleep or frozen) it will double in power to 130.
Hex.changes: In Generation 5, Hex has base power 50.
Hex.gameDescription: This relentless attack does massive damage to a target affected by status conditions.

Hidden Power.name: Hidden Power
Hidden Power.effects:
Hidden Power deals damage, however its type varies for every Pokémon, depending on that Pokémon's Individual Values (IVs). This makes it a useful move for coverage - giving the Pokémon a type of move they don't normally have. Hidden Power can be any type except Normal or Fairy. It receives STAB if the user's type matches the type given to Hidden Power. Individual Values are 6 hidden numbers (one for each stat) that are randomly generated upon encountering a Pokémon. It is not possible to find your exact IVs in-game. You can find the type of Hidden Power in-game by talking to a particular character who will state the type a Pokémon's Hidden Power would be if it learned the move. They are located at: 
Veilstone Game Corner Prize Exchange in Platinum
Celadon Game Corner Prize Exchange in HeartGold/SoulSilver
Mistralton City Pokécenter in Black/White
Pokémon World Tournament in Black 2/White 2
Anistar City, south-easternmost house in X/Y.
 It is also possible via elimination by using the move against different Pokémon, or against Kecleon, whose ability Color Change will tell you the type.
Hidden Power.changes: In Generations 2-5, the base power of Hidden Power ranges from 30-70, depending on the user's IVs. The move will be boosted by the ability Technician only if its power for that Pokémon is 60 or below.
Hidden Power.gameDescription: A unique attack that varies in type depending on the Pokémon using it.

High Horsepower.name: High Horsepower
High Horsepower.effects: The user fiercely attacks the target using its entire body.
High Horsepower.gameDescription: The user fiercely attacks the target using its entire body.

High Jump Kick.name: High Jump Kick
High Jump Kick.effects: High Jump Kick deals damage, however, if it misses the user keeps going and crashes, losing 1⁄2 of its maximum HP. High Jump Kick cannot be used if Gravity is in effect.
High Jump Kick.changes: In Generations 1-3 High Jump Kick has a base power of 85. In Generation 4 its base power is 100. In Generation 1, the crash damage is always 1 HP. From Generation 2 to Generation 4, the crash damage is 1⁄2 of the damage the attack would have inflicted (which could be all of the user's own HP). In Generations 1-4, High Jump Kick has 20 PP. In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as Hi Jump Kick.
High Jump Kick.gameDescription: The target is attacked with a knee kick from a jump. If it misses, the user is hurt instead.

Hold Back.name: Hold Back
Hold Back.effects: Always leaves opponent with at least 1 HP.
Hold Back.gameDescription: The user holds back when it attacks, and the target is left with at least 1 HP.

Hold Hands.name: Hold Hands
Hold Hands.effects: Makes the user and an ally very happy.
Hold Hands.gameDescription: The user and an ally hold hands. This makes them very happy.
Hold Hands.target: Targets an adjacent Pokemon on the user’s team.

Hone Claws.name: Hone Claws
Hone Claws.effects: Hone Claws raises the user's Attack and Accuracy by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Hone Claws.gameDescription: The user sharpens its claws to boost its Attack stat and accuracy.

Horn Attack.name: Horn Attack
Horn Attack.effects: Horn Attack deals damage with no additional effect.
Horn Attack.gameDescription: The target is jabbed with a sharply pointed horn to inflict damage.

Horn Drill.name: Horn Drill
Horn Drill.effects:
If it hits, Horn Drill is guaranteed to make the opponent faint. It is more likely to hit Pokémon that are of a lower level than the user. Its accuracy (as a percentage) is calculated as below, ignoring all other accuracy and evasion modifiers: UserLevel - TargetLevel + 30
 This means that Horn Drill will fail against a target Pokémon at least 30 levels above the user.
Horn Drill.changes: In Generation 1, Horn Drill has 30% accuracy, but does not affect opponents faster than the user.
Horn Drill.gameDescription: The user stabs the target with a horn that rotates like a drill. The target faints instantly if this attack hits.

Horn Leech.name: Horn Leech
Horn Leech.effects: Horn Leech deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained. If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokemon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
Horn Leech.gameDescription: The user drains the target’s energy with its horns. The user’s HP is restored by half the damage taken by the target.

Howl.name: Howl
Howl.effects: Howl raises the user's Attack by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Howl.gameDescription: The user howls loudly to raise its spirit, which raises its Attack stat.

Hurricane.name: Hurricane
Hurricane.effects: Hurricane deals damage and has a 30% chance of confusing the target. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused. If used during rain, its accuracy rises to 100%. Conversely, if used during intense sunlight, its accuracy drops to 50%. Hurricane can hit Pokemon in the invulnerable stage of Fly and Bounce.
Hurricane.changes: In Generation 5, Hurricane has base power 120.
Hurricane.gameDescription: The user attacks by wrapping its opponent in a fierce wind that flies up into the sky. This may also confuse the target.
Hurricane.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Hydro Cannon.name: Hydro Cannon
Hydro Cannon.gameDescription: The target is hit with a watery blast. The user can’t move on the next turn.

Hydro Pump.name: Hydro Pump
Hydro Pump.effects: Hydro Pump deals damage with no additional effect.
Hydro Pump.changes: In Generations 1-5, Hydro Pump has base power 120.
Hydro Pump.gameDescription: The target is blasted by a huge volume of water launched under great pressure.

Hydro Vortex.name: Hydro Vortex
Hydro Vortex.effects: Hydro Vortex is the Water type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Hydro Vortex.gameDescription: The user creates a huge whirling current using its Z-Power to swallow the target with full force. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Hyper Beam.name: Hyper Beam
Hyper Beam.effects: Hyper Beam deals damage, but the user must recharge on the next turn (bringing its effective power down to 75 per turn). If the user has the ability Truant, it will recharge in the same turn that it loafs around. Hyper Beam is the Special counterpart to Giga Impact.
Hyper Beam.changes: In Generation 1, if Hyper Beam KOs a Pokemon, it does not need to recharge.
Hyper Beam.gameDescription: The target is attacked with a powerful beam. The user can’t move on the next turn.

Hyper Fang.name: Hyper Fang
Hyper Fang.effects: Hyper Fang deals damage and has a 10% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Hyper Fang.gameDescription: The user bites hard on the target with its sharp front fangs. This may also make the target flinch.

Hyper Voice.name: Hyper Voice
Hyper Voice.effects:
Hyper Voice deals damage with no additional effect, besides targeting multiple foes.
Hyper Voice has no effect on Pokemon with the ability Soundproof.
Hyper Voice.gameDescription: The user lets loose a horribly echoing shout with the power to inflict damage.

Hyperspace Fury.name: Hyperspace Fury
Hyperspace Fury.effects: Hyperspace Fury deals damage but lowers the user's Defense by one stage after attacking. The move always hits, even if the target used a Protect-like move. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Hyperspace Fury is the signature move of Hoopa Unbound.
Hyperspace Fury.gameDescription: Using its many arms, the user unleashes a barrage of attacks that ignore the effects of moves like Protect and Detect. But the user’s Defense stat falls.

Hyperspace Hole.name: Hyperspace Hole
Hyperspace Hole.effects: Hyperspace Hole deals damage and always hits, even if the target used a Protect-like move. It is the signature move of Hoopa.
Hyperspace Hole.gameDescription: Using a hyperspace hole, the user appears right next to the target and strikes. This also hits a target using a move such as Protect or Detect.

Hypnosis.name: Hypnosis
Hypnosis.effects: Hypnosis puts the target to sleep, if it hits. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns. Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
Hypnosis.changes: In Diamond/Pearl, Hypnosis' accuracy was raised to 70%. In all other games (including from Platinum onwards) it is 60%.
Hypnosis.gameDescription: The user employs hypnotic suggestion to make the target fall into a deep sleep.

Ice Ball.name: Ice Ball
Ice Ball.effects: Ice Ball deals damage for 5 turns, doubling in power each turn. The move stops if it misses on any turn. If it doesn't miss, Ice Ball will deal 30, 60, 120, 240 and 480 base power damage each turn respectively. If the user has used Defense Curl in any previous turn (without switching out) then Ice Ball doubles in power, i.e. it will deal 60, 120, 240, 480 and 960 base power damage respectively. As Ice Ball has 90% accuracy, the chances of it being successful for each turn (with normal Accuracy/Evasion and no other interruptions) are 90%, 81%, 73%, 66% and 59% respectively. In other words, roughly 3 out of every 5 times Ice Ball is used, it will hit for the full 5 turns.
Ice Ball.gameDescription: The user attacks the target for five turns. The move’s power increases each time it hits.

Ice Beam.name: Ice Beam
Ice Beam.effects: Ice Beam deals damage and has a 10% chance of freezing the target. Ice type Pokémon, those with the ability Magma Armor or those behind a Substitute cannot be frozen.
Ice Beam.changes: In Generations 1-5, Ice Beam has base power 95.
Ice Beam.gameDescription: The target is struck with an icy-cold beam of energy. This may also leave the target frozen.

Ice Burn.name: Ice Burn
Ice Burn.effects: The user of Ice Burn will charge on the first turn. On the second turn, it deals damage and has a 30% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned. If the user is holding a Power Herb, Ice Burn executes in one turn.
Ice Burn.gameDescription: On the second turn, an ultracold, freezing wind surrounds the target. This may leave the target with a burn.

Ice Fang.name: Ice Fang
Ice Fang.effects: Ice Fang deals damage, has a 10% chance of freezing the target and has a 10% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Ice type Pokémon, those with the ability Magma Armor or those behind a Substitute cannot be frozen. Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Ice Fang.gameDescription: The user bites with cold-infused fangs. This may also make the target flinch or leave it frozen.

Ice Hammer.name: Ice Hammer
Ice Hammer.effects: The user swings and hits with its strong, heavy fist. It lowers the user’s Speed, however.
Ice Hammer.gameDescription: The user swings and hits with its strong, heavy fist. It lowers the user’s Speed, however.

Ice Punch.name: Ice Punch
Ice Punch.effects: Ice Punch deals damage and has a 10% chance of freezing the target. Ice type Pokémon, those with the ability Magma Armor or those behind a Substitute cannot be frozen.
Ice Punch.gameDescription: The target is punched with an icy fist. This may also leave the target frozen.

Ice Shard.name: Ice Shard
Ice Shard.effects: Ice Shard deals damage and has a priority of +1. Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
Ice Shard.gameDescription: The user flash-freezes chunks of ice and hurls them at the target. This move always goes first.

Icicle Crash.name: Icicle Crash
Icicle Crash.effects: Icicle Crash deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Icicle Crash.gameDescription: The user attacks by harshly dropping large icicles onto the target. This may also make the target flinch.

Icicle Spear.name: Icicle Spear
Icicle Spear.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 50
3 3⁄8 75
4 1⁄8 100
5 1⁄8 125

 Icicle Spear hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Icicle Spear is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Icicle Spear to always hit the maximum number of times.
Icicle Spear.changes: In Generations 3-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generation 3, Icicle Spear ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generations 3-4, Icicle Spear has a base power of 10.
Icicle Spear.gameDescription: The user launches sharp icicles at the target two to five times in a row.

Icy Wind.name: Icy Wind
Icy Wind.effects: Icy Wind deals damage and lowers the target's Speed by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Icy Wind.gameDescription: The user attacks with a gust of chilled air. This also lowers the opposing Pokémon’s Speed stats.

Imprison.name: Imprison
Imprison.effects: Opponent is unable to use moves that the user also knows.
Imprison.gameDescription: If opposing Pokémon know any move also known by the user, they are prevented from using it.
Imprison.target: Targets all Pokemon on the opposing field.

Incinerate.name: Incinerate
Incinerate.effects: Incinerate deals damage and if the target is holding a Berry, it is burnt and becomes no longer usable. If Incinerate would be super-effective and the target is holding an Occa Berry, the Berry activates before the move hits so does not get burnt.
Incinerate.changes: In Generation 5, Incinerate has base power 30.
Incinerate.gameDescription: The user attacks opposing Pokémon with fire. If a Pokémon is holding a certain item, such as a Berry, the item becomes burned up and unusable.

Inferno.name: Inferno
Inferno.effects: Inferno deals damage and burns the target, if it hits. Burned Pokémon lose 1⁄8 of their maximum HP each turn and their Attack is decreased by 50%. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Inferno.gameDescription: The user attacks by engulfing the target in an intense fire. This leaves the target with a burn.

Inferno Overdrive.name: Inferno Overdrive
Inferno Overdrive.effects: Inferno Overdrive is the Fire type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Inferno Overdrive.gameDescription: The user breathes a stream of intense fire toward the target with the full force of its Z-Power. The power varies depending on the original move.

Infestation.name: Infestation
Infestation.effects: Infestation inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the opponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
Infestation.gameDescription: The target is infested and attacked for four to five turns. The target can’t flee during this time.

Ingrain.name: Ingrain
Ingrain.effects: The user of Ingrain plants it roots, which restores 1⁄16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn, but prevents switching out. Only the moves Baton Pass, U Turn or Volt Switch will allow the user to switch out, with Baton Pass transferring the effects of Ingrain. Moves such as Roar used on this Pokemon will have no effect. Ingrain cancels effects given to raised Pokemon such as immunity to Ground-type moves, Spikes and so on. See more in the glossary. If the user is holding a Big Root, Ingrain restores 30% more HP each turn - approximately 1⁄12 of its maximum.
Ingrain.gameDescription: The user lays roots that restore its HP on every turn. Because it’s rooted, it can’t switch out.

Instruct.name: Instruct
Instruct.effects: Instruct tells the user's teammate in a double/triple battle to use its most recent move instead of them. In other words, it allows a teammate to attack twice instead of the two Pokémon attacking once each.
Instruct.gameDescription: The user instructs the target to use the target’s last move again.

Ion Deluge.name: Ion Deluge
Ion Deluge.effects: Ion Deluge changes Normal-type moves to Electric-type.
Ion Deluge.gameDescription: The user disperses electrically charged particles, which changes Normal-type moves to Electric-type moves.

Iron Defense.name: Iron Defense
Iron Defense.effects: Iron Defense raises the user's Defense by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Iron Defense.gameDescription: The user hardens its body’s surface like iron, sharply raising its Defense stat.

Iron Head.name: Iron Head
Iron Head.effects: Iron Head deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Iron Head.gameDescription: The user slams the target with its steel-hard head. This may also make the target flinch.

Iron Tail.name: Iron Tail
Iron Tail.effects: Iron Tail deals damage and has a 30% chance of lowering the target's Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Iron Tail.gameDescription: The target is slammed with a steel-hard tail. This may also lower the target’s Defense stat.

Judgment.name: Judgment
Judgment.effects: Type depends on the Arceus Plate being held.
Judgment.gameDescription: The user releases countless shots of light at the target. This move’s type varies depending on the kind of Plate the user is holding.

Jump Kick.name: Jump Kick
Jump Kick.effects: Jump Kick deals damage, however, if it misses the user keeps going and crashes, losing 1⁄2 of its maximum HP. Jump Kick cannot be used if Gravity is in effect.
Jump Kick.changes: In Generations 1-3 Jump Kick has a base power of 70. In Generation 4 its base power is 85. In Generation 1, the crash damage is always 1 HP. From Generation 2 to Generation 4, the crash damage is 1⁄8 of the damage the attack would have inflicted (which could be all of the user's own HP). In Generations 1-4, Jump Kick has 25 PP.
Jump Kick.gameDescription: The user jumps up high, then strikes with a kick. If the kick misses, the user hurts itself.

Karate Chop.name: Karate Chop
Karate Chop.effects: Karate Chop deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Karate Chop.changes: In Generation 1, Karate Chop is a Normal-type move.
Karate Chop.gameDescription: The target is attacked with a sharp chop. Critical hits land more easily.

Kinesis.name: Kinesis
Kinesis.effects: Kinesis lowers the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Kinesis.gameDescription: The user distracts the target by bending a spoon. This lowers the target’s accuracy.

King's Shield.name: King's Shield
King's Shield.effects: King's Shield prevents any attacks targeted at the user from striking on that turn. In addition, if an opponent targeted a contact move at the user of King's Shield, the opponent's Attack is lowered by two stages. Its accuracy drops to 50% if used consecutively after itself or any other protecting move. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
King's Shield.gameDescription: The user takes a defensive stance while it protects itself from damage. It also harshly lowers the Attack stat of any attacker who makes direct contact.

Knock Off.name: Knock Off
Knock Off.effects: Knock Off deals damage and if the target has a held item, damage is increased by 50% (i.e. 97.5 base power) and the item is removed for the remainder of the battle (switching out does not restore the item). All items are restored at the end of a battle. If the item would activate on attack (e.g. Focus Band), it does so before being stolen. If the item is consumable on attack (e.g. Focus Sash) then the item is consumed as normal and cannot be stolen. Pokemon with the ability Sticky Hold cannot have their held item removed. The Griseous Orb cannot be removed from Giratina; Type Plates cannot be removed from Arceus; Drives cannot be removed from Genesect; and Mega Stones cannot be removed from their respective Pokémon. Note that in these cases the damage dealt does not increase.
Knock Off.changes: In Generations 3-5, Knock Off has base power 20, and did not increase damage when knocking off items. In Generation 6 only, Knock Off has 25 PP.
Knock Off.gameDescription: The user slaps down the target’s held item, and that item can’t be used in that battle. The move does more damage if the target has a held item.

Land's Wrath.name: Land's Wrath
Land's Wrath.effects: Land's Wrath deals damage with no additional effects.
Land's Wrath.gameDescription: The user gathers the energy of the land and focuses that power on opposing Pokémon to damage them.

Laser Focus.name: Laser Focus
Laser Focus.effects: User's next attack is guaranteed to result in a critical hit.
Laser Focus.gameDescription: The user concentrates intensely. The attack on the next turn always results in a critical hit.

Last Resort.name: Last Resort
Last Resort.effects: Last Resort deals high damage, but will fail if the user has not used each of its other moves at least once (or has no other moves). If the user switches out, the move gets reset and when it switches back in, will need to use each of its other moves at least once in order to use Last Resort again.
Last Resort.changes: In Generations 1-4, Last Resort has a base power of 130.
Last Resort.gameDescription: This move can be used only after the user has used all the other moves it knows in the battle.

Lava Plume.name: Lava Plume
Lava Plume.effects: Lava Plume deals damage and has a 30% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Lava Plume.gameDescription: The user torches everything around it in an inferno of scarlet flames. This may also leave those it hits with a burn.

Leaf Blade.name: Leaf Blade
Leaf Blade.effects: Leaf Blade deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Leaf Blade.changes: In Generations 1-3, Leaf Blade has a base power of 70.
Leaf Blade.gameDescription: The user handles a sharp leaf like a sword and attacks by cutting its target. Critical hits land more easily.

Leaf Storm.name: Leaf Storm
Leaf Storm.effects: Leaf Storm deals damage but lowers the user's Special Attack by two stages after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Leaf Storm.changes: In Generations 4-5, Leaf Storm has base power 140.
Leaf Storm.gameDescription: The user whips up a storm of leaves around the target. The attack’s recoil harshly lowers the user’s Sp. Atk stat.

Leaf Tornado.name: Leaf Tornado
Leaf Tornado.effects: Leaf Tornado deals damage and has a 30% chance of lowering the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Leaf Tornado.gameDescription: The user attacks its target by encircling it in sharp leaves. This attack may also lower the target’s accuracy.

Leafage.name: Leafage
Leafage.gameDescription: The user attacks by pelting the target with leaves.

Leech Life.name: Leech Life
Leech Life.effects: Leech Life deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained. If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokemon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
Leech Life.changes: In Generations 1-6, Leech Life has base power 20 and 15 PP.
Leech Life.gameDescription: The user drains the target’s blood. The user’s HP is restored by half the damage taken by the target.

Leech Seed.name: Leech Seed
Leech Seed.effects: Leech Seed plants a seed on the target that drains 1⁄8 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn and restores it to the user, or any Pokemon that takes its place. It does not work on Grass-type Pokemon; it does technically work against Pokemon with the Magic Guard ability, but no HP will be sapped. If the user is holding a Big Root, the move still saps the same amount of HP but recovers 30% more than normal. For example, if a Pokemon has 320 HP, Leech Seed would cause them to lose 40 HP each turn but the seeder would recover 52 HP. If used on a Pokemon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained. The seeded Pokemon can clear Leech Seed by switching out or using Rapid Spin.
Leech Seed.changes: In Generation 1, Leech Seed saps 1⁄16 of the target's HP. If the target is also badly poisoned, the damage increases by 1⁄16 each turn, in the same way as bad poison (and in addition to poison damage). In Generation 1 and Generation 2 only, Haze will also clear the effects of Leech Seed.
Leech Seed.gameDescription: A seed is planted on the target. It steals some HP from the target every turn.

Leer.name: Leer
Leer.effects: Leer lowers the target's Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Leer.gameDescription: The user gives opposing Pokémon an intimidating leer that lowers the Defense stat.

Lick.name: Lick
Lick.effects: Lick deals damage and has a 30% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Lick.changes: In Generations 1-5, Lick has base power 20.
Lick.gameDescription: The target is licked with a long tongue, causing damage. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Light of Ruin.name: Light of Ruin
Light of Ruin.effects: Light of Ruin deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄2 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 100 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 50 HP.
Light of Ruin.gameDescription: Drawing power from the Eternal Flower, the user fires a powerful beam of light. This also damages the user quite a lot.

Light Screen.name: Light Screen
Light Screen.effects: Light Screen reduces damage from Special attacks by 50%, for 5 turns. Its effects apply to all Pokémon on the user's side of the field. If the user is holding Light Clay when Light Screen is used, its effects last for 8 turns. The move Brick Break, when used against an Pokémon under Light Screen's effect, will remove the screen before dealing damage. The ability Infiltrator bypasses the effects of Light Screen. Light Screen is the Special counterpart to Reflect.
Light Screen.gameDescription: A wondrous wall of light is put up to reduce damage from special attacks for five turns.
Light Screen.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Liquidation.name: Liquidation
Liquidation.effects: The user slams into the target using a full-force blast of water. This may also lower the target’s Defense stat.
Liquidation.gameDescription: The user slams into the target using a full-force blast of water. This may also lower the target’s Defense stat.

Lock-On.name: Lock-On
Lock-On.effects: User's next attack is guaranteed to hit.
Lock-On.gameDescription: The user takes sure aim at the target. This ensures the next attack does not miss the target.

Lovely Kiss.name: Lovely Kiss
Lovely Kiss.effects: Lovely Kiss puts the target to sleep, if it hits. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns. Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
Lovely Kiss.gameDescription: With a scary face, the user tries to force a kiss on the target. If it succeeds, the target falls asleep.

Low Kick.name: Low Kick
Low Kick.effects:
Weight (kg) Power


0.1 - 9.9 20
10.0 - 24.9 40
25.0 - 49.9 60
50.0 - 99.9 80
100.0 - 199.9 100
200.0+ 120

 Low Kick inflicts greater damage on heavier opponents, as per the table to the right. Low Kick is able to hit opponents hidden underwater from using Dive.
Low Kick.changes: In Generations 1-2, Low Kick has 90% accuracy and a fixed base power of 50. It also has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved).
Low Kick.gameDescription: A powerful low kick that makes the target fall over. The heavier the target, the greater the move’s power.

Low Sweep.name: Low Sweep
Low Sweep.effects: Low Sweep deals damage and lowers the target's Speed by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Low Sweep.changes: In Generation 5, Low Sweep has base power 60.
Low Sweep.gameDescription: The user makes a swift attack on the target’s legs, which lowers the target’s Speed stat.

Lucky Chant.name: Lucky Chant
Lucky Chant.effects: Opponent cannot land critical hits for 5 turns.
Lucky Chant.gameDescription: The user chants an incantation toward the sky, preventing opposing Pokémon from landing critical hits for five turns.
Lucky Chant.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Lunar Dance.name: Lunar Dance
Lunar Dance.effects: The user faints but the next Pokémon released is fully healed.
Lunar Dance.gameDescription: The user faints. In return, the Pokémon taking its place will have its status and HP fully restored.

Lunge.name: Lunge
Lunge.effects: The user makes a lunge at the target, attacking with full force. This also lowers the target’s Attack stat.
Lunge.gameDescription: The user makes a lunge at the target, attacking with full force. This also lowers the target’s Attack stat.

Luster Purge.name: Luster Purge
Luster Purge.effects: Luster Purge deals damage and has a 50% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Luster Purge.gameDescription: The user lets loose a damaging burst of light. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Mach Punch.name: Mach Punch
Mach Punch.effects: Mach Punch deals damage and has a priority of +1. Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
Mach Punch.gameDescription: The user throws a punch at blinding speed. This move always goes first.

Magic Coat.name: Magic Coat
Magic Coat.effects: Magic Coat reflects any move causing status conditions - for example Thunder Wave or Toxic - back to the attacker. It applies only to the turn it is used.
Magic Coat.changes: In Generations 3-4, Teeter Dance and Memento are not affected by Magic Coat.
Magic Coat.gameDescription: A barrier reflects back to the target moves like Leech Seed and moves that damage status.

Magic Room.name: Magic Room
Magic Room.effects: Magic Room suppresses the effects of held items for all Pokémon for five turns.
Magic Room.gameDescription: The user creates a bizarre area in which Pokémon’s held items lose their effects for five turns.

Magical Leaf.name: Magical Leaf
Magical Leaf.effects: Magical Leaf deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Magical Leaf.gameDescription: The user scatters curious leaves that chase the target. This attack never misses.

Magma Storm.name: Magma Storm
Magma Storm.effects: Magma Storm inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the opponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
Magma Storm.changes: In Generations 1-4, Magma Storm has 70% accuracy. Its after-effects also last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5.
Magma Storm.gameDescription: The target becomes trapped within a maelstrom of fire that rages for four to five turns.

Magnet Bomb.name: Magnet Bomb
Magnet Bomb.effects: Magnet Bomb deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Magnet Bomb.gameDescription: The user launches steel bombs that stick to the target. This attack never misses.

Magnet Rise.name: Magnet Rise
Magnet Rise.effects: User becomes immune to Ground-type moves for 5 turns.
Magnet Rise.gameDescription: The user levitates using electrically generated magnetism for five turns.

Magnetic Flux.name: Magnetic Flux
Magnetic Flux.effects: Magnetic Flux raises the Defense and Special Defense of ally Pokémon with the Plus or Minus abilities.
Magnetic Flux.gameDescription: The user manipulates magnetic fields, which raises the Defense and Sp. Def stats of ally Pokémon with the Plus or Minus Ability.
