Magnitude.name: Magnitude
Magnitude.effects:
Magnitude Prob. Power


4 5% 10
5 10% 30
6 20% 50
7 30% 70
8 20% 90
9 10% 110
10 5% 150

 The base power of Magnitude is one of 7 random values, with varying probability, as per the table to the right. Magnitude will hit with double power if the opponent is underground due to the move Dig.
Magnitude.gameDescription: The user attacks everything around it with a ground-shaking quake. Its power varies.

Malicious Moonsault.name: Malicious Moonsault
Malicious Moonsault.effects: Malicious Moonsault is a Dark type Z-move exclusive to Incineroar. It is used with Incineroar's signature move Darkest Lariat.
Malicious Moonsault.gameDescription: The user, Incineroar, strengthens its body using its Z-Power and crashes into the target with full force.

Mat Block.name: Mat Block
Mat Block.effects: Mat Block protects the user's team from Physical or Special category moves, but not Status moves.
Mat Block.changes: In Generation 6, Mat Block has 15 PP.
Mat Block.gameDescription: Using a pulled-up mat as a shield, the user protects itself and its allies from damaging moves. This does not stop status moves.

Me First.name: Me First
Me First.effects: If the opponent is readying a direct attack, the user of Me First will try to copy it and attack with 50% more power. The move only works if the user is faster than the opponent or otherwise able to move first (for example a Quick Claw activating). Me First cannot copy Sucker Punch or Fake Out, nor by its definition above, any high priority move such as ExtremeSpeed. However it can copy a multi-turn move from any of its turns.
Me First.gameDescription: The user cuts ahead of the target to copy and use the target’s intended move with greater power. This move fails if it isn’t used first.
Me First.target: Targets the user, but hits a random adjacent opponent.

Mean Look.name: Mean Look
Mean Look.gameDescription: The user pins the target with a dark, arresting look. The target becomes unable to flee.

Meditate.name: Meditate
Meditate.effects: Meditate raises the user's Attack by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Meditate.gameDescription: The user meditates to awaken the power deep within its body and raise its Attack stat.

Mega Drain.name: Mega Drain
Mega Drain.effects: Mega Drain deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained. If the user is holding a Big Root, the move instead recovers 65% of the damage dealt (30% more than normal). If used on a Pokemon with the ability Liquid Ooze, the user instead loses the HP it would have otherwise gained.
Mega Drain.changes: In Generations 1-3, Mega Drain has 10 PP.
Mega Drain.gameDescription: A nutrient-draining attack. The user’s HP is restored by half the damage taken by the target.

Mega Kick.name: Mega Kick
Mega Kick.effects: Mega Kick deals damage with no additional effect.
Mega Kick.gameDescription: The target is attacked by a kick launched with muscle-packed power.

Mega Punch.name: Mega Punch
Mega Punch.effects: Mega Punch deals damage with no additional effect.
Mega Punch.gameDescription: The target is slugged by a punch thrown with muscle-packed power.

Megahorn.name: Megahorn
Megahorn.effects: Megahorn deals damage with no additional effect.
Megahorn.gameDescription: Using its tough and impressive horn, the user rams into the target with no letup.

Memento.name: Memento
Memento.effects: User faints, sharply lowers opponent's Attack and Special Attack.
Memento.gameDescription: The user faints when using this move. In return, this harshly lowers the target’s Attack and Sp. Atk stats.

Metal Burst.name: Metal Burst
Metal Burst.effects: Deals damage equal to 1.5x opponent's attack.
Metal Burst.gameDescription: The user retaliates with much greater force against the opponent that last inflicted damage on it.

Metal Claw.name: Metal Claw
Metal Claw.effects: Metal Claw deals damage and has a 10% chance of raising the user's Attack by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Metal Claw.gameDescription: The target is raked with steel claws. This may also raise the user’s Attack stat.

Metal Sound.name: Metal Sound
Metal Sound.effects: Metal Sound lowers the target's Special Defense by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Metal Sound.gameDescription: A horrible sound like scraping metal harshly lowers the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Meteor Mash.name: Meteor Mash
Meteor Mash.effects: Meteor Mash deals damage and has a 20% chance of raising the user's Attack by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Meteor Mash.changes: In Generations 3-5, Meteor Mash has base power 100 and 85% accuracy.
Meteor Mash.gameDescription: The target is hit with a hard punch fired like a meteor. This may also raise the user’s Attack stat.

Metronome.name: Metronome
Metronome.effects: User performs any move in the game at random.
Metronome.gameDescription: The user waggles a finger and stimulates its brain into randomly using nearly any move.

Milk Drink.name: Milk Drink
Milk Drink.effects: Milk Drink recovers up to 50% of the user's maximum HP.
Milk Drink.gameDescription: The user restores its own HP by up to half of its max HP.

Mimic.name: Mimic
Mimic.effects: Mimic copies the last move used by the target (replacing Mimic). The copied move always has 5 PP. The effect only lasts while the user is in battle: if the user switches out or when the battle ends, the move becomes Mimic again. Mimic cannot copy Chatter, Metronome, Sketch or Struggle.
Mimic.changes: In Generation 1, Mimic allows the user to choose any of the opponent's moves to copy.
Mimic.gameDescription: The user copies the target’s last move. The move can be used during battle until the Pokémon is switched out.

Mind Reader.name: Mind Reader
Mind Reader.effects: User's next attack is guaranteed to hit.
Mind Reader.gameDescription: The user senses the target’s movements with its mind to ensure its next attack does not miss the target.

Minimize.name: Minimize
Minimize.effects: Minimize raises the user's Evasion by two stages, thus making the user more difficult to hit. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each. The moves Stomp and Steamroller hit with double power against a Pokemon that has used Minimize.
Minimize.changes: In Generations 1-5, Minimize has 20 PP. In Generations 1-4, Minimize only raises Evasion one stage.
Minimize.gameDescription: The user compresses its body to make itself look smaller, which sharply raises its evasiveness.

Miracle Eye.name: Miracle Eye
Miracle Eye.effects: Resets opponent's Evasiveness, removes Dark's Psychic immunity.
Miracle Eye.gameDescription: Enables a Dark-type target to be hit by Psychic-type attacks. This also enables an evasive target to be hit.

Mirror Coat.name: Mirror Coat
Mirror Coat.effects: When hit by a Special Attack, user strikes back with 2x power.
Mirror Coat.gameDescription: A retaliation move that counters any special attack, inflicting double the damage taken.

Mirror Move.name: Mirror Move
Mirror Move.effects: User performs the opponent's last move.
Mirror Move.gameDescription: The user counters the target by mimicking the target’s last move.

Mirror Shot.name: Mirror Shot
Mirror Shot.effects: Mirror Shot deals damage and has a 30% chance of lowering the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Mirror Shot.gameDescription: The user lets loose a flash of energy at the target from its polished body. This may also lower the target’s accuracy.

Mist.name: Mist
Mist.effects: User's stats cannot be changed for a period of time.
Mist.gameDescription: The user cloaks itself and its allies in a white mist that prevents any of their stats from being lowered for five turns.
Mist.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Mist Ball.name: Mist Ball
Mist Ball.effects: Mist Ball deals damage and has a 50% chance of lowering the target's Special Attack by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Mist Ball.gameDescription: A mist-like flurry of down envelops and damages the target. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Atk stat.

Misty Terrain.name: Misty Terrain
Misty Terrain.effects: Misty Terrain creates a low-lying mist for 5 turns, that protects all grounded Pokémon from status conditions (including confusion). It also halves the power of Dragon type moves while in effect. Grounded Pokémon are simply those that are not raised. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary. Misty Terrain is a terrain condition and can coexist at the same time as weather conditions, but not other terrain conditions. The move Nature Power turns into Moonblast under Misty Terrain.
Misty Terrain.gameDescription: This protects Pokémon on the ground from status conditions and halves damage from Dragon-type moves for five turns.

Moonblast.name: Moonblast
Moonblast.effects: Moonblast deals damage and has a 30% chance of lowering the target's Special Attack by one stage.
Moonblast.gameDescription: Borrowing the power of the moon, the user attacks the target. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Atk stat.

Moongeist Beam.name: Moongeist Beam
Moongeist Beam.gameDescription: The user emits a sinister ray to attack the target. This move can be used on the target regardless of its Abilities.

Moonlight.name: Moonlight
Moonlight.effects: The user restores its own HP. The amount of HP regained varies with the weather.
Moonlight.changes: Prior to Generation 6, Moonlight was Normal type.
Moonlight.gameDescription: The user restores its own HP. The amount of HP regained varies with the weather.

Morning Sun.name: Morning Sun
Morning Sun.effects: User recovers HP. Amount varies with the weather.
Morning Sun.gameDescription: The user restores its own HP. The amount of HP regained varies with the weather.

Mud Bomb.name: Mud Bomb
Mud Bomb.effects: Mud Bomb deals damage and has a 30% chance of lowering the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Mud Bomb.gameDescription: The user launches a hard-packed mud ball to attack. This may also lower the target’s accuracy.

Mud Shot.name: Mud Shot
Mud Shot.effects: Mud Shot deals damage and lowers the target's Speed by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Mud Shot.gameDescription: The user attacks by hurling a blob of mud at the target. This also lowers the target’s Speed stat.

Mud Sport.name: Mud Sport
Mud Sport.effects: Mud Sport reduces the power of Electric type moves by 50%. The effect applies to the entire field. Most Pokemon that learn Mud Sport are part Ground type and thus already immune to Electric attacks.
Mud Sport.gameDescription: The user kicks up mud on the battlefield. This weakens Electric-type moves for five turns.

Mud-Slap.name: Mud-Slap
Mud-Slap.effects: Mud-Slap deals damage and lowers the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Mud-Slap.gameDescription: The user hurls mud in the target’s face to inflict damage and lower its accuracy.

Muddy Water.name: Muddy Water
Muddy Water.effects: Muddy Water deals damage and has a 30% chance of lowering the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Muddy Water.changes: In Generations 3-5, Muddy Water has base power 95.
Muddy Water.gameDescription: The user attacks by shooting muddy water at the opposing Pokémon. This may also lower their accuracy.

Multi-Attack.name: Multi-Attack
Multi-Attack.gameDescription: Cloaking itself in high energy, the user slams into the target. The memory held determines the move’s type.

Mystical Fire.name: Mystical Fire
Mystical Fire.effects: Mystical Fire deals damage and lowers the target's Special Attack by one stage.
Mystical Fire.changes: In Generation 6, Mystical Fire has base power 65.
Mystical Fire.gameDescription: The user attacks by breathing a special, hot fire. This also lowers the target’s Sp. Atk stat.

Nasty Plot.name: Nasty Plot
Nasty Plot.effects: Nasty Plot raises the user's Special Attack by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Nasty Plot.gameDescription: The user stimulates its brain by thinking bad thoughts. This sharply raises the user’s Sp. Atk stat.

Natural Gift.name: Natural Gift
Natural Gift.effects:
Natural Gift deals damage with no additional effects. However, its type and base power vary depending on the user's held Berry. The grid below shows which Berries provide which power and type. For example, if a Pokemon holding a Cheri Berry uses Natural Gift, it will become a base power 60, Fire-type attack; holding a Starf Berry it will become an 80 power Psychic-type move. 

60 BP 70 BP 80 BP


Normal Chilan Berry 
Fire Cheri Berry, Occa Berry Bluk Berry Watmel Berry
Water Chesto Berry, Passho Berry Nanab Berry Durin Berry
Electric Pecha Berry, Wacan Berry Wepear Berry Belue Berry
Grass Rawst Berry, Rindo Berry Pinap Berry Liechi Berry
Ice Aspear Berry, Yache Berry Pomeg Berry Ganlon Berry
Fighting Leppa Berry, Chople Berry Kelpsy Berry Salac Berry
Poison Oran Berry, Kebia Berry Qualot Berry Petaya Berry
Ground Persim Berry, Shuca Berry Hondew Berry Apicot Berry
Flying Lum Berry, Coba Berry Grepa Berry Lansat Berry
Psychic Sitrus Berry, Payapa Berry Tamato Berry Starf Berry
Bug Figy Berry, Tanga Berry Cornn Berry Enigma Berry
Rock Wiki Berry, Charti Berry Magost Berry Micle Berry
Ghost Mago Berry, Kasib Berry Rabuta Berry Custap Berry
Dragon Aguav Berry, Haban Berry Nomel Berry Jaboca Berry
Dark Iapapa Berry, Colbur Berry Spelon Berry Rowap Berry
Steel Razz Berry, Babiri Berry Pamtre Berry
Natural Gift.gameDescription: The user draws power to attack by using its held Berry. The Berry determines the move’s type and power.

Nature Power.name: Nature Power
Nature Power.effects: When Nature Power is used it turns into a different move depending on the current battle terrain, as listed below. Although it's a Normal type move, the user only receives STAB if the move it turns into is their type. For example, Sawsbuck (Normal/Grass) would not obtain STAB if Nature Power turned into Hydro Pump, but Ludicolo would. In double/triple battles, due to the different moves having varying targets Nature Power is set to target the user. However, moves that target multiple Pokémon such as Rock Slide or Earthquake still hit multiple foes and/or teammates as normal. Moves that target a single foe will strike the Pokémon directly opposite the user, or an adjacent foe if there is no Pokémon opposite.
Nature Power.gameDescription: This attack makes use of nature’s power. Its effects vary depending on the user’s environment.

Nature's Madness.name: Nature's Madness
Nature's Madness.gameDescription: The user hits the target with the force of nature. It halves the target’s HP.

Needle Arm.name: Needle Arm
Needle Arm.effects: Needle Arm deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Needle Arm.gameDescription: The user attacks by wildly swinging its thorny arms. This may also make the target flinch.

Never-Ending Nightmare.name: Never-Ending Nightmare
Never-Ending Nightmare.effects: Never-Ending Nightmare is the Ghost type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Never-Ending Nightmare.gameDescription: Deep-seated grudges summoned by the user’s Z-Power trap the target. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Night Daze.name: Night Daze
Night Daze.effects: Night Daze deals damage and has a 40% chance of lowering the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Night Daze.gameDescription: The user lets loose a pitch-black shock wave at its target. This may also lower the target’s accuracy.

Night Shade.name: Night Shade
Night Shade.effects: The damage of Night Shade is equal to the user's level. So at level 100 the Pokémon will inflict 100 HP damage.
Night Shade.changes: In Generation 1, Night Shade also hits Normal- and Psychic-type Pokémon despite their immunity to Ghost-type attacks.
Night Shade.gameDescription: The user makes the target see a frightening mirage. It inflicts damage equal to the user’s level.

Night Slash.name: Night Slash
Night Slash.effects: Night Slash deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Night Slash.gameDescription: The user slashes the target the instant an opportunity arises. Critical hits land more easily.

Nightmare.name: Nightmare
Nightmare.effects: If the target is asleep, Nightmare causes it to lose 1⁄4 of its maximum HP after each turn. The status condition is cured when the Pokemon wakes up.
Nightmare.gameDescription: A sleeping target sees a nightmare that inflicts some damage every turn.

Noble Roar.name: Noble Roar
Noble Roar.effects: Noble Roar lowers the target's Attack and Special Attack by one stage each. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Noble Roar.gameDescription: Letting out a noble roar, the user intimidates the target and lowers its Attack and Sp. Atk stats.

Nuzzle.name: Nuzzle
Nuzzle.effects: Nuzzle deals damage and paralyzes the target. Paralyzed Pokémon have a 25% chance of not being able to attack, and their Speed is decreased by 75%. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Nuzzle.gameDescription: The user attacks by nuzzling its electrified cheeks against the target. This also leaves the target with paralysis.

Oblivion Wing.name: Oblivion Wing
Oblivion Wing.effects: Oblivion Wing deals damage and the user will recover 75% of the HP drained. Oblivion Wing is the signature move of Yveltal. In battle, the user flies high into the sky then releases a beam of red light that scorches the ground.
Oblivion Wing.gameDescription: The user absorbs its target’s HP. The user’s HP is restored by over half of the damage taken by the target.

Oceanic Operetta.name: Oceanic Operetta
Oceanic Operetta.effects: Oceanic Operetta is a Water type Z-move exclusive to Primarina. It is used with Primarina's signature move Sparkling Aria.
Oceanic Operetta.gameDescription: The user, Primarina, summons a massive amount of water using its Z-Power and attacks the target with full force.

Octazooka.name: Octazooka
Octazooka.effects: Octazooka deals damage and has a 50% chance of lowering the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Octazooka.gameDescription: The user attacks by spraying ink in the target’s face or eyes. This may also lower the target’s accuracy.

Odor Sleuth.name: Odor Sleuth
Odor Sleuth.effects: Resets opponent's Evasiveness, Normal-type and Fighting-type attacks can now hit Ghosts, and Ghost-type attacks hit Normal.
Odor Sleuth.gameDescription: Enables a Ghost-type target to be hit by Normal- and Fighting-type attacks. This also enables an evasive target to be hit.

Ominous Wind.name: Ominous Wind
Ominous Wind.effects: Ominous Wind deals damage and has a 10% chance of raising the user's Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Ominous Wind.gameDescription: The user blasts the target with a gust of repulsive wind. This may also raise all the user’s stats at once.

Origin Pulse.name: Origin Pulse
Origin Pulse.effects: Origin Pulse deals damage and hits all adjacent opponents in double/triple battles. It is the signature move of Kyogre.
Origin Pulse.gameDescription: The user attacks opposing Pokémon with countless beams of light that glow a deep and brilliant blue.

Outrage.name: Outrage
Outrage.effects: The user of Outrage attacks for 2-3 turns, during which it cannot switch out, and then becomes confused. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. If Outrage is disrupted (e.g. if the move misses or the user cannot attack due to paralysis) then it will stop and not cause confusion. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Outrage.changes: In Generations 1-3, Outrage has a base power of 90. In Generations 1-4, it has 15 PP. Furthermore, sleep, freezing and flinching will pause but not disrupt Outrage.
Outrage.gameDescription: The user rampages and attacks for two to three turns. The user then becomes confused.
Outrage.target: Targets the user, but hits a random adjacent opponent.

Overheat.name: Overheat
Overheat.effects: Overheat deals damage but lowers the user's Special Attack by two stages after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Overheat.changes: In Generations 3-5, Overheat has base power 140.
Overheat.gameDescription: The user attacks the target at full power. The attack’s recoil harshly lowers the user’s Sp. Atk stat.

Pain Split.name: Pain Split
Pain Split.effects: The user's and opponent's HP becomes the average of both.
Pain Split.gameDescription: The user adds its HP to the target’s HP, then equally shares the combined HP with the target.

Parabolic Charge.name: Parabolic Charge
Parabolic Charge.effects: Parabolic Charge deals damage and the user will recover 50% of the HP drained. It targets all adjacent Pokémon.
Parabolic Charge.changes: In Generation 6, Parabolic Charge has base power 50.
Parabolic Charge.gameDescription: The user attacks everything around it. The user’s HP is restored by half the damage taken by those hit.

Parting Shot.name: Parting Shot
Parting Shot.effects: Parting Shot lowers the opponent's Attack and Special Attack by one stage each, then the user switches out of battle. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Parting Shot.gameDescription: With a parting threat, the user lowers the target’s Attack and Sp. Atk stats. Then it switches with a party Pokémon.

Pay Day.name: Pay Day
Pay Day.effects: A small amount of money is gained after the battle resolves.
Pay Day.gameDescription: Numerous coins are hurled at the target to inflict damage. Money is earned after the battle.

Payback.name: Payback
Payback.effects: Power doubles if the user was attacked first.
Payback.gameDescription: The user stores power, then attacks. If the user moves after the target, this attack’s power will be doubled.

Peck.name: Peck
Peck.effects: Peck deals damage with no additional effect, besides being able to hit non-adjacent Pokémon in triple battles.
Peck.gameDescription: The target is jabbed with a sharply pointed beak or horn.
Peck.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Perish Song.name: Perish Song
Perish Song.effects: Any Pokémon in play when this attack is used faints in 3 turns.
Perish Song.gameDescription: Any Pokémon that hears this song faints in three turns, unless it switches out of battle.

Petal Blizzard.name: Petal Blizzard
Petal Blizzard.effects: Petal Blizzard deals damage with no additional effect. In double battles it will hit all Pokémon on the field; in triple battles it will hit all adjacent Pokémon.
Petal Blizzard.gameDescription: The user stirs up a violent petal blizzard and attacks everything around it.

Petal Dance.name: Petal Dance
Petal Dance.effects: The user of Petal Dance attacks for 2-3 turns, during which it cannot switch out, and then becomes confused. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. If Petal Dance is disrupted (e.g. if the move misses or the user cannot attack due to paralysis) then it will stop and not cause confusion. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Petal Dance.changes: In Generations 1-3 Petal Dance has a base power of 70. In Generation 4 its base power is 90. In Generations 1-4, Petal Dance has 20 PP. Furthermore, sleep, freezing and flinching will pause but not disrupt Petal Dance. In Generation 1, Petal Dance lasts for 3-4 turns.
Petal Dance.gameDescription: The user attacks the target by scattering petals for two to three turns. The user then becomes confused.
Petal Dance.target: Targets the user, but hits a random adjacent opponent.

Phantom Force.name: Phantom Force
Phantom Force.effects: Phantom Force causes the user to disappear on the first turn, becoming invulnerable to most attacks. On the second turn, it deals damage and can hit Pokemon using Protect or Detect.
Phantom Force.gameDescription: The user vanishes somewhere, then strikes the target on the next turn. This move hits even if the target protects itself.

Pin Missile.name: Pin Missile
Pin Missile.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 50
3 3⁄8 75
4 1⁄8 100
5 1⁄8 125

 Pin Missile hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Pin Missile is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Pin Missile to always hit the maximum number of times.
Pin Missile.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Pin Missile ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest. In Generations 1-5, Pin Missile has 85% accuracy and a base power of 14, resulting in a total power of 28, 42, 56 or 70.
Pin Missile.gameDescription: Sharp spikes are shot at the target in rapid succession. They hit two to five times in a row.

Play Nice.name: Play Nice
Play Nice.effects: Play Nice lowers the target's Attack by one stage. The move always hits, even if the target used a Protect-like move. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Play Nice.gameDescription: The user and the target become friends, and the target loses its will to fight. This lowers the target’s Attack stat.

Play Rough.name: Play Rough
Play Rough.effects: Play Rough deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Attack by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Play Rough.gameDescription: The user plays rough with the target and attacks it. This may also lower the target’s Attack stat.

Pluck.name: Pluck
Pluck.effects: If the opponent is holding a berry, its effect is stolen by user.
Pluck.gameDescription: The user pecks the target. If the target is holding a Berry, the user eats it and gains its effect.
Pluck.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Poison Fang.name: Poison Fang
Poison Fang.effects: Poison Fang deals damage and has a 50% chance of badly poisoning the target. Badly poisoned Pokémon will lose an increasing amount of HP at the end of each turn.
Poison Fang.changes: In Generations 3-5, Poison Fang has a 30% chance of badly poisoning the target.
Poison Fang.gameDescription: The user bites the target with toxic fangs. This may also leave the target badly poisoned.

Poison Gas.name: Poison Gas
Poison Gas.effects: Poison Gas causes the target to become poisoned. Poisoned Pokémon lose 1⁄8 of their maximum HP each turn. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Poison Gas.changes: In Generation 5, Poison Gas has 85% accuracy. In Generations 1-4, Poison Gas has 55% accuracy and only targets a single opponent.
Poison Gas.gameDescription: A cloud of poison gas is sprayed in the face of opposing Pokémon, poisoning those hit.

Poison Jab.name: Poison Jab
Poison Jab.effects: Poison Jab deals damage and has a 30% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Poison Jab.gameDescription: The target is stabbed with a tentacle or arm steeped in poison. This may also poison the target.

Poison Powder.name: Poison Powder
Poison Powder.effects: Poison Powder causes the target to become poisoned. Poisoned Pokémon lose 1⁄8 of their maximum HP each turn. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Poison Powder.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as PoisonPowder.
Poison Powder.gameDescription: The user scatters a cloud of poisonous dust that poisons the target.

Poison Sting.name: Poison Sting
Poison Sting.effects: Poison Sting deals damage and has a 30% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Poison Sting.gameDescription: The user stabs the target with a poisonous stinger. This may also poison the target.

Poison Tail.name: Poison Tail
Poison Tail.effects: Poison Tail deals damage and has a 10% chance of poisoning the target. It also has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16). Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Poison Tail.gameDescription: The user hits the target with its tail. This may also poison the target. Critical hits land more easily.

Pollen Puff.name: Pollen Puff
Pollen Puff.effects: The user attacks the enemy with a pollen puff that explodes. If the target is an ally, it gives the ally a pollen puff that restores its HP instead.
Pollen Puff.gameDescription: The user attacks the enemy with a pollen puff that explodes. If the target is an ally, it gives the ally a pollen puff that restores its HP instead.

Pound.name: Pound
Pound.effects: Pound deals damage with no additional effect.
Pound.gameDescription: The target is physically pounded with a long tail, a foreleg, or the like.

Powder.name: Powder
Powder.effects: Powder moves with priority and covers the target in a powder that lasts for the rest of the current turn only. It damages the target if they use a Fire type move in that turn, and prevents the Fire move from working.
Powder.gameDescription: The user covers the target in a combustible powder. If the target uses a Fire-type move, the powder explodes and damages the target.

Powder Snow.name: Powder Snow
Powder Snow.effects: Powder Snow deals damage and has a 10% chance of freezing the target. Ice type Pokémon, those with the ability Magma Armor or those behind a Substitute cannot be frozen.
Powder Snow.gameDescription: The user attacks with a chilling gust of powdery snow. This may also freeze the opposing Pokémon.

Power Gem.name: Power Gem
Power Gem.effects: Power Gem deals damage with no additional effect.
Power Gem.changes: In Generations 4-5, Power Gem has base power 70.
Power Gem.gameDescription: The user attacks with a ray of light that sparkles as if it were made of gemstones.

Power Split.name: Power Split
Power Split.effects: Power Split averages the user's Attack and Special Attack with those of the target. Stat boosts are not taken into account. The effect lasts until the battle ends or the Pokemon switches out. For example, if the user's Attack was 100, the opponent's was 200, and the opponent had used Swords Dance, then both Pokemon would end up with 150 Attack. Due to the stat boost, the opponent's effective Attack would now be 300 (instead of the 400 it was originally).
Power Split.gameDescription: The user employs its psychic power to average its Attack and Sp. Atk stats with those of the target.

Power Swap.name: Power Swap
Power Swap.effects: User and opponent swap Attack and Special Attack.
Power Swap.gameDescription: The user employs its psychic power to switch changes to its Attack and Sp. Atk stats with the target.

Power Trick.name: Power Trick
Power Trick.effects: User's own Attack and Defense switch.
Power Trick.gameDescription: The user employs its psychic power to switch its Attack stat with its Defense stat.

Power Trip.name: Power Trip
Power Trip.effects: The user boasts its strength and attacks the target. The more the user’s stats are raised, the greater the move’s power.
Power Trip.gameDescription: The user boasts its strength and attacks the target. The more the user’s stats are raised, the greater the move’s power.

Power Whip.name: Power Whip
Power Whip.effects: Power Whip deals damage with no additional effect.
Power Whip.gameDescription: The user violently whirls its vines, tentacles, or the like to harshly lash the target.

Power-Up Punch.name: Power-Up Punch
Power-Up Punch.effects: Power-Up Punch deals damage and raises the user's Attack by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Power-Up Punch.gameDescription: Striking opponents over and over makes the user’s fists harder. Hitting a target raises the Attack stat.

Precipice Blades.name: Precipice Blades
Precipice Blades.effects: Precipice Blades deals damage and hits all adjacent opponents in double/triple battles. It is the signature move of Groudon.
Precipice Blades.gameDescription: The user attacks opposing Pokémon by manifesting the power of the land in fearsome blades of stone.

Present.name: Present
Present.gameDescription: The user attacks by giving the target a gift with a hidden trap. It restores HP sometimes, however.

Prismatic Laser.name: Prismatic Laser
Prismatic Laser.effects: The user shoots powerful lasers using the power of a prism. The user can’t move on the next turn.
Prismatic Laser.gameDescription: The user shoots powerful lasers using the power of a prism. The user can’t move on the next turn.

Protect.name: Protect
Protect.effects: Protect prevents any attacks targeted at the user from striking on that turn. It is identical to Detect. Its accuracy drops to 50% if used consecutively after itself, Detect, Endure, Quick Guard or Wide Guard.
Protect.changes: In Generations 1-4, the accuracy of Protect drops by 50% each time when used consecutively after itself, Detect or Endure.
Protect.gameDescription: Enables the user to evade all attacks. Its chance of failing rises if it is used in succession.

Psybeam.name: Psybeam
Psybeam.effects: Psybeam deals damage and has a 10% chance of confusing the target. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Psybeam.gameDescription: The target is attacked with a peculiar ray. This may also leave the target confused.

Psych Up.name: Psych Up
Psych Up.gameDescription: The user hypnotizes itself into copying any stat change made by the target.

Psychic.name: Psychic
Psychic.effects: Psychic deals damage and has a 10% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Psychic.changes: In Generation 1, Psychic has a 30% chance of lowering the target's Special stat (Sp.Atk and Sp.Def combined).
Psychic.gameDescription: The target is hit by a strong telekinetic force. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Psychic Fangs.name: Psychic Fangs
Psychic Fangs.effects: The user bites the target with its psychic capabilities. This can also destroy Light Screen and Reflect.
Psychic Fangs.gameDescription: The user bites the target with its psychic capabilities. This can also destroy Light Screen and Reflect.

Psychic Terrain.name: Psychic Terrain
Psychic Terrain.effects: Psychic Terrain creates a low-lying psychic field for 5 turns, that prevents high-priority moves (such as Quick Attack or Sucker Punch) being used. The power of Psychic type moves also increases while in effect. Grounded Pokémon are simply those that are not raised. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary. Psychic Terrain is a terrain condition and can coexist at the same time as weather conditions, but not other terrain conditions.
Psychic Terrain.gameDescription: This protects Pokémon on the ground from priority moves and powers up Psychic-type moves for five turns.

Psycho Boost.name: Psycho Boost
Psycho Boost.effects: Psycho Boost deals damage but lowers the user's Special Attack by two stages after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Psycho Boost.gameDescription: The user attacks the target at full power. The attack’s recoil harshly lowers the user’s Sp. Atk stat.

Psycho Cut.name: Psycho Cut
Psycho Cut.effects: Psycho Cut deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Psycho Cut.gameDescription: The user tears at the target with blades formed by psychic power. Critical hits land more easily.

Psycho Shift.name: Psycho Shift
Psycho Shift.effects: Gives the opponent the user's status condition, if it hits.
Psycho Shift.gameDescription: Using its psychic power of suggestion, the user transfers its status conditions to the target.

Psyshock.name: Psyshock
Psyshock.effects: Inflicts damage based on the target's Defense, not Special Defense.
Psyshock.gameDescription: The user materializes an odd psychic wave to attack the target. This attack does physical damage.

Psystrike.name: Psystrike
Psystrike.effects: Inflicts damage based on the target's Defense, not Special Defense.
Psystrike.gameDescription: The user materializes an odd psychic wave to attack the target. This attack does physical damage.

Psywave.name: Psywave
Psywave.effects: Psywave inflicts a random amount of HP damage, varying between 50% and 150% of the user's level. In other words, at level 100 the damage will be 50-150 HP. The damage is typeless (not affected by type advantages/disadvantages) but it still does not affect Dark type Pokemon.
Psywave.gameDescription: The target is attacked with an odd psychic wave. The attack varies in intensity.

Pulverizing Pancake.name: Pulverizing Pancake
Pulverizing Pancake.effects: Pulverizing Pancake is a Normal type Z-Move exclusive to Snorlax. It is used with Giga Impact.
Pulverizing Pancake.gameDescription: Z-Power brings out the true capabilities of the user, Snorlax. The Pokémon moves its enormous body energetically and attacks the target with full force.

Punishment.name: Punishment
Punishment.effects:
Punishment deals varying damage based on the opponent's stat increases. It starts at base power 60 and increases by 20 for every net stat boost of the opponent, up to a maximum of 200 (7 boosts). In other words the power is: 20 × NumIncreases + 60
 For example, if the opponent used Nasty Plot and Agility once each, that is a total of 4 stat increases (+2 Special Attack, +2 Speed) and Punishment's base power will be 20 × 4 + 60 = 140.
Punishment.gameDescription: The more the target has powered up with stat changes, the greater the move’s power.

Purify.name: Purify
Purify.effects: The user heals the target’s status condition. If the move succeeds, it also restores the user’s own HP.
Purify.gameDescription: The user heals the target’s status condition. If the move succeeds, it also restores the user’s own HP.

Pursuit.name: Pursuit
Pursuit.effects: Pursuit deals damage, and hits with double power if the target is switching out. In that case, Pursuit technically has priority +7, meaning it attacks before all other actions and moves.
Pursuit.gameDescription: The power of this attack move is doubled if it’s used on a target that’s switching out of battle.

Quash.name: Quash
Quash.effects: Quash forces the target Pokémon to move last in the current turn. It does not have priority so will fail if the target already moved in the current turn. Therefore it is useless in single battles and only works in double/triple battles.
Quash.gameDescription: The user suppresses the target and makes its move go last.

Quick Attack.name: Quick Attack
Quick Attack.effects: Quick Attack deals damage and has a priority of +1. Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
Quick Attack.gameDescription: The user lunges at the target at a speed that makes it almost invisible. This move always goes first.

Quick Guard.name: Quick Guard
Quick Guard.effects: Quick Guard protects the user's team from all increased priority moves such as ExtremeSpeed and Bullet Punch. Since its priority is +3 it will be used before all damage-dealing priority moves. Its accuracy drops to 50% if used consecutively after itself, Detect, Protect, Endure or Wide Guard.
Quick Guard.gameDescription: The user protects itself and its allies from priority moves.
Quick Guard.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Quiver Dance.name: Quiver Dance
Quiver Dance.effects: Quiver Dance raises the user's Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Quiver Dance.gameDescription: The user lightly performs a beautiful, mystic dance. This boosts the user’s Sp. Atk, Sp. Def, and Speed stats.

Rage.name: Rage
Rage.effects: Rage deals damage, and if the user is hit by a direct attack - any time after Rage is first used but before a different move is used - the user's Attack is raised by one stage. The game will state the Pokemon's rage is building rather than explicitly assert the stat increase. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each. The Attack increases will continue as long as Rage is the last move used, even if it misses, the user is incapacitated (paralyzed, sleeping, etc) or the player uses an item. The Attack increase activates for every blow of multi-hit moves such as DoubleSlap or Fury Swipes. As an example, if a Pokemon uses Rage then the opponent hits the user in the same turn, the user's Attack increases. If the user moves last it will not increase that turn, but will in the next turn if the opponent hits the user again.
Rage.changes: In Generation 1, after Rage is selected it will continue to be used until the end of the battle or the user faints. In Generations 2-3, if the user is slower than the opponent, the Attack rise only occurs if Rage is selected in that turn - if a different move is selected (or an item used) and the Pokemon is hit before it uses the new move, its Attack does not increase.
Rage.gameDescription: As long as this move is in use, the power of rage raises the Attack stat each time the user is hit in battle.

Rage Powder.name: Rage Powder
Rage Powder.effects: Rage Powder redirects all single-target moves used by opponents to itself. It is only useful in double or triple battles. It does not work for moves that target multiple Pokemon such as Air Cutter or Bulldoze.
Rage Powder.gameDescription: The user scatters a cloud of irritating powder to draw attention to itself. Opponents aim only at the user.

Rain Dance.name: Rain Dance
Rain Dance.effects:
Rain Dance causes a rain shower that lasts for 5 turns, and induces these additional effects: 
The power of Water-type moves increases by 50%.
The power of Fire-type moves and SolarBeam decreases by 50%.
The accuracy of Thunder and Hurricane rises to 100%.
In Diamond/Pearl only, Thunder has a 30% chance to break through Protect and Detect.
Pokemon with the ability Dry Skin recover 1⁄8 of their max HP each turn.
Pokemon with the ability Swift Swim double their speed.
The move Weather Ball changes to Water type and doubles in power.
The moves Synthesis, Morning Sun and Moonlight recover 1⁄4 of the user's max HP (instead of 1⁄2 HP normally).
Rain Dance.gameDescription: The user summons a heavy rain that falls for five turns, powering up Water-type moves. It lowers the power of Fire-type moves.

Rapid Spin.name: Rapid Spin
Rapid Spin.effects:
Rapid Spin deals a small amount of damage and removes the effects of several trap moves. It fails if the move misses or the target is immune. The effects from the following moves are removed: 
Bind
Clamp
Fire Spin
Leech Seed
Magma Storm
Sand Tomb
Spikes
Stealth Rock
Toxic Spikes
Whirlpool
Wrap
Rapid Spin.gameDescription: A spin attack that can also eliminate such moves as Bind, Wrap, Leech Seed, and Spikes.

Razor Leaf.name: Razor Leaf
Razor Leaf.effects: Razor Leaf deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Razor Leaf.gameDescription: Sharp-edged leaves are launched to slash at the opposing Pokémon. Critical hits land more easily.

Razor Shell.name: Razor Shell
Razor Shell.effects: Razor Shell deals damage and has a 50% chance of lowering the target's Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Razor Shell.gameDescription: The user cuts its target with sharp shells. This may also lower the target’s Defense stat.

Razor Wind.name: Razor Wind
Razor Wind.effects: The user of Razor Wind will whip up a whirlwind on the first turn. On the second turn, Razor Wind deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16). If the user is holding a Power Herb, Razor Wind executes in one turn.
Razor Wind.changes: In Generations 1-2, Razor Wind has 75% accuracy. In Generation 1, Razor Wind does not have an increased critical hit ratio.
Razor Wind.gameDescription: In this two-turn attack, blades of wind hit opposing Pokémon on the second turn. Critical hits land more easily.

Recover.name: Recover
Recover.effects: Recover restores up to 50% of the user's maximum HP.
Recover.gameDescription: Restoring its own cells, the user restores its own HP by half of its max HP.

Recycle.name: Recycle
Recycle.effects: User's used hold item is restored.
Recycle.gameDescription: The user recycles a held item that has been used in battle so it can be used again.

Reflect.name: Reflect
Reflect.effects: Reflect reduces damage from Physical attacks by 50%, for 5 turns. Its effects apply to all Pokémon on the user's side of the field. If the user is holding Light Clay when Reflect is used, its effects last for 8 turns. The move Brick Break, when used against an Pokémon under Reflect's effect, will remove the screen before dealing damage. The ability Infiltrator bypasses the effects of Reflect. Reflect is the Physical counterpart to Light Screen.
Reflect.gameDescription: A wondrous wall of light is put up to reduce damage from physical attacks for five turns.
Reflect.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Reflect Type.name: Reflect Type
Reflect Type.effects: Reflect Type changes the user's type to match the type(s) of the target.
Reflect Type.gameDescription: The user reflects the target’s type, making it the same type as the target.

Refresh.name: Refresh
Refresh.gameDescription: The user rests to cure itself of poisoning, a burn, or paralysis.

Relic Song.name: Relic Song
Relic Song.effects: May put the target to sleep.							(10% chance)
Relic Song.gameDescription: The user sings an ancient song and attacks by appealing to the hearts of the listening opposing Pokémon. This may also induce sleep.

Rest.name: Rest
Rest.effects: User sleeps for 2 turns, but user is fully healed.
Rest.gameDescription: The user goes to sleep for two turns. This fully restores the user’s HP and heals any status conditions.

Retaliate.name: Retaliate
Retaliate.effects: Inflicts double damage if a teammate fainted on the last turn.
Retaliate.gameDescription: The user gets revenge for a fainted ally. If an ally fainted in the previous turn, this move’s power is increased.

Return.name: Return
Return.effects: The power of Return is higher when the user likes its trainer more. The base power varies between 1 (minimum happiness) and 102 (maximum happiness). It is the counterpart move to Frustration.
Return.gameDescription: This full-power attack grows more powerful the more the user likes its Trainer.

Revelation Dance.name: Revelation Dance
Revelation Dance.effects:
Revelation Dance deals damage with a different type depending on the style of Oricorio: 
Baile Style - Fire
Pom-Pom Style - Electric
Pa'u Style - Psychic
Sensu Style - Ghost
Revelation Dance.gameDescription: The user attacks the target by dancing very hard. The user’s type determines the type of this move.

Revenge.name: Revenge
Revenge.effects: Power increases if user was hit first.
Revenge.gameDescription: This attack move’s power is doubled if the user has been hurt by the opponent in the same turn.

Reversal.name: Reversal
Reversal.effects:
Reversal deals more damage the lower the user's HP is, as per the table below. 

HP (%) Power


70.1 - 100 20
35.1 - 70 40
20.1 - 35 80
10.1 - 20 100
4.1 - 10 150
0 - 4 200
Reversal.gameDescription: An all-out attack that becomes more powerful the less HP the user has.

Roar.name: Roar
Roar.effects: In the wild, Roar causes the target Pokémon to flee if they are of a lower level, and the battle ends. In trainer battles (including linked battles), Roar forces the target to switch out of battle (regardless of level) and is replaced with another Pokémon in the trainer's team. Pokémon with the abilities Soundproof or Suction Cups or those rooted by Ingrain are not affected by Roar.
Roar.changes: In Generations 1-5, Roar has 100% accuracy (in other words, it is affected by Accuracy and Evasion stats). In Generations 1-4, Roar works on any level Pokémon in wild battles. Roar has a priority of -5 in Generation 3 and -1 in Generation 2. In Generation 1, Roar has no priority and only causes wild battles to end with no effect in trainer battles.
Roar.gameDescription: The target is scared off, and a different Pokémon is dragged out. In the wild, this ends a battle against a single Pokémon.

Roar of Time.name: Roar of Time
Roar of Time.gameDescription: The user blasts the target with power that distorts even time. The user can’t move on the next turn.

Rock Blast.name: Rock Blast
Rock Blast.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 50
3 3⁄8 75
4 1⁄8 100
5 1⁄8 125

 Rock Blast hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Rock Blast is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Rock Blast to always hit the maximum number of times.
Rock Blast.changes: In Generations 3-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generation 3, Rock Blast ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generations 3-4, Rock Blast has 80% accuracy.
Rock Blast.gameDescription: The user hurls hard rocks at the target. Two to five rocks are launched in a row.

Rock Climb.name: Rock Climb
Rock Climb.effects: Rock Climb deals damage and has a 20% chance of confusing the target. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.

Rock Polish.name: Rock Polish
Rock Polish.effects: Rock Polish raises the user's Speed by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Rock Polish.gameDescription: The user polishes its body to reduce drag. This can sharply raise the Speed stat.

Rock Slide.name: Rock Slide
Rock Slide.effects: Rock Slide deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Rock Slide.gameDescription: Large boulders are hurled at the opposing Pokémon to inflict damage. This may also make the opposing Pokémon flinch.

Rock Smash.name: Rock Smash
Rock Smash.effects: Rock Smash deals damage and has a 50% chance of lowering the target's Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Rock Smash.changes: In Generations 1-3, Rock Smash has a base power of 20.
Rock Smash.gameDescription: The user attacks with a punch. This may also lower the target’s Defense stat.

Rock Throw.name: Rock Throw
Rock Throw.effects: Rock Throw deals damage with no additional effect.
Rock Throw.changes: In Generation 1, Rock Throw has 65% accuracy.
Rock Throw.gameDescription: The user picks up and throws a small rock at the target to attack.

Rock Tomb.name: Rock Tomb
Rock Tomb.effects: Rock Tomb deals damage and lowers the target's Speed by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Rock Tomb.changes: In Generations 3-5, Rock Tomb has base power 50, 80% accuracy and 10 PP.
Rock Tomb.gameDescription: Boulders are hurled at the target. This also lowers the target’s Speed stat by preventing its movement.

Rock Wrecker.name: Rock Wrecker
Rock Wrecker.gameDescription: The user launches a huge boulder at the target to attack. The user can’t move on the next turn.

Role Play.name: Role Play
Role Play.effects: Role Play copies the opponent's ability, replacing its own with that of the target's. Role Play does not work on Pokemon with Wonder Guard or Multitype.
Role Play.gameDescription: The user mimics the target completely, copying the target’s natural Ability.

Rolling Kick.name: Rolling Kick
Rolling Kick.effects: Rolling Kick deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Rolling Kick.gameDescription: The user lashes out with a quick, spinning kick. This may also make the target flinch.

Rollout.name: Rollout
Rollout.effects: Rollout deals damage for 5 turns, doubling in power each turn. The move stops if it misses on any turn. If it doesn't miss, Rollout will deal 30, 60, 120, 240 and 480 base power damage each turn respectively. If the user has used Defense Curl in any previous turn (without switching out) then Rollout doubles in power, i.e. it will deal 60, 120, 240, 480 and 960 base power damage respectively. As Rollout has 90% accuracy, the chances of it being successful for each turn (with normal Accuracy/Evasion and no other interruptions) are 90%, 81%, 73%, 66% and 59% respectively. In other words, roughly 3 out of every 5 times Rollout is used, it will hit for the full 5 turns.
Rollout.gameDescription: The user continually rolls into the target over five turns. It becomes more powerful each time it hits.

Roost.name: Roost
Roost.effects: User recovers half of its max HP and loses the Flying type temporarily.
Roost.gameDescription: The user lands and rests its body. It restores the user’s HP by up to half of its max HP.

Rototiller.name: Rototiller
Rototiller.effects: Rototiller raises the Attack and Special Attack of any Grass-type Pokémon on the field by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Rototiller.gameDescription: Tilling the soil, the user makes it easier for plants to grow. This raises the Attack and Sp. Atk stats of Grass-type Pokémon.

Round.name: Round
Round.effects: Round deals damage. If multiple Pokémon on the same team use it in the same turn, the power doubles to 120 and the slower Pokémon move immediately after the fastest Pokémon uses it, regardless of their Speed.
Round.gameDescription: The user attacks the target with a song. Others can join in the Round to increase the power of the attack.

Sacred Fire.name: Sacred Fire
Sacred Fire.effects: Sacred Fire deals damage and has a 50% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned. If the user is frozen, Sacred Fire can be used and will thaw out the Pokemon before attacking.
Sacred Fire.gameDescription: The target is razed with a mystical fire of great intensity. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Sacred Sword.name: Sacred Sword
Sacred Sword.effects: Sacred Sword deals damage, but ignores changes to the target's stats (i.e. Defense and Evasion in this case). Note this does not include the effects of screens like Reflect as they are different to regular stat boosts.
Sacred Sword.gameDescription: The user attacks by slicing with a long horn. The target’s stat changes don’t affect this attack’s damage.

Safeguard.name: Safeguard
Safeguard.effects: The user's party is protected from status conditions.
Safeguard.gameDescription: The user creates a protective field that prevents status conditions for five turns.
Safeguard.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Sand Attack.name: Sand Attack
Sand Attack.effects: Sand Attack lowers the target's Accuracy by one stage. Although it is a Ground-type move it still affects raised Pokemon. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Sand Attack.changes: In Generation 1, Sand Attack is a Normal-type move. In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as Sand-Attack.
Sand Attack.gameDescription: Sand is hurled in the target’s face, reducing the target’s accuracy.

Sand Tomb.name: Sand Tomb
Sand Tomb.effects: Sand Tomb inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the opponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
Sand Tomb.changes: In Generations 1-4, Sand Tomb has a base power of 15 and 70% accuracy. Its after-effects also last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5.
Sand Tomb.gameDescription: The user traps the target inside a harshly raging sandstorm for four to five turns.
Sand Tomb.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Sandstorm.name: Sandstorm
Sandstorm.effects:
Sandstorm creates a sandstorm on the battlefield that lasts for 5 turns and induces these additional effects: 
All Pokemon except Rock, Ground and Steel types and those with the Sand Veil, Sand Rush or Sand Force abilities, lose 1⁄16 of their max HP at the end of each turn.
Pokemon with the Sand Veil ability increase their evasion by 20%.
Pokemon with the Sand Rush ability double their speed.
Pokemon with the Sand Force ability increase the power of Rock, Ground and Steel type moves by 30%.
From Generation 4 onward, the Special Defense of Rock-type Pokemon is increased by 50%.
The move Weather Ball changes to Rock type and doubles in power.
The power of SolarBeam decreases by 50%.
The moves Synthesis, Morning Sun and Moonlight recover 1⁄4 of the user's max HP (instead of the usual 1⁄2 HP).
Sandstorm.gameDescription: A five-turn sandstorm is summoned to hurt all combatants except the Rock, Ground, and Steel types. It raises the Sp. Def stat of Rock types.

Savage Spin-Out.name: Savage Spin-Out
Savage Spin-Out.effects: Savage Spin-Out is the Bug type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Savage Spin-Out.gameDescription: The user binds the target with full force with threads of silk that the user spits using its Z-Power. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Scald.name: Scald
Scald.effects: Scald deals damage and has a 30% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned. If the user is frozen, Scald can be used and will thaw out the Pokemon before attacking.
Scald.gameDescription: The user shoots boiling hot water at its target. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Scary Face.name: Scary Face
Scary Face.effects: Scary Face lowers the target's Speed by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Scary Face.changes: In Generations 1-4, Scary Face has 90% accuracy.
Scary Face.gameDescription: The user frightens the target with a scary face to harshly lower its Speed stat.

Scratch.name: Scratch
Scratch.effects: Scratch is one of the most common and basic moves a Pokémon learns. It deals damage with no additional effects.
Scratch.gameDescription: Hard, pointed, sharp claws rake the target to inflict damage.

Screech.name: Screech
Screech.effects: Screech lowers the target's Defense by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Screech.gameDescription: An earsplitting screech harshly lowers the target’s Defense stat.

Searing Shot.name: Searing Shot
Searing Shot.effects: Searing Shot deals damage and has a 30% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Searing Shot.gameDescription: The user torches everything around it in an inferno of scarlet flames. This may also leave those it hits with a burn.

Secret Power.name: Secret Power
Secret Power.effects:
Secret Power deals damage and has a 30% chance of inducing a secondary effect on the opponent, depending on the environment. The move's animation also changes, reusing that of a specific attack for each terrain. 

Location Effect Animation


Grass Sleep Needle Arm
Sand or regular terrain Accuracy reduced one stage Mud Slap
Caves or rocky terrain Flinching Rock Throw
Water Attack lowered one stage Water Pulse
Snow or ice Freezing Avalanche
Buildings Paralysis Body Slam
Secret Power.gameDescription: The additional effects of this attack depend upon where it was used.

Secret Sword.name: Secret Sword
Secret Sword.effects: Inflicts damage based on the target's Defense, not Special Defense.
Secret Sword.gameDescription: The user cuts with its long horn. The odd power contained in the horn does physical damage to the target.

Seed Bomb.name: Seed Bomb
Seed Bomb.effects: Seed Bomb deals damage with no additional effect.
Seed Bomb.gameDescription: The user slams a barrage of hard-shelled seeds down on the target from above.

Seed Flare.name: Seed Flare
Seed Flare.effects: Seed Flare deals damage and has a 40% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Seed Flare.gameDescription: The user emits a shock wave from its body to attack its target. This may also harshly lower the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Seismic Toss.name: Seismic Toss
Seismic Toss.effects: The damage of Seismic Toss is equal to the user's level. So at level 100 the Pokémon will inflict 100 HP damage.
Seismic Toss.changes: In Generation 1 Seismic Toss can hit Ghost-type Pokémon despite their immunity to Fighting-type attacks.
Seismic Toss.gameDescription: The target is thrown using the power of gravity. It inflicts damage equal to the user’s level.

Self-Destruct.name: Self-Destruct
Self-Destruct.effects: Self-Destruct deals high damage, but causes the user to faint.
Self-Destruct.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as Selfdestruct.
Self-Destruct.gameDescription: The user attacks everything around it by causing an explosion. The user faints upon using this move.

Shadow Ball.name: Shadow Ball
Shadow Ball.effects: Shadow Ball deals damage and has a 20% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Shadow Ball.gameDescription: The user hurls a shadowy blob at the target. This may also lower the target’s Sp. Def stat.

Shadow Bone.name: Shadow Bone
Shadow Bone.effects: The user attacks by beating the target with a bone that contains a spirit. This may also lower the target’s Defense stat.
Shadow Bone.gameDescription: The user attacks by beating the target with a bone that contains a spirit. This may also lower the target’s Defense stat.

Shadow Claw.name: Shadow Claw
Shadow Claw.effects: Shadow Claw deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Shadow Claw.gameDescription: The user slashes with a sharp claw made from shadows. Critical hits land more easily.

Shadow Force.name: Shadow Force
Shadow Force.effects: The user of Shadow Force will vanish instantly on the first turn, disappearing from view and becoming invulnerable to most attacks. On the second turn, Shadow Force deals damage and can hit Pokemon using Protect or Detect. It also removes their effect for the rest of the turn (in double and triple battles). While disappeared, the Pokemon can only be hit by moves from No Guard Pokemon, or any move following an identify move. If the user is holding a Power Herb, Shadow Force executes in one turn.
Shadow Force.gameDescription: The user disappears, then strikes the target on the next turn. This move hits even if the target protects itself.

Shadow Punch.name: Shadow Punch
Shadow Punch.effects: Shadow Punch deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Shadow Punch.gameDescription: The user throws a punch from the shadows. This attack never misses.

Shadow Sneak.name: Shadow Sneak
Shadow Sneak.effects: Shadow Sneak deals damage and has a priority of +1. Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
Shadow Sneak.gameDescription: The user extends its shadow and attacks the target from behind. This move always goes first.

Sharpen.name: Sharpen
Sharpen.effects: Sharpen raises the user's Attack by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Sharpen.gameDescription: The user makes its edges more jagged, which raises its Attack stat.

Shattered Psyche.name: Shattered Psyche
Shattered Psyche.effects: Shattered Psyche is the Psychic type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Shattered Psyche.gameDescription: The user controls the target with its Z-Power and hurts the target with full force. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Sheer Cold.name: Sheer Cold
Sheer Cold.effects:
If it hits, Sheer Cold is guaranteed to make the opponent faint. It is more likely to hit Pokémon that are of a lower level than the user. Its accuracy (as a percentage) is calculated as below, ignoring all other accuracy and evasion modifiers: UserLevel - TargetLevel + 30
 This means that Sheer Cold will fail against a target Pokémon at least 30 levels above the user.
Sheer Cold.gameDescription: The target faints instantly. It’s less likely to hit the target if it’s used by Pokémon other than Ice types.

Shell Smash.name: Shell Smash
Shell Smash.effects: Shell Smash lowers the user's Defense and Special Defense by one stage each, while also raising Attack, Special Attack and Speed by two stages each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each, or lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Shell Smash.gameDescription: The user breaks its shell, which lowers Defense and Sp. Def stats but sharply raises its Attack, Sp. Atk, and Speed stats.

Shell Trap.name: Shell Trap
Shell Trap.effects: Shell Trap sets a trap at the beginning of the turn, and if the user is hit by a physical move during the turn, it deals high damage to the opponent.
Shell Trap.gameDescription: The user sets a shell trap. If the user is hit by a physical move, the trap will explode and inflict damage on the opposing Pokémon.

Shift Gear.name: Shift Gear
Shift Gear.effects: Shift Gear raises the user's Attack by one stage and Speed by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Shift Gear.gameDescription: The user rotates its gears, raising its Attack stat and sharply raising its Speed stat.

Shock Wave.name: Shock Wave
Shock Wave.effects: Shock Wave deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Shock Wave.gameDescription: The user strikes the target with a quick jolt of electricity. This attack never misses.

Shore Up.name: Shore Up
Shore Up.effects: The user regains up to half of its max HP. It restores more HP in a sandstorm.
Shore Up.gameDescription: The user regains up to half of its max HP. It restores more HP in a sandstorm.

Signal Beam.name: Signal Beam
Signal Beam.effects: Signal Beam deals damage and has a 10% chance of confusing the target. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Signal Beam.gameDescription: The user attacks with a sinister beam of light. This may also confuse the target.

Silver Wind.name: Silver Wind
Silver Wind.effects: Silver Wind deals damage and has a 10% chance of raising the user's Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Silver Wind.gameDescription: The target is attacked with powdery scales blown by the wind. This may also raise all the user’s stats.

Simple Beam.name: Simple Beam
Simple Beam.effects: Simple Beam changes the target's ability to Simple. It does not cancel any ability's effects already felt (such as the Attack drop from Intimidate), but it does stop any further effects the ability may have (for example, damage from Rough Skin). It does not work on Pokemon with the abilities Truant or Multitype.
Simple Beam.gameDescription: The user’s mysterious psychic wave changes the target’s Ability to Simple.

Sing.name: Sing
Sing.effects: Sing puts the target to sleep, if it hits. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns. Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
Sing.gameDescription: A soothing lullaby is sung in a calming voice that puts the target into a deep slumber.

Sinister Arrow Raid.name: Sinister Arrow Raid
Sinister Arrow Raid.effects: Sinister Arrow Raid is a Ghost type Z-move exclusive to Decidueye. It is used with Decidueye's signature move Spirit Shackle.
Sinister Arrow Raid.gameDescription: The user, Decidueye, creates countless arrows using its Z-Power and shoots the target with full force.

Sketch.name: Sketch
Sketch.effects: Permanently copies the opponent's last move.
Sketch.gameDescription: It enables the user to permanently learn the move last used by the target. Once used, Sketch disappears.

Skill Swap.name: Skill Swap
Skill Swap.effects: The user swaps Abilities with the opponent.
Skill Swap.gameDescription: The user employs its psychic power to exchange Abilities with the target.

Skull Bash.name: Skull Bash
Skull Bash.effects: The user of Skull Bash will tuck in its head on the first turn and raise its Defense by one stage. On the second turn, Skull Bash deals damage. If the user is holding a Power Herb, Skull Bash executes in one turn.
Skull Bash.changes: In Generations 1-5, Skull Bash has base power 100 and 15 PP. In Generation 1, Skull Bash does not raise the user's Defense.
Skull Bash.gameDescription: The user tucks in its head to raise its Defense stat on the first turn, then rams the target on the next turn.

Sky Attack.name: Sky Attack
Sky Attack.effects: The user of Sky Attack will become cloaked in a harsh light on the first turn. On the second turn, Sky Attack deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch. If the user is holding a Power Herb, Sky Attack executes in one turn.
Sky Attack.gameDescription: A second-turn attack move where critical hits land more easily. This may also make the target flinch.
Sky Attack.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Sky Drop.name: Sky Drop
Sky Drop.effects: Sky Drop takes the target into the air on the first turn, then drops them on the second turn, wherein they receive damage. While in the air, neither Pokemon can be hit, except by Gust, Hurricane, Sky Uppercut, Smack Down, Thunder or Twister. Moves from No Guard Pokemon, or any move following an identify move can also hit. Sky Drop will appear to work on Flying-types and those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis, but will not cause them any damage. It fails if Gravity is in effect, the target is holding an Iron Ball, or is behind a Substitute. There is a glitch with Sky Drop in Black/White in double battles. If Gravity is put into effect while the Pokemon are in the air, the user of Sky Drop returns to the ground, but the target stays in the air and cannot attack or be hit (apart from the moves above). Due to this, it has been banned from Wi-Fi battles and all official Pokemon competitions.
Sky Drop.gameDescription: The user takes the target into the sky, then drops it during the next turn. The target cannot attack while in the sky.
Sky Drop.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Sky Uppercut.name: Sky Uppercut
Sky Uppercut.effects: Hits the opponent, even during Fly.
Sky Uppercut.gameDescription: The user attacks the target with an uppercut thrown skyward with force.

Slack Off.name: Slack Off
Slack Off.effects: Slack Off recovers up to 50% of the user's maximum HP.
Slack Off.gameDescription: The user slacks off, restoring its own HP by up to half of its max HP.

Slam.name: Slam
Slam.effects: Slam deals damage with no additional effect.
Slam.gameDescription: The target is slammed with a long tail, vines, or the like to inflict damage.

Slash.name: Slash
Slash.effects: Slash deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Slash.gameDescription: The target is attacked with a slash of claws or blades. Critical hits land more easily.

Sleep Powder.name: Sleep Powder
Sleep Powder.effects: Sleep Powder puts the target to sleep, if it hits. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns. Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
Sleep Powder.gameDescription: The user scatters a big cloud of sleep-inducing dust around the target.

Sleep Talk.name: Sleep Talk
Sleep Talk.effects: User performs one of its own moves while sleeping.
Sleep Talk.gameDescription: While it is asleep, the user randomly uses one of the moves it knows.

Sludge.name: Sludge
Sludge.effects: Sludge deals damage and has a 30% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Sludge.gameDescription: Unsanitary sludge is hurled at the target. This may also poison the target.

Sludge Bomb.name: Sludge Bomb
Sludge Bomb.effects: Sludge Bomb deals damage and has a 30% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Sludge Bomb.gameDescription: Unsanitary sludge is hurled at the target. This may also poison the target.

Sludge Wave.name: Sludge Wave
Sludge Wave.effects: Sludge Wave deals damage and has a 10% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Sludge Wave.gameDescription: The user strikes everything around it by swamping the area with a giant sludge wave. This may also poison those hit.

Smack Down.name: Smack Down
Smack Down.effects: Smack Down deals damage and knocks the target to the ground. Any raised Pokémon now become susceptible to Ground moves and Arena Trap. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary. Smack Down can hit Pokémon using Fly or Bounce and will bring them back down to the ground, thus cancelling the moves. It can also hit Pokémon using Sky Drop but does not knock them to the ground. It does not knock down Substitutes but deals damage to the Substitute as normal.
Smack Down.gameDescription: The user throws a stone or similar projectile to attack an opponent. A flying Pokémon will fall to the ground when it’s hit.

Smart Strike.name: Smart Strike
Smart Strike.effects: The user stabs the target with a sharp horn. This attack never misses.
Smart Strike.gameDescription: The user stabs the target with a sharp horn. This attack never misses.

Smelling Salts.name: Smelling Salts
Smelling Salts.effects: Smelling Salts deals damage, and hits with double power (140) if the target is paralyzed. However, it also cures the paralysis.
Smelling Salts.changes: In Generations 3-5, Smelling Salts has base power 60. In Generations 3-5, this move's name was formatted as SmellingSalt.
Smelling Salts.gameDescription: This attack’s power is doubled when used on a target with paralysis. This also cures the target’s paralysis, however.

Smog.name: Smog
Smog.effects: Smog deals damage and has a 40% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Smog.changes: In Generations 1-5, Smog has base power 20.
Smog.gameDescription: The target is attacked with a discharge of filthy gases. This may also poison the target.

Smokescreen.name: Smokescreen
Smokescreen.effects: Smokescreen lowers the target's Accuracy by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each. Pokémon with the abilities Keen Eye, Clear Body or White Smoke cannot have their accuracy reduced.
Smokescreen.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as SmokeScreen.
Smokescreen.gameDescription: The user releases an obscuring cloud of smoke or ink. This lowers the target’s accuracy.

Snarl.name: Snarl
Snarl.effects: Snarl deals damage and lowers the target's Special Attack by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Snarl.gameDescription: The user yells as if it’s ranting about something, which lowers the Sp. Atk stat of opposing Pokémon.

Snatch.name: Snatch
Snatch.effects:
Snatch moves first and steals the effects of the next status move used by the opponent(s) in that turn. If two or more Pokemon use Snatch, the slowest of the Pokemon will gain the effect, because the fastest Pokemon will steal the move first, then the next slowest will steal the move from the snatcher and so on. Moves that can be snatched: 
Stat boosts, for example Swords Dance or Belly Drum (exceptions below)
Protection moves, for example Substitute, Lucky Chant, Wide Guard or Quick Guard (exceptions below)
Recovery and healing moves, for example Recover, Ingrain or Heal Bell
Imprison
Other self-induced effects such as Magnet Rise, Power Trick or Light Screen
 Moves that cannot be snatched: 
Acupressure
Curse
Protect or Detect
Helping Hand
Taunt
Snatch.gameDescription: The user steals the effects of any attempts to use a healing or stat-changing move.

Snore.name: Snore
Snore.effects: Snore deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved).
