However, it can only be used while the user is asleep (either from a move like Hypnosis or self-induced via Rest). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Snore.changes: In Generations 2-5, Snore has base power 40.
Snore.gameDescription: This attack can be used only if the user is asleep. The harsh noise may also make the target flinch.

Soak.name: Soak
Soak.effects: Soak changes the target's type to Water. It does not work on Pokémon with the ability Multitype.
Soak.gameDescription: The user shoots a torrent of water at the target and changes the target’s type to Water.

Soft-Boiled.name: Soft-Boiled
Soft-Boiled.effects: Soft-Boiled recovers up to 50% of the user's maximum HP.
Soft-Boiled.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as Softboiled.
Soft-Boiled.gameDescription: The user restores its own HP by up to half of its max HP.

Solar Beam.name: Solar Beam
Solar Beam.effects: The user of Solar Beam will absorb light on the first turn. On the second turn, Solar Beam deals damage. During intense sunlight or when holding a Power Herb, Solar Beam executes in one turn. Its power decreases by 50% during rain, hail or a sandstorm.
Solar Beam.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as SolarBeam.
Solar Beam.gameDescription: In this two-turn attack, the user gathers light, then blasts a bundled beam on the next turn.

Solar Blade.name: Solar Blade
Solar Blade.effects: The user of Solar Blade will absorb light on the first turn. On the second turn, Solar Blade deals damage.
Solar Blade.gameDescription: In this two-turn attack, the user gathers light and fills a blade with the light’s energy, attacking the target on the next turn.

Sonic Boom.name: Sonic Boom
Sonic Boom.effects: Sonic Boom always deals 20 HP damage to the target, regardless of typing (although Ghost type Pokémon are still immune). It has no additional effect.
Sonic Boom.changes: In Generation 1, Sonic Boom hits Ghost types regardless of their immunity to Normal type moves. In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as SonicBoom.
Sonic Boom.gameDescription: The target is hit with a destructive shock wave that always inflicts 20 HP damage.

Soul-Stealing 7-Star Strike.name: Soul-Stealing 7-Star Strike
Soul-Stealing 7-Star Strike.effects: Soul-Stealing 7-Star Strike is a Ghost type Z-move exclusive to Marshadow. It is used with Marshadow's signature move Spectral Thief.
Soul-Stealing 7-Star Strike.gameDescription: After obtaining Z-Power, the user, Marshadow, punches and kicks the target consecutively with full force.

Spacial Rend.name: Spacial Rend
Spacial Rend.effects: Spacial Rend deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Spacial Rend.gameDescription: The user tears the target along with the space around it. Critical hits land more easily.

Spark.name: Spark
Spark.effects: Spark deals damage and has a 30% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Spark.gameDescription: The user throws an electrically charged tackle at the target. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Sparkling Aria.name: Sparkling Aria
Sparkling Aria.effects: Sparkling Aria deals damage, and if the target is burned, heals it.
Sparkling Aria.gameDescription: The user bursts into song, emitting many bubbles. Any Pokémon suffering from a burn will be healed by the touch of these bubbles.

Spectral Thief.name: Spectral Thief
Spectral Thief.effects: The user hides in the target’s shadow, steals the target’s stat boosts, and then attacks.
Spectral Thief.gameDescription: The user hides in the target’s shadow, steals the target’s stat boosts, and then attacks.

Speed Swap.name: Speed Swap
Speed Swap.effects: The user exchanges Speed stats with the target.
Speed Swap.gameDescription: The user exchanges Speed stats with the target.

Spider Web.name: Spider Web
Spider Web.gameDescription: The user ensnares the target with thin, gooey silk so it can’t flee from battle.

Spike Cannon.name: Spike Cannon
Spike Cannon.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 40
3 3⁄8 60
4 1⁄8 80
5 1⁄8 100

 Spike Cannon hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Spike Cannon is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Spike Cannon to always hit the maximum number of times.
Spike Cannon.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Spike Cannon ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
Spike Cannon.gameDescription: Sharp spikes are shot at the target in rapid succession. They hit two to five times in a row.

Spikes.name: Spikes
Spikes.effects:
Layers Damage


1 1⁄8
2 1⁄6
3 1⁄4

 Spikes lays a trap of spikes around the foe, which hurts Pokemon switching in to the opposing field. It can be used up to three times to inflict more damage on incoming Pokemon, equal to a fraction of the Pokemon's HP (see right). The move will not cause damage to any raised Pokemon. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary. Spikes can be cleared from the field by the moves Rapid Spin (around the user) or Defog (around the target).
Spikes.gameDescription: The user lays a trap of spikes at the opposing team’s feet. The trap hurts Pokémon that switch into battle.
Spikes.target: Targets all Pokemon on the opposing field.

Spiky Shield.name: Spiky Shield
Spiky Shield.effects: Spiky Shield prevents any attacks targeted at the user from striking on that turn. If a move that makes contact is targeted at the user on that turn, the attacker receives damage. Its accuracy drops to 50% if used consecutively after itself or any other protecting move.
Spiky Shield.gameDescription: In addition to protecting the user from attacks, this move also damages any attacker who makes direct contact.

Spirit Shackle.name: Spirit Shackle
Spirit Shackle.effects: Spirit Shackle deals damage and prevents the target from switching out, while the user remains in battle.
Spirit Shackle.gameDescription: The user attacks while simultaneously stitching the target’s shadow to the ground to prevent the target from escaping.

Spit Up.name: Spit Up
Spit Up.effects: Spit Up deals varying damage depending on how many times the user used Stockpile. The base power is 100, 200 or 300 if the user stockpiled one, two or three times respectively. Spit Up also removes the Defense and Special Defense boosts given through Stockpile.
Spit Up.gameDescription: The power stored using the move Stockpile is released at once in an attack. The more power is stored, the greater the move’s power.

Spite.name: Spite
Spite.effects: The opponent's last move loses 2-5 PP.
Spite.gameDescription: The user unleashes its grudge on the move last used by the target by cutting 4 PP from it.

Splash.name: Splash
Splash.gameDescription: The user just flops and splashes around to no effect at all...

Spore.name: Spore
Spore.effects: Spore puts the target to sleep. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns. Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
Spore.gameDescription: The user scatters bursts of spores that induce sleep.

Spotlight.name: Spotlight
Spotlight.effects: The user shines a spotlight on the target so that only the target will be attacked during the turn.
Spotlight.gameDescription: The user shines a spotlight on the target so that only the target will be attacked during the turn.

Stealth Rock.name: Stealth Rock
Stealth Rock.effects:
Defense Damage


1⁄4× 1⁄32 HP
1⁄2× 1⁄16 HP
1× 1⁄8 HP
2× 1⁄4 HP
4× 1⁄2 HP

 Stealth Rock lays a trap of stones around the foe, which hurts Pokemon switching in to the opposing field. The rocks inflicts variable damage - a fraction of the Pokemon's maximum HP, based on its susceptibility to the Rock type, as in the table to the right. For example, a Fighting type switching in would lose 1⁄16 their maximum HP since Rock is not very effective against it. A Fire/Flying type would lose 1⁄2 their HP since Rock is super-effective against both Fire and Flying. Stealth Rock can be cleared from the field by the moves Rapid Spin (around the user) or Defog (around the target).
Stealth Rock.gameDescription: The user lays a trap of levitating stones around the opposing team. The trap hurts opposing Pokémon that switch into battle.
Stealth Rock.target: Targets all Pokemon on the opposing field.

Steam Eruption.name: Steam Eruption
Steam Eruption.effects: Steam Eruption deals damage and has a 30% chance of burning the target. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Steam Eruption.gameDescription: The user immerses the target in superheated steam. This may also leave the target with a burn.

Steamroller.name: Steamroller
Steamroller.effects: Steamroller deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch. If the target has used Minimize, Steamroller's base power doubles to 130.
Steamroller.gameDescription: The user crushes its target by rolling over the target with its rolled-up body. This may also make the target flinch.

Steel Wing.name: Steel Wing
Steel Wing.effects: Steel Wing deals damage and has a 10% chance of raising the user's Defense by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Steel Wing.gameDescription: The target is hit with wings of steel. This may also raise the user’s Defense stat.

Sticky Web.name: Sticky Web
Sticky Web.effects: Sticky Web sets up a sticky net around the opposing team, which lowers the Speed of Pokémon switching into battle by one stage. Raised Pokémon switching in are not affected. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary.
Sticky Web.gameDescription: The user weaves a sticky net around the opposing team, which lowers their Speed stat upon switching into battle.
Sticky Web.target: Targets all Pokemon on the opposing field.

Stockpile.name: Stockpile
Stockpile.effects: Stockpile raises the user's Defense and Special Defense by one stage each and charges up power for use with companion moves Spit Up or Swallow. Stockpile can be used up to three times before its companion moves, which will attack or recover HP respectively. The power of Spit Up and HP gained from Swallow varies depending on how many times Stockpile was used. After one of those moves is used, the user loses the Defense and Special Defense boosts.
Stockpile.changes: In Generations 1-3, Stockpile has 10 PP and it does not increase Defense nor Special Defense.
Stockpile.gameDescription: The user charges up power and raises both its Defense and Sp. Def stats. The move can be used three times.

Stoked Sparksurfer.name: Stoked Sparksurfer
Stoked Sparksurfer.effects: Stoked Sparksurfer is an Electric type Z-Move exclusive to Alolan Raichu. It is used with Thunderbolt.
Stoked Sparksurfer.gameDescription: After obtaining Z-Power, the user, Alolan Raichu, attacks the target with full force. This move leaves the target with paralysis.

Stomp.name: Stomp
Stomp.effects: Stomp deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch. If the target has used Minimize, Stomp's base power doubles to 130.
Stomp.changes: In Generation 1, the Minimize effect did not occur.
Stomp.gameDescription: The target is stomped with a big foot. This may also make the target flinch.

Stomping Tantrum.name: Stomping Tantrum
Stomping Tantrum.effects: Driven by frustration, the user attacks the target. If the user’s previous move has failed, the power of this move doubles.
Stomping Tantrum.gameDescription: Driven by frustration, the user attacks the target. If the user’s previous move has failed, the power of this move doubles.

Stone Edge.name: Stone Edge
Stone Edge.effects: Stone Edge deals damage and has an increased critical hit ratio (1⁄8 instead of 1⁄16).
Stone Edge.gameDescription: The user stabs the target from below with sharpened stones. Critical hits land more easily.

Stored Power.name: Stored Power
Stored Power.effects:
Stored Power deals varying damage based on the user's stat increases. It starts at base power 20 and increases by 20 for each net stat boost the user has received, including Evasion and Accuracy. In other words the power is: 20 × NumIncreases + 20
 For example, if the Pokémon used Dragon Dance and Double Team once each, that is a total of 3 stat increases (+1 Attack, +1 Speed, +1 Evasion) and Stored Power's base power will be 20 × 3 + 20 = 80. The maximum it could reach (although impractical) if all stats are fully boosted is 20 × 6 × 7 + 20 = a massive 860 base power. (This does not include other boosts - here the Pokémon would have a +6 Special Attack boost meaning a 4× multiplier, plus STAB for most of the Pokémon that can learn Stored Power.)
Stored Power.gameDescription: The user attacks the target with stored power. The more the user’s stats are raised, the greater the move’s power.

Storm Throw.name: Storm Throw
Storm Throw.effects: Storm Throw deals damage and always results in a critical hit, increasing its power to 90. However, Pokemon with the abilities Battle Armor or Shell Armor, or those under the effect of Lucky Chant are immune to critical hits so Storm Throw will hit them with base power 60.
Storm Throw.changes: In Generation 5, Storm Throw has base power 40. Critical hits also increase power by 2× rather than 1.5× so the effective power is 80 with the critical hit.
Storm Throw.gameDescription: The user strikes the target with a fierce blow. This attack always results in a critical hit.

Strength.name: Strength
Strength.effects: Strength deals damage with no additional effect in battle.

Strength Sap.name: Strength Sap
Strength Sap.effects: The user restores its HP by the same amount as the target’s Attack stat. It also lowers the target’s Attack stat.
Strength Sap.gameDescription: The user restores its HP by the same amount as the target’s Attack stat. It also lowers the target’s Attack stat.

String Shot.name: String Shot
String Shot.effects: String Shot lowers the target's Speed by two stages. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
String Shot.changes: In Generations 1-5, String Shot lowers Speed by one stage.
String Shot.gameDescription: The opposing Pokémon are bound with silk blown from the user’s mouth that harshly lowers the Speed stat.

Struggle.name: Struggle
Struggle.effects: Only usable when all PP are gone. Hurts the user.
Struggle.gameDescription: This attack is used in desperation only if the user has no PP. It also damages the user a little.

Struggle Bug.name: Struggle Bug
Struggle Bug.effects: Struggle Bug deals damage and lowers the target's Special Attack by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Struggle Bug.changes: In Generation 5, Struggle Bug has base power 30.
Struggle Bug.gameDescription: While resisting, the user attacks the opposing Pokémon. This lowers the Sp. Atk stat of those hit.

Stun Spore.name: Stun Spore
Stun Spore.effects: Stun Spore paralyzes the target, if it hits. Paralyzed Pokémon have a 25% chance of not being able to attack, and their Speed is decreased by 75%. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Stun Spore.gameDescription: The user scatters a cloud of numbing powder that paralyzes the target.

Submission.name: Submission
Submission.effects: Submission deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄4 of the damage it inflicts in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 100 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 25 HP.
Submission.gameDescription: The user grabs the target and recklessly dives for the ground. This also damages the user a little.

Substitute.name: Substitute
Substitute.effects: Uses HP to creates a decoy that takes hits.
Substitute.gameDescription: The user makes a copy of itself using some of its HP. The copy serves as the user’s decoy.

Subzero Slammer.name: Subzero Slammer
Subzero Slammer.effects: Subzero Slammer is the Ice type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Subzero Slammer.gameDescription: The user dramatically drops the temperature using its Z-Power and freezes the target with full force. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Sucker Punch.name: Sucker Punch
Sucker Punch.effects: Sucker Punch deals damage and has a priority of +1. However, the move only works if the target uses a direct attack in the same turn. If the target is not preparing an attack, Sucker Punch will fail. Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
Sucker Punch.changes: In Generations 4-6, Sucker Punch has base power 80.
Sucker Punch.gameDescription: This move enables the user to attack first. This move fails if the target is not readying an attack.

Sunny Day.name: Sunny Day
Sunny Day.effects:
Sunny Day causes bright sunlight that lasts for 5 turns, and induces these additional effects: 
The power of Fire-type moves increases by 50%.
The power of Water-type moves decreases by 50%.
The accuracy of Thunder and Hurricane lowers to 50%.
SolarBeam does not require the charging turn, thus attacks straight away.
Pokemon with the ability Dry Skin lose 1⁄8 of their max HP each turn.
Pokemon with the ability Chlorophyll double their speed.
The move Weather Ball changes to Fire type and doubles in power.
The moves Synthesis, Morning Sun and Moonlight recover 2⁄3 of the user's max HP (instead of the usual 1⁄2 HP).
Sunny Day.gameDescription: The user intensifies the sun for five turns, powering up Fire-type moves. It lowers the power of Water-type moves.

Sunsteel Strike.name: Sunsteel Strike
Sunsteel Strike.gameDescription: The user slams into the target with the force of a meteor. This move can be used on the target regardless of its Abilities.

Super Fang.name: Super Fang
Super Fang.effects: Always takes off half of the opponent's HP.
Super Fang.gameDescription: The user chomps hard on the target with its sharp front fangs. This cuts the target’s HP in half.

Superpower.name: Superpower
Superpower.effects: Superpower deals damage but lowers the user's Attack and Defense by one stage each after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Superpower.gameDescription: The user attacks the target with great power. However, this also lowers the user’s Attack and Defense stats.

Supersonic.name: Supersonic
Supersonic.effects: Supersonic causes the target to become confused. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused. Soundproof also prevents this move.
Supersonic.gameDescription: The user generates odd sound waves from its body that confuse the target.

Supersonic Skystrike.name: Supersonic Skystrike
Supersonic Skystrike.effects: Supersonic Skystrike is the Flying type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Supersonic Skystrike.gameDescription: The user soars up with its Z-Power and plummets toward the target at full speed. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Surf.name: Surf
Surf.effects: Surf deals damage. In double battles it will hit all Pokémon on the field; in triple battles it will hit all adjacent Pokémon. If the opponent is hidden underwater from using Dive, Surf will hit with double power.
Surf.changes: In Generations 1-5, Surf has base power 95.
Surf.gameDescription: The user attacks everything around it by swamping its surroundings with a giant wave.

Swagger.name: Swagger
Swagger.effects: Swagger confuses the target and raises its Attack by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Swagger.gameDescription: The user enrages and confuses the target. However, this also sharply raises the target’s Attack stat.

Swallow.name: Swallow
Swallow.effects: Swallow recovers a varying amount of HP depending on how many times the user has used Stockpile. It recovers 25%, 50% or 100% of the user's maximum HP if the user stockpiled one, two or three times respectively. Swallow also removes the Defense and Special Defense boosts given through Stockpile.
Swallow.gameDescription: The power stored using the move Stockpile is absorbed by the user to heal its HP. Storing more power heals more HP.

Sweet Kiss.name: Sweet Kiss
Sweet Kiss.effects: Sweet Kiss causes the target to become confused. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Sweet Kiss.changes: Prior to Generation 6, Sweet Kiss is a Normal type move.
Sweet Kiss.gameDescription: The user kisses the target with a sweet, angelic cuteness that causes confusion.

Sweet Scent.name: Sweet Scent
Sweet Scent.effects: Sweet Scent lowers the target's Evasion by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Sweet Scent.gameDescription: A sweet scent that harshly lowers opposing Pokémon’s evasiveness.

Swift.name: Swift
Swift.effects: Swift deals damage and ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Swift.changes: In Generation 1, Swift can hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stage of Dig and Fly.
Swift.gameDescription: Star-shaped rays are shot at the opposing Pokémon. This attack never misses.

Switcheroo.name: Switcheroo
Switcheroo.effects: Switcheroo switches held items with the target. It does not require both Pokémon to be holding an item, in which case the item is simply given to the target or received from it. Switching items with wild Pokémon is permanent (received items are kept, given items are lost). All held items in Trainer battles and wi-fi/linked battles (including Battle Tower/Subway/Maison) are returned to their respective owners at the end of a battle. Pokemon with the ability Sticky Hold cannot have their held item removed. The Griseous Orb cannot be removed from Giratina; Type Plates cannot be removed from Arceus; Drives cannot be removed from Genesect; and Mega Stones cannot be removed from their respective Pokémon.
Switcheroo.changes: In Generation 4, switching items with a Trainer's Pokémon is also permanent, but Switcheroo will fail if used by a wild Pokémon or a Trainer's Pokémon.
Switcheroo.gameDescription: The user trades held items with the target faster than the eye can follow.

Swords Dance.name: Swords Dance
Swords Dance.effects: Swords Dance raises the user's Attack by two stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Swords Dance.changes: In Generations 1-5, Swords Dance has 30 PP.
Swords Dance.gameDescription: A frenetic dance to uplift the fighting spirit. This sharply raises the user’s Attack stat.

Synchronoise.name: Synchronoise
Synchronoise.effects: Synchronoise hits all adjacent Pokémon that share a type with the user. Dual type Pokémon match either of their types, so for example a Normal/Flying Pokémon using Synchronoise will hit a Flying/Dragon type.
Synchronoise.changes: In Generation 5, Synchronoise has base power 70.
Synchronoise.gameDescription: Using an odd shock wave, the user inflicts damage on any Pokémon of the same type in the area around it.

Synthesis.name: Synthesis
Synthesis.effects: User recovers HP. Amount varies with the weather.
Synthesis.gameDescription: The user restores its own HP. The amount of HP regained varies with the weather.

Tackle.name: Tackle
Tackle.effects: Tackle is one of the most common and basic moves a Pokémon learns. It deals damage with no additional effects.
Tackle.changes: In Generations 1-4, Tackle has a base power of 35 and 95% accuracy. In Generations 5-6, Tackle has a base power of 50.
Tackle.gameDescription: A physical attack in which the user charges and slams into the target with its whole body.

Tail Glow.name: Tail Glow
Tail Glow.effects: Tail Glow raises the user's Special Attack by three stages. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each. Assuming no other stat changes, the first use of Tail Glow would raise Special Attack to 2.5× normal value, and the second to 4× (the maximum level).
Tail Glow.changes: In Generations 3-4, Tail Glow increases Special Attack by two stages.
Tail Glow.gameDescription: The user stares at flashing lights to focus its mind, drastically raising its Sp. Atk stat.

Tail Slap.name: Tail Slap
Tail Slap.effects:
Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 50
3 3⁄8 75
4 1⁄8 100
5 1⁄8 125

 Tail Slap hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Tail Slap is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Tail Slap to always hit the maximum number of times.
Tail Slap.gameDescription: The user attacks by striking the target with its hard tail. It hits the target two to five times in a row.

Tail Whip.name: Tail Whip
Tail Whip.effects: Tail Whip lowers the target's Defense by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Tail Whip.gameDescription: The user wags its tail cutely, making opposing Pokémon less wary and lowering their Defense stat.

Tailwind.name: Tailwind
Tailwind.effects: Tailwind doubles the speed of all Pokémon in the user's party for 4 turns.
Tailwind.changes: In Generations 1-4, Tailwind lasts 3 turns instead of 4.
Tailwind.gameDescription: The user whips up a turbulent whirlwind that ups the Speed stat of the user and its allies for four turns.
Tailwind.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Take Down.name: Take Down
Take Down.effects: Take Down deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄4 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 100 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 25 HP.
Take Down.gameDescription: A reckless, full-body charge attack for slamming into the target. This also damages the user a little.

Taunt.name: Taunt
Taunt.effects: Opponent can only use moves that attack.
Taunt.gameDescription: The target is taunted into a rage that allows it to use only attack moves for three turns.

Tearful Look.name: Tearful Look
Tearful Look.effects: The user gets teary eyed to make the target lose its combative spirit. This lowers the target’s Attack and Sp. Atk stats.
Tearful Look.gameDescription: The user gets teary eyed to make the target lose its combative spirit. This lowers the target’s Attack and Sp. Atk stats.

Techno Blast.name: Techno Blast
Techno Blast.effects:
Techno Blast deals damage. Its type changes depending on the held Drive: 
Normal type if no Drive is held.
Fire type if Burn Drive is held.
Ice type if Chill Drive is held.
Water type if Douse Drive is held.
Electric type if Shock Drive is held.
 Techno Blast is the signature move of Genesect.
Techno Blast.gameDescription: The user fires a beam of light at its target. The move’s type changes depending on the Drive the user holds.

Tectonic Rage.name: Tectonic Rage
Tectonic Rage.effects: Tectonic Rage is the Ground type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Tectonic Rage.gameDescription: The user burrows deep into the ground and slams into the target with the full force of its Z-Power. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Teeter Dance.name: Teeter Dance
Teeter Dance.effects: Teeter Dance causes all adjacent Pokémon to become confused. In single battles this is simply the opponent; in double/triple battles it includes all adjacent opponents and teammate(s). Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Teeter Dance.gameDescription: The user performs a wobbly dance that confuses the Pokémon around it.

Telekinesis.name: Telekinesis
Telekinesis.effects: Telekinesis raises the target into the air for three turns, guaranteeing that all attacks against the target (except OHKO moves) will hit, regardless of Accuracy or Evasion. The target gains the usual benefits of being raised, e.g. immunity to Ground-type moves. More details, including when Telekinesis can't be used, are in the glossary. The effect is cancelled if the raised Pokemon is hit by Smack Down.
Telekinesis.gameDescription: The user makes the target float with its psychic power. The target is easier to hit for three turns.

Teleport.name: Teleport
Teleport.effects: Teleport will always fail in a Trainer battle. In battles with wild Pokémon, Teleport allows the user to flee battles. Teleport also fails in wild battles if the user would normally be unable to flee due to a trapping move (e.g. Fire Spin) or ability (e.g. Arena Trap.
Teleport.gameDescription: Use it to flee from any wild Pokémon.

Thief.name: Thief
Thief.effects: Thief deals damage and steals the target's held item, if the user is not holding an item. Items stolen from wild Pokémon are kept after the battle ends, but items stolen from a Trainer's Pokémon are not. Items stolen from the player's Pokémon either by wild Pokémon or Trainer Pokémon are returned at the end of the battle. All held items in wi-fi/linked battles (including Battle Tower/Subway/Maison) are returned to their respective owners at the end of a battle. If the item would activate on attack (e.g. Focus Band), it does so before being stolen. If the item is consumable on attack (e.g. Focus Sash) then the item is consumed as normal and cannot be stolen. Pokemon with the ability Sticky Hold cannot have their held item removed. The Griseous Orb cannot be removed from Giratina; Type Plates cannot be removed from Arceus; Drives cannot be removed from Genesect; and Mega Stones cannot be removed from their respective Pokémon.
Thief.changes: In Generations 2-5, Thief has base power 40 and 10 PP. In Generations 2-4, Thief steals a Trainer Pokémon's item permanently, but a wild Pokémon or a Trainer's Pokémon using Thief will not steal the player's item at all.
Thief.gameDescription: The user attacks and steals the target’s held item simultaneously. The user can’t steal anything if it already holds an item.

Thousand Arrows.name: Thousand Arrows
Thousand Arrows.effects: Thousand Arrows deals damage and knocks the target to the ground. Any raised Pokémon now become susceptible to Ground moves and Arena Trap. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary. Thousand Arrows can hit Pokémon using Fly or Bounce and will bring them back down to the ground, thus cancelling the moves. It can also hit Pokémon using Sky Drop but does not knock them to the ground. It does not knock down Substitutes but deals damage to the Substitute as normal.
Thousand Arrows.gameDescription: This move also hits opposing Pokémon that are in the air. Those Pokémon are knocked down to the ground.

Thousand Waves.name: Thousand Waves
Thousand Waves.effects: Thousand Waves deals damage and prevents the target from fleeing or switching out, as long as the user remains in battle.
Thousand Waves.gameDescription: The user attacks with a wave that crawls along the ground. Those hit can’t flee from battle.

Thrash.name: Thrash
Thrash.effects: The user of Thrash attacks for 2-3 turns, during which it cannot switch out, and then becomes confused. Confused Pokémon have a 50% chance of hurting themselves each turn, for 1-4 turns. The damage received is as if the Pokémon attacks itself with a typeless 40 base power Physical attack. If Thrash is disrupted (e.g. if the move misses or the user cannot attack due to paralysis) then it will stop and not cause confusion. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Thrash.changes: In Generations 1-4, Thrash has 20 PP and a base power of 90. Furthermore, sleep, freezing and flinching will pause but not disrupt Thrash. In Generation 1, Thrash lasts for 3-4 turns.
Thrash.gameDescription: The user rampages and attacks for two to three turns. The user then becomes confused.
Thrash.target: Targets the user, but hits a random adjacent opponent.

Throat Chop.name: Throat Chop
Throat Chop.effects: Throat Chop deals damage and prevents the target from using sound-based moves such as Hyper Voice for two turns.
Throat Chop.gameDescription: The user attacks the target’s throat, and the resultant suffering prevents the target from using moves that emit sound for two turns.

Thunder.name: Thunder
Thunder.effects: Thunder deals damage and has a 30% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed. If used during rain, its accuracy rises to 100%. Conversely, if used during intense sunlight, its accuracy drops to 50%. Thunder can hit Pokemon using Fly and Bounce, the latter dealing double damage.
Thunder.changes: In Generations 1-5, Thunder has base power 120. In Diamond/Pearl only, Thunder has a 30% chance of breaking through Protect or Detect during rain. In Generation 1, the chance of paralysis is 10%.
Thunder.gameDescription: A wicked thunderbolt is dropped on the target to inflict damage. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Thunder Fang.name: Thunder Fang
Thunder Fang.effects: Thunder Fang deals damage, has a 10% chance of paralyzing the target, and has a 10% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed. Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Thunder Fang.gameDescription: The user bites with electrified fangs. This may also make the target flinch or leave it with paralysis.

Thunder Punch.name: Thunder Punch
Thunder Punch.effects: Thunder Punch deals damage and has a 10% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Thunder Punch.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as ThunderPunch.
Thunder Punch.gameDescription: The target is punched with an electrified fist. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Thunder Shock.name: Thunder Shock
Thunder Shock.effects: Thunder Shock deals damage and has a 10% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Thunder Shock.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as ThunderShock.
Thunder Shock.gameDescription: A jolt of electricity crashes down on the target to inflict damage. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Thunder Wave.name: Thunder Wave
Thunder Wave.effects: Thunder Wave paralyzes the opponent. Paralyzed Pokémon have a 25% chance of not being able to attack, and their Speed is decreased by 75%. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Thunder Wave.changes: In Generations 1-6, Thunder Wave has 100% accuracy.
Thunder Wave.gameDescription: The user launches a weak jolt of electricity that paralyzes the target.

Thunderbolt.name: Thunderbolt
Thunderbolt.effects: Thunderbolt deals damage and has a 10% chance of paralyzing the target. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Thunderbolt.changes: In Generations 1-5, Thunderbolt has base power 95.
Thunderbolt.gameDescription: A strong electric blast crashes down on the target. This may also leave the target with paralysis.

Tickle.name: Tickle
Tickle.effects: Tickle lowers the target's Attack and Defense by one stage each. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Tickle.gameDescription: The user tickles the target into laughing, reducing its Attack and Defense stats.

Topsy-Turvy.name: Topsy-Turvy
Topsy-Turvy.effects: Topsy-Turvy reverses the stat changes of the target Pokémon. For example, if the target has boosted their attack by 2 stages using Swords Dance, Topsy-Turvy will reduce their Attack down to -2 stages. Similarly, if the opponent has used Draco Meteor (lowering their Special Attack), Topsy-Turvy will raise their Special Attack to +1 stage.
Topsy-Turvy.gameDescription: All stat changes affecting the target turn topsy-turvy and become the opposite of what they were.

Torment.name: Torment
Torment.effects: Opponent cannot use the same move in a row.
Torment.gameDescription: The user torments and enrages the target, making it incapable of using the same move twice in a row.

Toxic.name: Toxic
Toxic.effects: Toxic causes the target to be badly poisoned. Pokémon that are badly poisoned will lose an increasing amount of HP at the end of each turn. The affected Pokémon will lose 1⁄16 of its maximum HP at the end of the first turn, which then increases by 1⁄16 each turn. In other words, they lose 1⁄16, 2⁄16, 3⁄16, 4⁄16 and so on. Toxic doesn't affect Pokémon already carrying a major status ailment, Pokémon behind a Substitute nor Poison- or Steel-type Pokémon.
Toxic.changes: In Generations 1-4, Toxic has 85% accuracy. In Generation 1, Toxic also increases the damage taken by Leech Seed.
Toxic.gameDescription: A move that leaves the target badly poisoned. Its poison damage worsens every turn.

Toxic Spikes.name: Toxic Spikes
Toxic Spikes.effects: Toxic Spikes lays a trap of poisonous spikes around the foe, which poison Pokémon switching in to the opposing field. If used more than once, incoming Pokémon will be badly poisoned. The spikes will not poison any raised Pokémon, nor does it affect Poison or Steel types, nor Pokémon with the abilities Immunity or Magic Guard. Raised Pokémon are any Flying types or those under the effects of Levitate, Magnet Rise or Telekinesis. Full details in glossary. Toxic Spikes can be cleared from the field by the moves Rapid Spin (around the user) or Defog (around the target). Poison type Pokémon (that are not raised) will absorb the spikes upon switching in, removing their effect.
Toxic Spikes.gameDescription: The user lays a trap of poison spikes at the feet of the opposing team. The spikes will poison opposing Pokémon that switch into battle.
Toxic Spikes.target: Targets all Pokemon on the opposing field.

Toxic Thread.name: Toxic Thread
Toxic Thread.effects: The user shoots poisonous threads to poison the target and lower the target’s Speed stat.
Toxic Thread.gameDescription: The user shoots poisonous threads to poison the target and lower the target’s Speed stat.

Transform.name: Transform
Transform.effects: User takes on the form and attacks of the opponent.
Transform.gameDescription: The user transforms into a copy of the target right down to having the same move set.

Tri Attack.name: Tri Attack
Tri Attack.effects: Tri Attack deals damage and has a 20% chance of paralyzing, burning or freezing the target - i.e. a 6.67% chance of each status condition. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed. Ice type Pokémon, those with the ability Magma Armor or those behind a Substitute cannot be frozen.
Tri Attack.gameDescription: The user strikes with a simultaneous three-beam attack. May also burn, freeze, or paralyze the target.

Trick.name: Trick
Trick.effects: Trick switches held items with the target. It does not require both Pokémon to be holding an item, in which case the item is simply given to the target or received from it. Switching items with wild Pokémon is permanent (received items are kept, given items are lost). All held items in Trainer battles and wi-fi/linked battles (including Battle Tower/Subway/Maison) are returned to their respective owners at the end of a battle. Pokemon with the ability Sticky Hold cannot have their held item removed. The Griseous Orb cannot be removed from Giratina; Type Plates cannot be removed from Arceus; Drives cannot be removed from Genesect; and Mega Stones cannot be removed from their respective Pokémon.
Trick.changes: In Generations 3-4, switching items with a Trainer's Pokémon is also permanent, but Trick will fail if used by a wild Pokémon or a Trainer's Pokémon.
Trick.gameDescription: The user catches the target off guard and swaps its held item with its own.

Trick Room.name: Trick Room
Trick Room.effects: Slower Pokémon move first in the turn for 5 turns.
Trick Room.gameDescription: The user creates a bizarre area in which slower Pokémon get to move first for five turns.

Trick-or-Treat.name: Trick-or-Treat
Trick-or-Treat.effects: Trick-or-Treat adds the Ghost type to the target. If the target is dual-typed they essentially become a triple-typed Pokémon. It fails if one of the Pokémon's types is already Ghost. If the target is under the effect of Forest's Curse the Grass type is replaced by Ghost.
Trick-or-Treat.gameDescription: The user takes the target trick-or-treating. This adds Ghost type to the target’s type.

Triple Kick.name: Triple Kick
Triple Kick.effects:
Triple Kick deals damage and will strike three times, with each kick's base power increasing by 10. In other words the blows will be base power 10, 20 and 30 - a total of 60. Each hit has its own accuracy check, and if one kick misses, the move ends. Therefore, the chances of it being successful for each number of hits (with normal Accuracy/Evasion) are 90%, 81% and 73% respectively. Each strike of Triple Kick is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
Triple Kick.changes: In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Band or Focus Sash activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 2-3, Triple Kick ends if the first hit breaks a Substitute.
Triple Kick.gameDescription: A consecutive three-kick attack that becomes more powerful with each successive hit.

Trop Kick.name: Trop Kick
Trop Kick.effects: Trop Kick deals damage and lowers the target's Attack by one stage. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
Trop Kick.gameDescription: The user lands an intense kick of tropical origins on the target. This also lowers the target’s Attack stat.

Trump Card.name: Trump Card
Trump Card.effects:
PP left Power


≥ 4 40
3 50
2 60
1 80
0 200

 Trump Card inflicts more damage when fewer PP are left, as per the table to the right. The power is calculated based on the PP remaining after the move has been used; this is to account for the ability Pressure which deducts 2 PP for each move. If Trump Card is selected via a different move such as Metronome or Sleep Talk, it uses the PP of that move to determine the power.
Trump Card.gameDescription: The fewer PP this move has, the greater its power.

Twineedle.name: Twineedle
Twineedle.effects:
Twineedle deals damage and will strike twice (with 25 base power each time). It has a 20% chance of poisoning the target. Poison or Steel type Pokémon, those with the ability Immunity or those behind a Substitute cannot be poisoned.
Each strike of Twineedle is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage.
Twineedle.changes:
In Generations 1-2, Twineedle can poison Poison and Steel types.
In Generations 2-4, if a Focus Sash or Focus Band activates before the final hit, subsequent hits do not cause the holder to faint. In Generations 1-3, Twineedle ends immediately if any hit breaks a Substitute. In Generation 1, each hit will always deal the same damage - if the first critical hits, so will the rest.
Twineedle.gameDescription: The user damages the target twice in succession by jabbing it with two spikes. This may also poison the target.

Twinkle Tackle.name: Twinkle Tackle
Twinkle Tackle.effects: Twinkle Tackle is the Fairy type Z-Move, introduced in Pokémon Sun/Moon.
Twinkle Tackle.gameDescription: The user creates a very charming space using its Z-Power and totally toys with the target. The power varies, depending on the original move.

Twister.name: Twister
Twister.effects: Twister deals damage and has a 30% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch. Twister can hit Pokémon during the invulnerable stages of Bounce, Fly and Sky Drop - and in the case of Bounce and Fly, inflicts double damage.
Twister.gameDescription: The user whips up a vicious tornado to tear at the opposing Pokémon. This may also make them flinch.

U-turn.name: U-turn
U-turn.effects: User switches out immediately after attacking.
U-turn.gameDescription: After making its attack, the user rushes back to switch places with a party Pokémon in waiting.

Uproar.name: Uproar
Uproar.effects: Uproar inflicts damage for 3 turns. During this time, no Pokémon on the field will be able to sleep, and any sleeping Pokémon will be woken up.
Uproar.changes: In Generations 1-4, Uproar has a base power of 50 and lasts 2-5 turns.
Uproar.gameDescription: The user attacks in an uproar for three turns. During that time, no Pokémon can fall asleep.
Uproar.target: Targets the user, but hits a random adjacent opponent.

V-create.name: V-create
V-create.effects: V-create deals damage but lowers the user's Defense, Special Defense and Speed by one stage each after attacking. Stats can be lowered to a minimum of -6 stages each.
V-create.gameDescription: With a hot flame on its forehead, the user hurls itself at its target. This lowers the user’s Defense, Sp. Def, and Speed stats.

Vacuum Wave.name: Vacuum Wave
Vacuum Wave.effects: Vacuum Wave deals damage and has a priority of +1. Moves with a higher priority always go first, regardless of a Pokémon's speed. If two moves with the same priority are used, the faster Pokémon goes first as usual.
Vacuum Wave.gameDescription: The user whirls its fists to send a wave of pure vacuum at the target. This move always goes first.

Venom Drench.name: Venom Drench
Venom Drench.effects: If the target is poisoned, Venom Drench lowers its Attack, Special Attack and Speed by one stage each.
Venom Drench.gameDescription: Opposing Pokémon are drenched in an odd poisonous liquid. This lowers the Attack, Sp. Atk, and Speed stats of a poisoned target.

Venoshock.name: Venoshock
Venoshock.effects: Inflicts double damage if the target is poisoned.
Venoshock.gameDescription: The user drenches the target in a special poisonous liquid. This move’s power is doubled if the target is poisoned.

Vice Grip.name: Vice Grip
Vice Grip.effects: Vice Grip deals damage with no additional effect.
Vice Grip.changes: In Generations 1-5, this move's name was formatted as ViceGrip.
Vice Grip.gameDescription: The target is gripped and squeezed from both sides to inflict damage.

Vine Whip.name: Vine Whip
Vine Whip.effects: Vine Whip deals damage with no additional effect.
Vine Whip.changes: In Generations 1-5, Vine Whip has base power 35. Vine Whip has 15 PP in Generations 4-5 and 10 PP in Generations 1-3.
Vine Whip.gameDescription: The target is struck with slender, whiplike vines to inflict damage.

Vital Throw.name: Vital Throw
Vital Throw.effects: Vital Throw deals damage with lower priority, so most attacks will take place before it. Vital Throw ignores changes to the Accuracy and Evasion stats. However, it will not hit Pokemon during the invulnerable stage of Bounce, Dig, Dive, Fly, Shadow Force or Sky Drop.
Vital Throw.gameDescription: The user attacks last. In return, this throw move never misses.

Volt Switch.name: Volt Switch
Volt Switch.effects: User must switch out after attacking.
Volt Switch.gameDescription: After making its attack, the user rushes back to switch places with a party Pokémon in waiting.

Volt Tackle.name: Volt Tackle
Volt Tackle.effects: Volt Tackle deals damage and has a 10% chance of paralyzing the target, but the user receives 1⁄3 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 90 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 30 HP.
Volt Tackle.gameDescription: The user electrifies itself and charges the target. This also damages the user quite a lot. This attack may leave the target with paralysis.

Wake-Up Slap.name: Wake-Up Slap
Wake-Up Slap.effects: Wake-Up Slap deals damage, and hits with double power (140) if the target is asleep. However, it also wakes up the target.
Wake-Up Slap.changes: In Generations 4-5, Wake-Up Slap has base power 60.
Wake-Up Slap.gameDescription: This attack inflicts big damage on a sleeping target. This also wakes the target up, however.

Water Gun.name: Water Gun
Water Gun.effects: Water Gun deals damage with no additional effect.
Water Gun.gameDescription: The target is blasted with a forceful shot of water.

Water Pledge.name: Water Pledge
Water Pledge.effects: Water Pledge deals damage at base power 80. If a teammate uses Grass Pledge or Fire Pledge in the same turn, the moves combine into one attack of base power 160 and added effects appear. The faster Pokemon moves first but waits for the other Pokemon to make their move. When the slower Pledge user moves, the combo attack hits the Pokemon the slower user was targeting. If Water Pledge is used with Grass Pledge, the move animation shows Grass Pledge and a swamp envelops the foe's team that halves the opponents' speed for 4 turns. If Water Pledge is used with Fire Pledge, the move animation shows Water Pledge and a rainbow appears in the sky on your team's side that doubles the chance of moves' secondary effects occurring for 4 turns.
Water Pledge.changes: In Generation 5, Water Pledge has base power 50.
Water Pledge.gameDescription: A column of water strikes the target. When combined with its fire equivalent, its power increases and a rainbow appears.

Water Pulse.name: Water Pulse
Water Pulse.effects: Water Pulse deals damage and has a 20% chance of confusing the target. Pokémon with the ability Own Tempo or those behind a Substitute cannot be confused.
Water Pulse.gameDescription: The user attacks the target with a pulsing blast of water. This may also confuse the target.
Water Pulse.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Water Shuriken.name: Water Shuriken
Water Shuriken.effects:
Water Shuriken attacks with increased priority. 

 Hits Prob. Power


2 3⁄8 30
3 3⁄8 45
4 1⁄8 60
5 1⁄8 75

 Water Shuriken hits 2-5 times per turn used. The probability of each interval is shown to the right, with the total power after each hit. Each strike of Water Shuriken is treated like a separate attack: 
Each strike can get a critical hit independently.
Abilities that activate on contact (Static, Weak Armor, Iron Barbs etc.) activate for each strike.
If the Sturdy ability, Focus Sash, or Focus Band activates before the final hit, the subsequent hit will still deal damage and therefore cause the opponent to faint.
If the first hit breaks a Substitute, the second hit will deal damage to the target Pokémon.
 The move Counter only counters the final hit, but Bide counters the complete damage. The Skill Link ability will cause Water Shuriken to always hit the maximum number of times. If Battle Bond is active, Water Shuriken always hits 3 times, each with 20 base power.
Water Shuriken.changes: In Generation 6, Water Shuriken is a Physical move.
Water Shuriken.gameDescription: The user hits the target with throwing stars two to five times in a row. This move always goes first.

Water Sport.name: Water Sport
Water Sport.effects: Water Sport reduces the power of Fire-type moves by 50%. The effect applies to the entire field. Most Pokémon that learn Water Sport are part Water type and thus already resistant to Fire attacks.
Water Sport.gameDescription: The user soaks the battlefield with water. This weakens Fire-type moves for five turns.

Water Spout.name: Water Spout
Water Spout.effects:
Water Spout inflicts more damage when the user's HP is higher. At full HP its base power is 150 and it decreases in proportion - i.e. the power is: 150 × CurrentHP ÷ MaxHP
 Water Spout is a counterpart move to Eruption. It is also similar to Crush Grip and Wring Out, based on the user rather than the opponent.
Water Spout.gameDescription: The user spouts water to damage opposing Pokémon. The lower the user’s HP, the lower the move’s power.

Waterfall.name: Waterfall
Waterfall.effects: Waterfall deals damage and has a 20% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Waterfall.changes: In Generations 1-3, Waterfall has no secondary effect.
Waterfall.gameDescription: The user charges at the target and may make it flinch.

Weather Ball.name: Weather Ball
Weather Ball.effects:
The power and type of Weather Ball changes with the weather. With no weather condition it is Normal and has a base power of 50. If a weather condition is in effect, its power doubles to 100 and the move becomes a different type: 
Bright sunlight: Fire type
Heavy rain: Water type
Sandstorm: Rock type
Hailstorm: Ice type
Fog: stays Normal type (but power still doubles)
 Weather Ball will receive STAB where appropriate - for example by Vanilluxe during a hailstorm, or Castform during sun, rain or hail since it transforms into the appropriate type. In sun and rain, the power of Weather Ball will gain an additional 50% power because Fire- and Water-type moves are boosted respectively in those conditions. (Other weather conditions don't receive any type boost.)
Weather Ball.gameDescription: This attack move varies in power and type depending on the weather.

Whirlpool.name: Whirlpool
Whirlpool.effects: Whirlpool inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the opponent in the vortex, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns. If the opponent is hidden underwater from using Dive, Whirlpool will hit with double power.
Whirlpool.changes: In Generations 1-4, Whirlpool has a base power of 15 and 70% accuracy. Its after-effects last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5.

Whirlwind.name: Whirlwind
Whirlwind.effects: In the wild, Whirlwind blows the target Pokémon away if they are of a lower level, and the battle ends. In trainer battles (including linked battles), Whirlwind forces the target to switch out of battle (regardless of level) and is replaced with another Pokémon in the trainer's team. Pokémon with the ability Suction Cups or those rooted by Ingrain are not affected by Whirlwind.
Whirlwind.changes: In Generations 1-5, Whirlwind has 100% accuracy (in other words, it is affected by Accuracy and Evasion stats). In Generations 1-4, Whirlwind works on any level Pokémon in wild battles. Whirlwind has a priority of -5 in Generation 3 and -1 in Generation 2. In Generation 1, Whirlwind has no priority and only causes wild battles to end with no effect in trainer battles.
Whirlwind.gameDescription: The target is blown away, and a different Pokémon is dragged out. In the wild, this ends a battle against a single Pokémon.

Wide Guard.name: Wide Guard
Wide Guard.effects: Wide Guard protects the user's team from all multi-target moves for that turn, such as Surf or Earthquake. Since its priority is +3 it will be used before all damage-dealing moves. Its accuracy drops to 50% if used consecutively after itself, Detect, Protect, Endure or Quick Guard.
Wide Guard.gameDescription: The user and its allies are protected from wide-ranging attacks for one turn.
Wide Guard.target: Targets all Pokemon on the user’s team.

Wild Charge.name: Wild Charge
Wild Charge.effects: Wild Charge deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄4 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 100 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 25 HP.
Wild Charge.gameDescription: The user shrouds itself in electricity and smashes into its target. This also damages the user a little.

Will-O-Wisp.name: Will-O-Wisp
Will-O-Wisp.effects: Will-O-Wisp causes the target to become burned, if it hits. Burned Pokémon lose 1⁄8 of their maximum HP each turn and their Attack is decreased by 50%. Fire type Pokémon, those with the ability Water Veil or those behind a Substitute cannot be burned.
Will-O-Wisp.gameDescription: The user shoots a sinister, bluish-white flame at the target to inflict a burn.

Wing Attack.name: Wing Attack
Wing Attack.effects: Wing Attack deals damage with no additional effect, besides being able to hit non-adjacent Pokémon in triple battles.
Wing Attack.changes: In Generation 1, Wing Attack has a base power of 35.
Wing Attack.gameDescription: The target is struck with large, imposing wings spread wide to inflict damage.
Wing Attack.target: Targets any single Pokemon on the field including non-adjacent ones.

Wish.name: Wish
Wish.effects: The user recovers HP in the following turn.
Wish.gameDescription: One turn after this move is used, the user’s or its replacement’s HP is restored by half the user’s max HP.

Withdraw.name: Withdraw
Withdraw.effects: Withdraw raises the user's Defense by one stage. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Withdraw.gameDescription: The user withdraws its body into its hard shell, raising its Defense stat.

Wonder Room.name: Wonder Room
Wonder Room.effects: Wonder Room switches the Defense and Special Defense of all Pokémon in battle, for 5 turns.
Wonder Room.gameDescription: The user creates a bizarre area in which Pokémon’s Defense and Sp. Def stats are swapped for five turns.

Wood Hammer.name: Wood Hammer
Wood Hammer.effects: Wood Hammer deals damage, but the user receives 1⁄3 of the damage it inflicted in recoil. In other words, if the attack does 90 HP damage to the opponent, the user will lose 30 HP.
Wood Hammer.gameDescription: The user slams its rugged body into the target to attack. This also damages the user quite a lot.

Work Up.name: Work Up
Work Up.effects: Work Up raises the user's Attack and Special Attack by one stage each. Stats can be raised to a maximum of +6 stages each.
Work Up.gameDescription: The user is roused, and its Attack and Sp. Atk stats increase.

Worry Seed.name: Worry Seed
Worry Seed.effects: Worry Seed changes the target's ability to Insomnia, which prevents the Pokémon from falling asleep. If the move is used on a sleeping Pokémon, it will wake up on its next turn. Worry Seed does not work on Pokémon with the ability Truant or Multitype.
Worry Seed.gameDescription: A seed that causes worry is planted on the target. It prevents sleep by making the target’s Ability Insomnia.

Wrap.name: Wrap
Wrap.effects: Wrap inflicts damage on the first turn then traps the opponent, causing them to lose 1⁄16 of their maximum HP after each turn, for 4-5 turns. If the user holds a Grip Claw then it is always 5 turns.
Wrap.changes: In Generations 1-4, Wrap has 85% accuracy. Its after-effects last for 2-5 turns instead of 4-5. In Generation 1, Wrap simply inflicts its base power damage for 2-5 turns. While in effect, the target is unable to attack.
Wrap.gameDescription: A long body, vines, or the like are used to wrap and squeeze the target for four to five turns.

Wring Out.name: Wring Out
Wring Out.effects:
Wring Out inflicts more damage when the opponent's HP is higher. At full HP its base power is 120 and it decreases in proportion - i.e. the power is: 120 × CurrentHP ÷ MaxHP
 Wring Out is a Special-category counterpart move to Crush Grip. It is also similar to Water Spout and Eruption, based on the opponent rather than the user.
Wring Out.gameDescription: The user powerfully wrings the target. The more HP the target has, the greater the move’s power.

X-Scissor.name: X-Scissor
X-Scissor.effects: X-Scissor deals damage with no additional effect.
X-Scissor.gameDescription: The user slashes at the target by crossing its scythes or claws as if they were a pair of scissors.

Yawn.name: Yawn
Yawn.effects: Yawn makes the target drowsy on the turn it is used. If the target is still on the field at the end of the next turn, it falls asleep. Sleeping Pokémon cannot move (with some exceptions such as Snore). Sleep lasts for 1-3 turns. Pokémon with the abilities Insomnia or Vital Spirit, or those behind a Substitute cannot be put to sleep.
Yawn.gameDescription: The user lets loose a huge yawn that lulls the target into falling asleep on the next turn.

Zap Cannon.name: Zap Cannon
Zap Cannon.effects: Zap Cannon deals damage and paralyzes the target, if it hits. Paralyzed Pokémon have a 25% chance of not being able to attack, and their Speed is decreased by 75%. Electric type Pokémon, those with the ability Limber or those behind a Substitute cannot be paralyzed.
Zap Cannon.changes: In Generations 2-3, Zap Cannon has base power 100.
Zap Cannon.gameDescription: The user fires an electric blast like a cannon to inflict damage and cause paralysis.

Zen Headbutt.name: Zen Headbutt
Zen Headbutt.effects: Zen Headbutt deals damage and has a 20% chance of causing the target to flinch (if the target has not yet moved). Pokémon with the ability Inner Focus or those behind a Substitute cannot be made to flinch.
Zen Headbutt.gameDescription: The user focuses its willpower to its head and attacks the target. This may also make the target flinch.

Zing Zap.name: Zing Zap
Zing Zap.effects: A strong electric blast crashes down on the target, giving it an electric shock. This may also make the target flinch.
Zing Zap.gameDescription: A strong electric blast crashes down on the target, giving it an electric shock. This may also make the target flinch.
